Here's the logic;
1.) This software is exactly the same as version 11, with the exception of being 64 bit and it can be adjusted to use popular brand GPUs.
In other words, some one familiar with version 11 sees very little difference in the layout except some additional plugins.
Version 11 has a nice user base, and a good rating from people who use it.
Users of lower versions of this product, who have upgraded to this 64 bit version have reported a huge difference in speed. Look for yourself.

2.) Version 12 \\"stand alone\\", has a good rating right here on Amazon. This suite IS version 12 stand alone, with additional programs included!
Judge the ratings by viewing Music Studio Platinum 12. But also check out version 11's reviews. Look elsewhere besides Amazon for more reviews.

3.) Included with the \\"stand alone\\" version of \\"Music Studio Platinum 12\\", is \\"Sound Forge Audio 10\\".
This also is a stand-alone program that seemlessly melds into the video program.
The 2 combined stand alone prices, are well above the Suite price. Check it out.
I already own and use Sony's Acid Pro 7, and the layout of both Sony products in Movie Studio PL 12 have the same work flow.

4.) I have asked questions about this product from a certain person who makes instuctional videos on how to use this and other \\"Sony Vegas\\" incarnations.
His videos are easily found on the internet.
I asked him about the compatability between the suites 64 bit Movie Studio, and the 32 bit Sound forge.( I bet you never thought of that! )
He explained, Both programs are working with manipulating files. And they work together very well.
A 64 bit program or a 32 bit program, do not change an MP3 file into 32 bit or 64 bit! Video files are the same!
He explained that it has to do with speed. Music files are small. So a 32 bits is fast for rendering music.
Rendering even complex music files, is nothing compared to rendering video. Especially the video Movie Studio is capable of producing. Thus 64 bit is an upgrade!

Yes this is \\"Sony VEGAS Music Studio HD Platinum Production Suite 12\\". Sony just decided to remove the words \\"Vegas\\", \\"HD\\", and \\"Production\\".
I will update my opinion, as soon as I receive and use the product. I may have to eat Humble Pie, but I don't let that deter me from what I expect to be a good upgrade
after mastering Windows Movie Maker. LOL!
Let's Face it, most people examining this product are looking to upgrade from something simpler, but they're not looking for something as complex as \\"full on\\" Premier or Vegas.

Secondary review: I was not surprised when I recieved Sony Movie StudioPlatinum 12 Suite, that it was what I expected, and more.
The main disk includes 3 Sony stand alone programs, that can be purchased separately at a higher cost.
1.) Movie Studio Platinum 12
2.) DVD Architech Studio 5
3.) Sound Forge Audio 10

The bonus content disk contains:
1.)NewBlueFX 3D titling and Video effects
2.)iZotope Vocal Eraser
3.)Red Giant Magic Bullet Quick looks

Each of these disks are accompanied by a corresponding pamphlet, that contains all the serial numbers for your programs. Very nice!
Besides the extras on the bonus disks, the main program contains many many different video transitions, video effects, as well as the same for audio.
You really don't need any of the things on the extras disk. But they are powerful tools, that allow for creative freedom.
But, if you dig deeper on the original program disk, after you have installed, you can open and explore the folders, and find 50 royalty free Sony music tracks.
And something I didn't see advertised; 1001 high quality sound effects.

The main program is easy to use, if you have an interest in video editing. But just like buying a guitar will not make you know how to play it, you have to want to edit your videos!
Sony provides at a cost, many instructional DVDs use can buy and learn how to use this. BUT, Sony sent me an email providing a link to many free official videos they post on YouTube!
This support is what I've already experienced with Sony's Acid Pro 7. It fulfilled my expectations.

So, if I want to know how to add a title, I watch a video, then implement. EZ! How to fuzz out a license plate? Same.
I don't try to learn the whole thing. I just learn new things as I go. If I wonder how to do something, I look it up.
The program itself is professional grade. It works fast and smooth. Renders are very tight and sharp. It is a good choice.

This product is not accurately represented by the manufacturer. It is nearly impossible to contact their 24/7 customer support. You CANNOT contact support through the process of loading software. One must get online (without antivirus protection) to attempt to locate contact information and once you finally find the number through a separate website and call, you will be put on terminal 'hold'. Upon loading the software my compter immediately locked up. The CD could not be removed. Afer several reboots I was able to finally remove the CD. Was extremely disappointed. Disks did not work in my Mac computer and I even ordered set for Mac. I am used to Clipart program through internet and it is so easy to work with but have to pay $125.00 per year. Was looking to save some $ but have decided to renew my subscription to Clipart.

Having bought and installed every version of Windows this installation and upgrade (from Windows Home XP) was the smoothest. Microsoft's Beta testing appears to have been very successful. By the way, I am just an average home computer user.

Vista first inventories the software and hardware and indexes whatever files are needed for the transfer. Then it installs, which took about an hour in my case on a Celeron D CPU at 2.13 Megahertz and a little over 1G of memory, with the standard Dell-Intel graphics chips (not exactly a high-end computer).

The look and feel and the interfaces and integration of Vista with other software is awesome. The software has killer diagnostic tools that are a cut above the usual third party software algorithms--for example, Vista remembers what has been tried and tells you so if you try to repeat a recommended \\"fix\\". I liked, and installed two \\"gadgets\\" in the left sidebar--a floating office--style clock and a calendar.

All the software on my machine functioned after the install and reboot, even software Vista identified as possibly not working--in my case, the Intellipoint mouse software. It did work just fine.

The install did kill my broadband internet connection for a brief time; and after going 'round and 'round with the idiots at Adelphia/Comcast customer service--who stated that company modems did not work with Vista, and that they are not ready to offer help for their customer running Vista (do not believe them)--I fixed the connection after discovering (through a Vista diagnostic tool) that competing firewalls from Windows Security Center and Windows Live One Care were blocking inbound streams.

In fact, Vista has a very nice feature in its Windows Security Center (that helped me fix my broadband connectivity) which tells you when you have competing security features enabled. In my case, it was two firewalls, one of which (Windows Live One Care), wasset to \\"restricted\\". When I removed this firewall, and left the Security Center firewall enabled everything worked perfectly.

By the way, despite what I read elsewhere, my iTunes runs smoothly. I also have lots of third party software (defraggers, spy removal software, password software, etc.) on my computer, and all of it, except the well-known buggy and unstable System Mechanic 7, operates without problems, and did so without having to download \\"patches\\".

I believe Microsoft did a great job on producing and testing Vista. I highly recommend it to anyone that wants to move beyond XP.

We got this for my 11 year-old for Christmas. We the option for him to use 3 different options from basic options to expert options he is able to use it easily. As he gets older he can learn more advanced things in the program. It was a wonderful option to get him away from video games!

Man what a problem this software created. Upon installation it deleted my very well running copy of Norton's Antivirus 2004. My system was slowed down so much it was like having an old 286 processor again. The crashes were mounting and \\"customer no support\\" if you can find it on the site was absolutely no help at all. Had to uninstall the product which is when I found the Antivirus Ver 4. was gone and I had no virus protection. Then to top everything off I dug out the AV 4. disk and found it had been cracked. Naturally Symantec refused to help resolve the problem I would not have had if I had not installed AV 2005. Every time I tried to tell the software that an email was not spam it would lock up the system requiring a re-boot.

AV 2005 is gone and is my AV ver.4 Still waiting on credit from them on my credit card. Purchasing a competitors product even though I have used Norton's since they first came out.

THIS SOFTWARE IS GARBAGE........ DO NOT BUY IT AND IF YOU DID DO NOT INSTALL IT. Much better off keeping ver. 4 and keeping your subscription unless like me you cannot replace AV Ver. 4. and you are simply screwed.

The key value of this product is the ability to sync large or many files across machines. I travel a lot, so being able to synchronize my laptop files with my office and home workstation is the whole point of Laplink Gold. You can imagine, then, my horror at finding that this product does not work with my laptop: Dell Latitude CS 400XT. Plug in the USB cable, and the system hard resets! Very nasty.
Back in November 2000, the online support admitted that \\"other problems with laptops have been reported\\", and they would contact me with details of a patch as soon as one is available. I have heard nothing to date. Furthermore, their website makes no mention of laptops that do or don't work with this product. No mind for the customer. They just take your money, and fob you off.
When added to the USB cable price, the entire package costs around $200, but provides no value at all. To all prospective purchasers: BE CAREFUL (or be ready to demand your money back).

I am fairly new to bookkeeping and completely new to QB. I am the office personnel for a rural church. Our needs differ from most businesses. Our purpose and our tax regulations don't fit the mold of a typical non-profit foundation either. These unique differences make the bulk of the training videos and manuals very tedious and confusing to adapt in a practical way. I could not have deciphered and used the product without the amazing techs that are available, patient, kind, enjoyable, and efficient. They have taught me the best way to accomplish my goals. I did watch the videos and have a manual and they have been very helpful, but the final breakthroughs usually come with the help of a tech.

My friends persuaded me that I didn't need to spend $ on my accountant for basic deductions (mortgage, second home loan, charities, work expenses, etc.) and that TurboTax was user- friendly and just as effective. For the most part, TurboTax lived up to my expectations. However, as a first-time user, I made a few mistakes (didn't have all of my wife's documentation and I lost a charity receipt that I had recorded in my computer records) so I had to resubmit. I hoped that, since I found these errors just minutes after submitting my TurboTax for direct bank deposit, that I could start all over again without amending my taxes and having to print out the amendment and having to send it snail mail to the IRS and state. I was wrong. Once you submit your results, you have to amend any caught mistakes no matter how soon after, which can put a red flag on your finances and catch the attention of the IRS and state. I've never been audited and the very thought is troubling indeed. Next year I will use TurboTax again but I will make sure I have dotted every \\"i\\" and crossed every \\"t\\" before I submit my final results. I hope my lesson can be of value to others and spare them unnecessary anxieties.

I recently discovered that this great consumer software - Easy Media Creator 7 - that I use for my own personal and family fun could also be used for some of my work projects. Not everyone in the world has PowerPoint, and if they do, they may not have the same fonts installed on their PC as the slideshow you are trying to share with them, etc. So creating and sharing slideshows that everyone can view can be a challenge. I just got back from attending a conference and trade show last week where I took a bunch of pictures. In no time I downloaded them and turned them into an annotated and audio narrated slideshow using Creator 7. I then had our Webmaster post it on our Intranet site and now co-workers from around the world can watch a quick summary of my show observations. It made me look like a star at work!
No problems with software installation and my computer runs smoothe. The 360 Program did not slow-up my computer.

As with all of my Amazon purchases to date, overall service is 5 stars. I start the review with this, because I purchased the product as an unwilling participant. I've been a QB user for at least twelve years and have upgraded the product based on a willingness to upgrade and improve my accounting systems. This upgrade has me a little more than annoyed as it was an unwilling upgrade. As many have felt, the current economy has all businesses scrambling to save themselves financially. QB decided their current subscribers needed to upgrade their entire accounting system in order to cure a systems security issue with their online mail and credit card processing, in-lieu-of a security patch. The minimum cost to upgrade is appx. $230.00+++. While $230.00 may not seem like a lot of money when spread over the years, when times are tight $20.00 seems to have value again. Without the upgrade, my business would have come to a creep with the discontinued abilities to electronically bill or send e-mails. Since the QB system is all proprietary, a user cannot cut-n-paste an invoice to send over their own private e-mail systems with the older versions, it requires the use of QB to accomplish this through the QB servers. That's the bad side. The good side is, QB now allows the use of private e-mail v. going through the QB servers to e-mail invoices, with a small hitch, QB asks for the e-mail password every time an e-mail billing or statement is sent through private e-mail. If there is a \\"remember me\\" command, I cannot find it in the set-up or help links. The new QB look and feel is better than ever, just as easy to use as before, with the added benefit of not having to use their server to electronically send invoices. Overall I'm pleased with the product, the timing was very bad and didn't allow for a planned purchase. Less than a months warning was given that the older version would expire and rendered useless for what I required. Amazon receives even more credit for hosting a great price, 1/3 the cost elsewhere, as well as delivering as promised.
Product was priced well, it was delivered on time and works as well or better than the Turbo Tax soft ware I have used in the past.
This cord worked well for the first few months but then developed a loose connection and broke. Poor quality it seems.

I have version 2.0 for Mac and bought 4.0 pro so that my wife could have an easier time e-mailing photos.
The e-mailing utility works great, but it doesn't store mails you've sent for later review and it doesn't allow for easy viewing of pictures you're selecting for mailing.
The print feature also works much better, or at least it did until I treid using it under OS 9.2.2. Under OS X things worked fine, but I had to downgrade for other reasons and have been unable to print to my HP Photosmart ever since. Their tech support was not very supportive. Anyway, when it was working it made much more efficient use of paper and it allowed you to select photos from multiple different directories, unlike the previous version.
However, what I liked about the old version was that it was drag-and-drop friendly. It was easier to transfer files between directories this way, and so it is infinitely harder to organize photos under version 4.0.
Generally, it seems that whoever wrote the software wasn't completely familiar with Macs. A lot of the convenient and powerful shortcuts we Mac folks use are not served by this program.
If I had to do it over again I wouldn't buy it. If they work out the above-mentioned bugs soon, though, then it's worth it.

Great for beginners and intermediates! I purchased this cd-rom for a very fair price. Since downloading it and going through a few of the sections I find this simply amazing! First, I think Keith Wyatt is an excellent teacher, specifically via DVD. He appears throughout the sections of this cd-rom. Second, this cd-rom has EVERYTHING! If you're into the blues and learning how not only to play but where the playing derived from, this is definitely for you. You can go to specific riffs and then click on icons to get the lowdown on scales, modes, etc... It tells you the history, the methods and the uses for everything. Awesome! This program has a virtual fretboard that you can slow/speed as it plays. It loops and sections off whatever parts you feel you need to look at again. It shows actual videos of Wyatt playing or teaching as well as computerized methods. There's too much to list as to what this can do for you. I love it already and I've hardly delved into the meat of it all. What I like so far is that this cd-rom teaches you what the blues is. If you want to pick up a guitar and become a rock and roll god overnight this is not for you. But if you want to learn a little something about the heart and soul of The Blues this is definitely a fantastic tool for your blues education and training. I highly suggest paying the small price for something like this. It's fun and, if you take the time, can really teach you some great things on the guitar.

I've been using Photoshop Element and Album since 1.0.

Contrary to what you may think, PE 3 is NOT Album 2.0 bundled with the image editor. It is one huge app with different intrinsic components: editor and browser.

Album 2.0 was good enough for my needs (pics and video clips cataloguing) but lacked a critical feature: watched folders (found in Picasa and ACDSEE). PE 3 has this feature, thus my decision to upgrade.

Below are the major issues I've been having with PE 3 are:
======================================
1- Video clips catalog is busted: only small clips are recognized while Sony 640x480 30fps clips show up as broken thumbnails. This worksd fine with Album 2.0.

2- Because of the above problem, the Browser is extremely slow to the point to appear being frozen. I had no choice but to disable 'Video' as an authorized media type...This alone is a showstopper for me.

3- Sluggish performance: launching and switching between editor and browser is slow (I have a P4 2G, 768MB RAM, nVidia GeForce ti 4200 with 64MB video card, WinXP Pro SP2)

If I wanted to catalog pics only, I'd use Miocrosoft Digital Suite, which is by far the faster app, not to mention the EXIF support wich is awesome (keywords are actually saved in the picture itself!)

Now because I need to tag video clips and pics, I'll be buying ACDSEE v.7.0. My friend ahs it and it is a great product: fast, video, pics and music cataloging. Their keywords is using a tree-like structure which is not as elegant as Adobe's tagging mechanism, but I'll live...

Hope that review helps.
p.s. In case you are wondering, I've purchased PE 3.0 for Windows from the Adobe store ten days ago.

I've been playing around with this app for the last month and have found that it fits solidly in that space between photo-editing software and full-fledged graphics design software.

What I mean by that statement is that this software offers a lot of creative capability - far more than an application like [[ASIN:B00EOQZB0A Adobe Photoshop Elements]]. Having said that, the additional capabilities come at the cost of increased complexity & cost, which means most casual users won't even consider it.

In our case, we were considering using Painter instead of the full-blown [[ASIN:B007USG3OC Adobe Photoshop]]. All-in-all, this is an excellent replacement; but, it turns out that X3 does not support vector graphics. It won't even open existing vector files - which is a deal breaker for us.

Overall, I would say that Painter X3 has a good interface and a lot of potential for people who want to move to the 'next level' when it comes to digital creativity. As long as you don't need vector support, I suspect this will fit the bill perfectly.

If you've seen this program in use and you know in advance what you will be getting, and that's what you want, then go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, exercise extreme caution. It is very powerful and capable. But it is also a very complex piece of software and not easy to learn. I tried it, decided it was several light-years beyond what I wanted, and chose to uninstall it.

And that's when the fun started.

Pinnacle installs about a dozen different applications when you run its installer. But when you run its uninstaller, it removes only the base application and leaves everything else on your disk--gigabytes worth of software. It took me an entire afternoon with Revo Uninstaller to get my PC back to where it had been beforehand. I had to find all the apps Pinnacle had installed, remove them one by one, and then remove *hundreds* of registry entries and *hundreds* of directories that each app's uninstaller failed to deal with. It was a nightmare and I'm still wondering what I might have missed and what will now fail to work because I deleted something I shouldn't have. It was an unmitigated disaster.

I would recommend that if you decide on installing this, that you first create a Windows Restore point. Then, choose the \\"Custom\\" install and just do the Pinnacle application itself. If you want all the other add-ons and libraries and tools, you can add them later, and if you decide to uninstall, you'll have a much easier time than I did.

I installed it on a Windows 7 laptop that is less than a year old. The software install went fine. I plugged in the included USB device and Windows installed the driver. Based on other reviews I asked the software to get updates. There weren't any. I fired up the VHS, selected the edit button because I want to save the videos to a hard drive. I can always burn them to DVD later. I started the capture and saved a 40 minute video to disk. it took about 2.5 gig of disk space. I did stop most other applications and did nothing on the laptop while the recording completed. I read most of the other reviews posted for this product. I have an idea why some folks may have had so much trouble with it. This kind of application can be CPU intensive and if folks were trying to do almost anything else on a typical PC they probably caused enough interrupts that the software just gave up trying to process the incoming tape stream and burn it to DVD at the same time. [[ASIN:B001LQO4P4 Roxio Easy VHS to DVD]]

I researched movie editors for months, before buying Sony Vegas Movie Studio 9 Platinum Pro Pack. Did I make the right choice? Yes, however this product is only usable if you have good general computer skills, and have the ability to learn through trial and error. I would not recommend this product if you expect to produce a masterpiece in one day.
What do you get in this package?
Vegas Movie Studio Platinum 9 - program to edit digital movie, add soundtracks, voice-overs, and fancy text, rolling credits, etc.
DVD Architect Studio - program to author DVD's, so you end up with professional quality DVD menus with all the bells and whistles
Sound Forge Audio Studio - a music editing program, with the added ability to convert all your L.P.'s and cassettes into digital format, so that you can then make CD's or load them onto your IPod.
Cinescore Studio 1.0 - free music of various genres, to add to your productions to give them a professional sound

There was one major problem with this software when I first loaded it, that I only managed to fix by pure luck. The problem was quite a major one. In the version which comes on CD-ROM, there is a bug which stops the soundtrack from MPEG2 files from loading into the editior program. This is incredible considering that almost every digital camcorder on the market uses the MPEG2 format, including Sony. However!!! Once you have loaded the program and registered, you need to go to the Sony update software web page. Here you will find a download that fixes many bugs in the program, including the MPEG2 problem.
There is another problem with the program if you are going to buying this to upload videos to You Tube. In the last couple of months You Tube has upgraded there video screen to Widescreen (16:9 ratio) format. There is no template in Vegas Movie Studio to handle this. So if you intend on uploading video to You Tube in 16:9, then you will need some advanced computer skills to create your own template. I'm sure Sony will work on this and provide an update to the program in time. At the moment, the program handles traditional 4:3 format for upload to the internet.

There are many cool features hidden within Sony Vegas Movie Studio 9 Platinum Pro Pack. Only the basics are discussed in the instructional booklets that come with the program. If you explore all the alien like buttons and features, through trial and error, you will be more than happy with this software.
6/10 for ease of use
9.5/10 for cool features
All the best with your movie editing and DVD production.
Regards D.

My son-in-law is comfortable with Lightroom and uses it well, so I tried it. I found it to be vastly different from previous generations of the full Photoshop software. Even after trying it, I am not certain I understand the differences. The major difference MAY BE that Lightroom allows across the board corrections and modifications over many images at once, whereas Elements allows image by image manipulation. Without extensive reading, study and tutorials, I had difficulty figuring out how to work on a single image at a time with Lightroom. I did use Lightroom successfully to create a slide show fairly easily. But this can be done with several software packages.

In the end, I uninstalled and sold Lightroom and replaced it with Elements 11.

Having had the same experience with Rosetta Stone as many of the reviewers here have described, I went in search of an alternative program that would give me the tools to say more than \\"The horse runs\\" and \\"The man eats rice\\" (Rosetta Stone is quite enjoyable, but better for vocab than for anything you can actually utilize in real life). I came across Fluenz, tried out the online demo and was hooked. I was amazed at the amount of info that stuck, even after one lesson. I completed level one in 3 weeks, which is probably faster than recommended, however, I looked forward to working on the lessons each day, and often had to stop myself from doing too many lessons at a time. I'm now in the middle of Level 2 and I'm starting to think in French. I'm often surprised at the number of structures I can put together (OK, some faster than others). The program is structured so that each lesson builds on the last and the explanations during the tutorial sessions are invaluable. Additional practice sessions on the audio CD's and podcasts help to further hammer the information into your brain. There's also a Facebook page that allows you to communicate with other Fluenz users and an additional site called the \\"Fluenz Commons\\", where newly developed flashcards are available. iPhone and iPad apps are on the way. I haven't needed to contact customer service, but based on other reviews, it's great. And no, I don't work for Fluenz. Just a very happy customer. If you're hesitating to purchase this, don't. It's the best $500 I've spent recently. Fluenz is a sleek, effective program, and most importantly, if you have realistic expectations and are willing to put in the time and effort required, it works.

I've used the past few versions of Adobe Photoshop Elements and I really enjoy using it. You can clean up or manipulate your images in a lot of different ways. A bigger problem with PSE10 is that the Organizer still has problems importing my photos. The import fails the same way PSE9 did. Because I can't use the Organizer at all, I only use Photoshop Elements as a photo editor and use Google's free Picasa program as my organizer. I'm not sure how much I would've liked Organizer, but I'm not that disappointed since Picasa is very, very good.

I've run PSE10 on both a Windows 7 64-bit PC and Mac OS X 10.6.8 without any crashes or performance issues.

I have been using Parallels 8 on my new Macbook Pro (the June 2012 model, dual core i5 processor) for over a month now, and have had exactly zero problems so far. I didn't expect this because I used to run Parallels 6 on an older Intel iMac in the past and that gave me nothing but trouble (horrible performance being problem number 1). Windows XP, Windows 7 and Windows 8 all run on my Macbook Pro as they should. The reason I decided to give Parallels 8 a try is because of its supposed higher speed and stability over VMware 5 and previous versions of Parallels.

Windows 8 is speedy enough on my machine that games from 2003-2005 run effortlessly in a 1600*1200 resolution, as well as various more serious applications. Applications that I frequently run in Parallels are:
- both \\"Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic\\" games (run great but Parallels GPU emulator doesn't support AA or buffer effects)
- \\"Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines\\" (runs flawlessly with the latest unofficial patch from the Patch Scrolls)
- MS Office Visio 2010
- Several password cracking algorithms (can be quite CPU-intensive)
- Several computer forensics applications, such as ProDiscover.
- Skyrim and Fallout 3 (were playable at a mix of the lowest and medium settings, don't expect to complete a round of Skyrim or Fallout 3 on a virtualized machine)

The Coherence mode works very well, I love using it for running programs with smaller user interfaces like ProDiscover. While in Coherence, you can run individual Windows programs in full-screen, which gives them their own Mac OS Desktop (accessible through \\"CTRL\\" + \\"up arrow\\"), and which also enables you to flick through your Windows apps with a three-fingered swipe like you would in Mac OS 10.8.

Finally, I should note that my Macbook Pro contains 16 GB of memory and uses a Corsair Force GT solid state drive, but Parallels ran on my notebook without issues before I performed these upgrades. It's also pretty clear that you would need at *least* 4 GB of memory to run a virtualized Windows 8 instance on top of Mac OS, and you'll find that having anywhere over 4 gigabytes makes a world of difference.

I wholeheartedly recommend Parallels 8! The only thing I miss is the ability to enable anti-aliasing in video games, but that is of no consequence anyway.

Delphi is the best all around tool i've used. You can do everything you can do in C++ and it's so easy. It's learning curve is almost the same one to learn Visual Basic. You can create apps, web server extensions, dlls, ActiveX Objects and ActiveX dlls, Control Panel applets, your own controls and much more. You have tons of components, and you can get more tons of them for free at the web.

I own both the IMSI (FloorPlan 3D Version 5) and Punch (Architect 4000) software titles, and the following are my own conclusions. I have no vested interest in either manufacturer. I have a doctorate in Mechanical Engineering, and have taught interactive computer graphics, so I guess I am more than usually familiar with computers and design.

I designed my previous home using the IMSI package, and after using it to capture the design, I passed it along to a draftsman to create drawings for the permitting process. I found that the package was easy to use (although a bit weird), and that it generally worked great. When we moved in, the home was absolutely spectacular! So, when we moved to another state to retire, we decided to repeat the process. Even though I still had the IMSI software (Version 5) and it readily installed onto XP, I thought that surely there had been improvements. So, I took the time to find the \\"best package out there\\". The reviews I read said that the Punch (Architect 4000) package was rated best, had the most features, blah, blah, blah. So I bought it, in spite of paying approximately 3X what I would pay for the latest IMSI version of FloorPlan 3D. The manual is about an inch thick, but I started wading through, thinking that this was the learning cost of a really good package. The manual seemed reasonable and there are TONS of features (read complexity), but when I actually tried to use the program, I couldn't get anything done. Everything was hard to do. Then, and this was the killer for me, whenever I saved data, I could never read the file back in. I tried everything, and eventually thought that it was my fault, so I went back to my old IMSI package because I had a house to design.

I quickly got up to speed because IMSI wins out hands down for its simple user interface. I struggled with both initially, but soon found that IMSI's wall layout tool, while weird, was useable. It's ease of use (tailorable wall heights, pushing even non-rectilinear wall segments around, changing wall thicknesses, immediate demonstration of dimensions and room square footage, changing wall and floor materials, colors, and texture, etc) allowed one to work pretty quickly. I was never able to use Punch's layout editor efficiently. Ever! Forget saving the data so you could work on a design again. Even just creating a simple layout was a huge struggle. Unless you knew the design beforehand, it was very difficult to lay out a floor plan interactively. This was what IMSI was good at. Even with a fully designed floorplan, I had trouble with the Punch program.

IMSI was also the easiest in viewing your design in 3D. Again, the viewing tools were weird and somewhat non-intuitive, but eventually useful. Punch's 3D viewer was totally useless, and I was never able to control the views, no matter what I did. And, \\"Hey!\\", I taught computer graphics.

After spending many hours getting a complete design (from my working with IMSI) entered into a freshly-reloaded Punch, I again tried to save my work. When I went back to work on it some more, it was unreadable. The file was there, but there was some formatting error that made it unreadable. I was furious, but thankfully, I had the IMSI design captured. So, I had a decision- Waste more time trying to debug a program I had paid 3X more for than the IMSI FloorPlan 3D, or spend my time getting work done on my house plan. Actually, I downloaded a free upgrade to Version 5.1 and got busy. Now I am thinking of purchasing IMSI's Version 11 as I am finalizing our house plan and like some of the new features and abilities of the new software.

To be candid, neither software package was bug-free. IMSI occasionally doesn't allow you to move a wall, but that is almost always because there is some constraint that is disallowing the modification. I found Punch to be even more restrictive. While I was able to exportthe IMSI design as a vrml file and e-MAIL it to my son to review, Punch had the greatest number of export file options. Too bad it always lost my saved designs. Neither package really creates beautiful 3D graphics, but IMSI's simple renderings were adequate for previewing the design work. I also liked IMSI's design methods using internal room dimensions. But, neither program made it clear how to proceed in starting a design from scratch. Nowhere did they tell you whether you could design the 2nd floor first, whether you had to layout the foundation beforehand (Punch), etc.

Finally, I should mention that I wanted to input site information for my lot, but that was too costly in terms of time. Interestingly, I downloaded Google's free Sketchup software, imported my IMSI design (in dxf file format), and was able to place it on the terrain using a Sketchup to Google Earth tool, and then interactively view it in 3D on my 10 acre lot using Google Earth. I found out that I have some serious grading and fill work to do on the build site.

PSE8 for Mac is great for all the reasons covered by the previous reviewers. I have a hunch there are others 'out there' who have intuitively discovered the grand set of tools available in PS and PSE, who may appreciate the following discoveries (much to my dismay and disappointment) before making any kind of upgrade to this version. The bottom line (and this is after several correspondences with Adobe tech support) is that many of my precious plug-in's (Kai Power Tools and Xaos Terrazzo) DO NOT work with this version!! Also, although brush,shape and gradient files can be added (dropped into the appropriate folders), the styles files CANNOT be added!! Anyone who has worked extensively with styles will know how valuable they are! There is an assortment of 'canned styles' included, but if you go to the preset manager there is no longer even a drop down to select 'styles' as in other versions of PS and PSE!! If any of this is of significance to a reviewer, and helps to avoid making a hasty purchase, then I will feel a little better about my own hasty rush to upgrade. Will I use PSE8? Of course, but I will stay primarily though, with the earlier versions that allow free addition of styles and work with my precious plug-ins! I'm so disappointed, but am learning the hard lesson that newest and latest, isn't always the best choice!!

I have used Turbo Tax since the early 2000' s (with one exception in 2006, when I used TaxCut) and have been somewhat satisfied. I just finished my taxes for 2013 (yes, it's late, but I have an extension to October 15) and find that for some reason, I have had significantly more issues with the 2013 version. Because of this, I need to mail in my return because TTax will not electronically file a return to the IRS if the taxpayer has overridden one of its entries. The foreign tax credit (FTC) component has a huge problem. A taxpayer is allow to claim the entire credit on Line 47 of Form 1040 if it is no more than $300 (single) or $600 (married). The taxpayer can claim the entire amount with no reduction. However, I have not been able to do this on TTax without performing an override because TTax generates a Form 1116 which performs some calculations which result in a reduction of the credit. It is true that Form 1116 does not have to be filed in this case; the problem is that the calculations are affecting the line item on the 1040. The result is that I cannot file this return online. Another shortcoming on TTax Premier is that there is insufficient direction for properly filling out limited partnership information that a taxpayer might receive for, say, holding shares in a MLP (a real possibility if the taxpayer is an income investor). The MLP's Form 1065 has a plethora of information in the \\"Statement\\" section, but much of it cannot be entered into TTax. One final problem: TTax does not download a number of brokerage 1099's. It does this for the more popular brokers (such as Schwab, which downloaded with no problems), but does not do so for Interactive Brokers or Options House. That meant all th e sales have to be hand-entered. These brokerages do not provide sales information in a friendly format, so it can be a bear to have to enter this information manually.

I was initially impressed with the quality of the appearance (nice layout and color choices, like Adobe's pretty logo) and straighforward option titles, but the real beauty is in the output. I installed the software, a ten minute process, and within two hours had an amazing slideshow, using most of the automated options, to use for my daughter's grad party. The user's guide is great. I read all the instructions for making a slideshow while it was installing. It was easy to figure out the steps because every time your mouse hovers over an option, it tells you what that option does. Love that. I was able to import video from my Panasonic HDC-TM55 and my Flip HD camera with no issues. The magic movie option is really, really fun if you don't need to be hands-on and picky about each scene's length or the transitions. I love the idea of 'rooms,' such as the media room, effect room, title room, etc. You know where to go for just what you want to do. The Title room is my favorite because I've been so frustrated with that aspect in other software, like Adobe's Premiere Elements. Making titles in Microsoft's old version of Movie Maker was quite easy, but also quite limited. This is just as easy as Movie Maker, but it's pretty much unlimited in my opinion. You can make titles as easy or complex as you like. I will never use all the options available, but will enjoy the ones I do use. I would suggset this software is best for people who are familiar with video editing software. Beginners should try to download an old version of Movie Maker and stick with that for a while.

I purchased Windows XP Home with service pack 3. The disk I received was Windows XP Professional Corporate Edition. So I am afraid to try to use it because of possible legal action by the corporation that this disk belongs too.

I have used Norton products for the PC and Mac for over 20 years. Based on my latest experience, I will NEVER purchase another Norton product. I installed NIS 2013 shortly after upgrading to Windows 8. NIS 2013 simply doesn't work with Windows 8. I started having problems downloading emails, then problems installing program/app updates. I suspected NIS might be a problem, so I disabled the software. Then I couldn't re-establish NIS. I then uninstalled and reinstalled the NIS, same problems as before. While on the phone with Norton tech support, my computer crashes and I can't recover. They tell me to call Microsoft tech support. Windows recovery disk also doesn't work. MS also can't help, short of telling me to wipe my computer clean, then reinstall Windows 8. Finally, I was able to uninstall NIS while in Safe Mode. By the way, Windows 8 comes with Anti-Virus (which both Norton and MS failed to mention to me). I made sure that Windows 8 anti-virus was enabled and I haven't had a problem since.

Norton - you just lost a customer of 20+ years

Ps is a great product and cs6 really does right by the user. The only reason I give it a 4 instead of a 5, is because of the difficulty of use. Ps has a true learning curve and it isn't user friendly.

I have not found any other software this complete and easy to use. It teaches at my pace. I can review or repeat as much as I need for comprehension. The best on the market! You won't be disappointed.

Because one \\"employer\\" who should be paying me as a subcontractor (I really am self employed) deducts taxes in whatever state you work in (almost all of my work is out of state, and my other W-2 clients deduct my residential state tax or none at all) I have to file more than one state return. This was my first year with Turbo Tax since 2006 tax year. The first state return is included in the Home & Business software and is free. When I went to do the second state return, TurboTax wanted to charge me $39.95. I thought that a bit much and went poking around their website (not designed to get you human interaction very swiftly). The TurboTax \\"chat\\" person told me second state return is $19.95 had I bought the CD version. I explained I downloaded the software from amazon.com (after all it is 2012, and aren't CD's becoming obsolete for software?). He had me uninstall TurboTax, and download a new copy, promising I would be charged $19.95 for 2nd state return. I opened the new download, and it was still $39.95. Ultimately, he gave me the 2nd state return for free. I would have been happy with $19.95 and it did take 45 minutes to get to our conclusion, but free is free. Note that when filling out the state return, the interview asked if I had \\"high deductible\\" health plan. I said yes, knowing that those premiums were already deducted from federal AGI as Self Employed Health Insurance Deduction (SEHID). TurboTax leads me to deduct the health insurance premiums a second time, from AGI, even though the state return gets its info from the TurboTax fed return. I'm waiting for TurboTax tax rep to get back to me on that. I'm sure its an error in TurboTax, and have seen similar double deduction last year in H&R Block software - ironic that it was health insurance premium as well. I have to buy the expensive Home & Business version because I file a Schedule C. Yet it still seems the software is designed for someone in a less complex situation, one employer, period.
Does the job for what I bought it for.

I have used Quickbooks since 1996. Before this version I was using Pro 08 and got caught in the forced upgrade. I am a creature of habit and hate change. BUT can you imagine using the QB from 1996 in 2011? Even though I gripe, whine and complain I know that in the end the upgrade, for the most part, is for the better. I purchased Pro 11 off amazon last week when it was only $99, happy about that. I completed my work for the week and started Fri morning with my install. Some of the reviews on here really scared the heck out of me so I was prepared for a long, tear filled stressful day. I am happy to report that my install could not have been better. Took about 30 minutes and I was up and running. I even got a signature scanned for paychecks & I am working on the logo to get it just right. Everything is exactly how it was and I have no complaints with this new product. This comment is for the QB people on here - one thing that changed from the 2006 to the 2008 version and is the same in 2011 that I am not happy with is in Customers & Jobs. We are in construction. I will have a developer that we do several jobs for, those jobs will have several phases, so it will be at lease 3 teired. In 2006 I could add Developer, right click and add job (job name & info) then right click on that and add phase (job # with phase #). I used to be able to have each phase with a different \\"ship to\\" without having to add a million different ship to addresses. You guys should look at how that was in 2006 and make it like that again. That is probably the only thing I would change in QB.

I moved to Mandrake from RedHat because Mandrake supported a device I had that RedHat did not. This is a nice distro for users new to Linux because it's fairly friendly to install and is one of the best at having built in support for newer hardware. Mandrake also has two community tech support lists that are very active, and their programmers participate regularly. The PowerPack has some nice extras to play with, like ViaVoice and Arkeia network backup software. It seems to install well on a variety of machines. I'm very pleased with its ease of installation and its performance.

Nero 9.0 was an absolute disaster, a disaster made even worse by comments from Nero on their own forum that suggested they were well aware that Nero 9.0 was exceptionally flawed and that there were no quick fixes available.

They said to wait for an update... and in June 2009, an update finally arrived (version 9.4), and it has in my opinion made Nero well again.

However, it was unconscionable that they left everyone with only semi-working software for several months. During those months, people even started writing their own code fixes to restore functionality that had been broken. I imagine many people no longer trust the company after this fiasco.

But for the record, everything seems ok again. And it is a free upgrade from 9.0 to 9.4, of course.

I am very satisfied with the product. It was easy to install and the price was right- about $50.00 less than purchasing it directly from microsoft. It was more economical than buying a new computer system.

Now these are small objects and my old eyes are having a hard time finding all of them now but I keep trying until I find them. There are some surprise and challenges as you play. It isn't one you can get done in a hurry.
My computer continues to run efficiently. I guess Norton is doing its job. This isn't the sort of thing a user can review unless his computer has blown up

Epic Fail out the door. I purchased Microsoft Office Professional Plus 2013, after installing, it will say it is downloading additional content. This window doesn't go away without the assistance of the Task Manager. Microsoft Word has crashed for me all day. It's currently locked up saying \\"Office may appear unresponsive... We're streaming a few required files in the background. This shouldn't take long\\" It's been over 45 minutes now. Support is a Joke. Try it for yourself. I highly recommend waiting until Microsoft deals with the initial release bugs. Stick with 2010 for a while longer. This one was pushed out the door way too early. If you use Microsoft Office, stay with your current version for a while. This version has not let me create a single file and crashes each time it opens. Hallmark Studio use to be good, now it is frankly a piece of crap. Their support is really non-existant they just email you the same instructions they have on their web site. The help file tells you to go to the setup on the Art Studio screen to setup borderless printing...only one problem..there IS NO SETUP option on that screen. No \\"borderless\\" settings work even though I DO have a new HP Photosmart Plus printer that of course CAN do borderless. When I saw Quicken WillMaker 2013 I didn't know everything that was involved with estate planning. That's where the plus comes in. With WillMaker I was able to create many documents that will help before I move on from this life. These include my living will, heath-care directive, and limited power of attorney.

I have to admit that it took a while for me to get around to creating a will and doing estate planning. I guess it just made that reality of life a little too real to me. When I did WillMaker plus made the process easier than I expected. It was effectively painless.

I didn't use the support - but other reviews provide glowing reviews which I suspect are founded based on the well thought-out software.

This is a good DIY tool for straightforward estate planning: probably 90+ percent of estates. It probably gets a good start on much more complicated planning that will requires a visit to legal office. The head start that WillMaker Plus could provide in paperwork and organization may save hundreds or thousands in legal fees compared to going in with nothing.

This product appears to have real value in it. The parts of the software that I can get to work have the potential to be great tools for improving your singing. Unfortunately, the meat of the product, the singing lessons, will not run on my computer and I have been unsuccessful at getting technical support for the product. Over the past week, I have sent emails and called durring business hours. No one was present to answer my calls and never returned the emails of voice messsages I left. At this point I intend to return the software.
Easy to use with no formal training needed. Even CPA approves of it! I would highly recommend this product for any small business starting out.

Works great....as long as you have some degree of technical know how.The 'average joe' may have trouble.
I have used McAfee Total Protection for the last 7 years. No problems. Great product.
This was an excellent price for an outstanding product. It was easy to install and easy to use. What more can I ask for.

Here's the thing, the Quick Books program is great. It makes paying bills, printing invoices, creating estimates and many more things, super easy! The QB software works until you choose to update to a newer version. So, if you'd like to run QB 2010 for 2 years or 5 years, you can. Here's the catch, the Payroll that you buy in the package is only good for 1 year. Yes, 1 year only! Every year after that you either have to buy the payroll software again (and pay more for it than you'd pay to get a whole new complete edition of QB) or just bite the bullet and pay for the new edition of QB+Payroll. Ridiculous? Yes. Worth it? Debatable.

I have been using TurboTax for many years. I see the changes that TerboTax, using suggestions from Beta Testing team members, have put into place. I have tried Sonic, Nero and Roxio products in the past with limited success since I need closed captioning to work (hard of hearing/deaf). I use a set-top DVD recorder with DVD-RAM and edit on my PC. Every program before has deleted the closed captioning and usually won't work with DVD-RAM so I had to first convert the DVD-RAM using Panasonic software.

Videostudio not only imports the DVD-RAM file directly, it also keeps the captioning intact. I find it very intuitive to use but I am more \\"computer literate\\" than average. I didn't need the manual at all.

Nero might be quicker to burn copies but it was miserable to create the DVD compared to this. Sonic MyDVD worked directly with the Panasonic software but if I edited the file at all it took forever and often failed. Videostudio seems to work as one package so I don't need MyDVD and Panasonic software anymore. It's a good thing because Panasonic doesn't support Vista and I just upgraded so I NEED something that works. This does.

Device haphazardly detects HDMI input, sometimes not recognizing a signal at all until the unit is powered on/off several times.

Software randomly locks up even when not capturing.

Will display HDCP content but won't let you record it? Bizzare.

The fact that it respects HDCP is commendable if you're a fan of DRM, but ultimately useless for the average consumer since it prevents you from copying a rather large portion of media that you legitimately own the right to enjoy. The offered alternative being to \\"just record in low def\\" isn't acceptable.

New versions of this device also seem to block using other capture software (ie: VirtualDub) which is frustrating considering the provided software is so unreliable.

I can't rate the software because I had to return it (I was buying for my son, but it turns he gets this product for free from college). But it arrived very quickly, and I had no problem whatsoever with the return. And the price was great.

Received the Trubo Tax Deluxe on the date promised. Product easily installed and is being used right now.

I liked this software a lot better than LR 3, but then upgraded my computer so I can now use LR 5 and Photoshop CC. The upgrade to LR 5 is worth it, if your computer can handle it. If not, this is a really great value also. It just doesn't have some of the conveniences of LR 5.

ACD Systems FotoSlate 4 has the potential to be a really great piece of software. Unfortunately it falls short for my use. Perhaps if you want a single document with different layouts for each page and are going to do a lot of adjustments by hand then this will be just the thing for you. What I was hoping for was the ability to take a large number of images and put them on multiple pages, either 6 or 12 per page, with the images scaled and rotated properly and with the file name as the caption. It looks like the software is supposed to do that but it doesn't. There is an option to \\"auto-rotate images\\" but it either rotates all images (even those that didn't need to be rotated) or it doesn't rotate any. So, all images are printed in either vertical or horizontal orientation, rather than the appropriate orientation for the individual images. It is possible to manually rotate those images that are wrong but it's impossible to select multiple images so you have to do it one image at a time. That's quite time consuming when you have hundreds or thousands of images to rotate. Although the ACD Systems web site has user forums and there is a link to submit technical questions, they seem to be either broken or simply abandoned and not actually in use. There are recent posts in the forums for other products but not for Fotoslate. Once registered you'd think I could post to the forum but that feature seems to be broken. It's too bad, really. I wanted to like this package and it is quite close to being just what I need. But for me, it's mostly useless.
Everything as advertised, but major problems in updating to the current release. If you are willing to go through the hassle of the update, you will find that all works well after that.
excellent is onlything i have to sayit is far better than the windows 8.1 i have on my other computer which i will be removing and replacing with nwindows xp prowith service pack xp3
I am going to purchase this program as I am unhappy with microsoft's licensing program. Hopefully, StarOffice will out perform MSOffice 2000.

My son volunteered to overhaul my laptop, which I had purchased early in 2007 so that it would have the \\"new and great\\" Vista operating system on it. Well, as probably everyone knows by now, Vista was a colossal joke of an operating system. After enduring several years of slow boot-ups, computer freeze-ups and countless other problems, I followed my son's recommendation to wipe my hard drive clean and install Windows 7 Professional. He handled the work for me and my laptop's operation is so much improved that it's hard to imagine it's the same machine. In short, I'm very happy with the Windows 7 Professional product from Amazon. But has anyone thought of filing a class-action lawsuit against Microsoft for putting out a product as flawed as Vista? Windows 7 Professional is so much better that it makes me wonder why Microsoft ever put its name on something as bad as Vista.

I use (TurboTax, Mint) or have used (QuickBooks Pro) other Intuit products successfully, but Quicken Deluxe 2014 is awful! I'm going to try to return it to amazon. It will not download my retirement account data. I've even tried uninstalling the program and reinstalling it. Nothing helps. It downloaded my bank checking and savings accounts just fine, but for my retirement accounts at one brokerage firm, it downloads the account numbers but shows a zero balance in each of them. At another brokerage firm, it downloaded one of my three accounts (and that one incorrectly--it showed the balance in securities and also in cash, showing double the correct balance), but won't download anything, even the account #'s, of the other two accounts at this firm. It's like those two don't exist. When I log into both these brokerage houses outside of Quicken, my info shows correctly for all six accounts. I've tried to download these into Quicken multiple times, trying \\"brokerage\\", \\"IRA\\", \\"advanced\\", etc. These are major brokerage firms, and I'm using Windows 7. I am ready to throw Quicken out the window!

In fairness, it did download one mutual fund account correctly, but one out of seven isn't good enough.

I have used Mint, and it downloads all of these accounts correctly, with no problem. It updated their balances today, correctly, and shows their transactions. I'm puzzled as to why Intuit's free program can do this, but their paid Deluxe program cannot.

I am also disappointed and surprised to learn that it will not transfer my Mint data into Quicken. I had planned to delete my Mint account and start using Quicken, but Quicken just doesn't work for my retirement accounts. My reason for wanting to change is that I'm just not comfortable having all my log-in information stored on Mint's servers.

Edit: I've just printed the return label. I'm pleased that amazon allows returns of software.

This game unfortunatly might be unstable for some windows XP. I bought this game years ago for my first child when we had windows 95 and it was wonderful!! She loved it and it was a great teaching tool. But when we upgrated to XP, everytime when I tryed to play it, it would just shut my computer down. I was excited when I ordered this one because I thought that it had been updated for XP but apparently it was not because when I recieved it, it does the same thing. It might work on some XP's, I'm not sure but I know it does not work on mine. I hate it, because I so wanted to use it for my other daughter who is 3 years old.

I do love my games. This one is a good one and would recommend for your pesonal use or as gift.
It keeps me thinking.

I stepped over GoLive a few years back, don't remember which version, but didn't get into it then.
I decided to get into it now during version 5 however, with the free upgrade to version 6, since I couldn't be bothered waiting for it to reach the market!
However the user-friendlyness has been improved a lot with GL6 and it is now not only a lot stronger and yes, slower, but also a bit easier to get around.

Oh, dear I forgot to mention the diagrams when I submitted this review the first time!! They have appered to me as the best thing yet with GL - just because I find them very useful. When you first start a site up (you can do it later too of course), you have the ability to create a site diagram, OK that might not be that revolutionary.. What is so great about them is that you can create them with different symbols from the objects palette; database, PDF, page etc and once you've set them up GL actually creates a site with all the pages you've specified in the diagram. Further more you can show the diagram as a PDF or SVG file to your client online! Of course you can use the diagram as a reference throughout the design process.
I was recommended GL years ago by fellow webdesigners in London who told me that it would be good for me since I don't know html and that way I would learn it. My London co-workers couldn't have been more right - I have learnt a lot since I've gotten GL and I am still learning. Now with version 6 I also find that I am learning ASP, JSP etc as well and I mean I learn it practically, there is only so much you can read yourself to!!
Web Workgroup Server 1.0 that comes with this version is also something that I've started to enjoy, especially with consideration to that it now makes it a whole lot easier for me and my collegues worldwide to check pages etc in and out of a website, without me having to do, way too much supervising either - it saves time for me and that is valuable!!
It's got a weblog with it, but I stillhaven't been able to figure out whether or not that shows who has been trying to log into the server and who had problems, or who got in straight away.
The other bad thing is that I was reading the instructions for how to set it up and while I was doing that, I missed the few seconds I had to change the \\"system\\" and \\"password\\" -> I found myself locked out of the server and the only way I saw, was that I had to re-install the whole thing and fill in the password before time-out. That was annoying, but of course it is very likely that I missed something, since I had to do that, considering the server is a whole new program and part of GL..
After I got in, it was however fairly straight forward to configure the website, publishing server and users.
I find that Adobe is best for me since there are so many resources over at Adobe Studio for one, you can find free actions and new templates and just get so many great ideas from other users on how to do things quickly. It's great because there is so many ppl around who you can ask for help if you need it.

Like the other reviewer from DeSoto, Texas said below, I too am experiencing crashes on a very robust installation of Windows XP. I am a hardware/software technician with over 10 years of field experience and I have a degree in Recording Engineering, yet, I cannot get this product to run on my system. I also have their DM2 mixer and used previous versions of their software on Win98 with no problems. I am hesitant to try their newer StudioXPro product fearing that it too will crash upon launch.
They really do have extremely poor support. They did NOT respond to any of my SEVEN e-mails regarding this problem. The only way to contact them is via e-mail. I even considered knocking on their doors when I last visited San Francisco, but their website only shows a PO BOX!
Until they get their act together, avoid MixMan. It's too bad too because they have a promising product line. They just don't know how to run a software company.

I have Mac OSX Lion and have used Toast for years with my macs. I talked myself into buying the Toast 11 Pro (I had Toast 10) because I really needed to convert my old family Super 8's that I had transferred years ago into my external drive digitally.
I had several (5) DVD-R's that would only convert 1/2 of the DVD-R digitally to ANY file format. I tried several times with several conversion formats with the same result: 1/2 of the DVD-R. The pre-process conversion would read that the entire DVD-R would transfer; but only 1/2 would actually convert. Iy did not matter if the DVD=R was 2 hours long or 45 minutes...only 1/2 was converted.

I finally had some DVD-Rs from the late 1990's of family that had audio as well as video as they were recorded originally on Hi -8 and put onto DVD-R.
These converted video OK to .mov files, but there were 2 second audio sync problems on the finished conversions. I tried several times with different formats--SAME PROBLEM. Unacceptable!
I purchased another program and I have had no problems with all of the situations listed above.

As far as CD audio burning...the Toast 11 program is great...but any older Toast can do that! No need to upgrade.

If you are going to burn CD's and/or Data files to CD or DVD/Bluray--I am sure that Toast 11 Pro will work fine for you. For Conversions: Toast 11 falls flat and short of expectations. School Grade: D+ and a lot of extra \\"Re-do\\" work for me.

I am pleased in all respects with this program. I have a Pentium 4,windows XP computer and only had very minor problems with installation. I took my time studying what each function did and compared it PC Tools Registry Mechanic which is basically the same thing and activated only those utilities which matched it and the little meter quickly went all the way to the right. So far I have not experienced any of the problems listed by other users in terms of loss of passwords or loss of anything period! Clearly when one buys new software,it behooves the person to study it closely to see if it is really going to fit the bill for your computer maintenance needs and so I give this program kudo's for doing exactly what it indicates!

Greetings all.

I purchased 'Fate: Jewel Case edition' believing I was purchasing Fate, Fate 2 (Undiscovered Reality) and Fate 3 (The Traitor Soul). It arrived on time and in good condition.

I'm running the game on Windows 7. When I attempted to load and install the game my computer had a difficult time reading the disk. I eventually needed to resort to opening the game manually through Windows Explorer. Although the load was very slow, the game loaded successfully.

At first look after installation it appeared I only had access to Fate 3 (The Traitor Soul). I became a touch irritated. Through the search process of looking for the first two Fate games I loaded a game storage site called \\"Wild Tangent,\\" a site where an individual can pay and play older games. Fate was there as was Fate 2 (Undiscovered Reality) however, there was a charge to play either of the games, which between the two would have cost more than double what I paid for the Jewel Case edition of Fate. Now I am more than irritated. I figure its time to send a very nasty note to the folks I purchased the game from and I headed back to Amazon to let them know my feelings in very clear and concise words. Luckily for me, I didn't get that far.

I choose to read through the reviews before giving in to my injured sense of fairness in the market place. First I read all the reviews of those who rated the game a 1. With a couple of exceptions in which the reviewer just wanted to hear him/herself rant, the reviewers experienced the same issue I did. I was feeling proud of myself now knowing I wasn't alone. However, there was a slight dent in my personal feelings of belonging to a disgruntled crowd. . . There were a whole lot more folks who rated the game 5 stars. Why that was, I decided I needed to find out.

The first Five Star rating I read was written by Oddlydrawn. He explained how Fate 3 (The Traitor Soul) contains within itself the other two games, as Fate 2 and 3 were expansions to the original Fate.

So good reader--if you have not read Oddlydrawn's review I believe you will find it very helpful and then, perhaps, like me, you will begin to feel the world isn't as bad as it was half an hour ago. :-)

~Somewhere in the process of getting older, I forgot to grow up.~o games, as Fate 2 and 3 were expansions to the original Fate.

So good reader--if you have not read Oddlydrawn's review I believe you will find it very helpful and then, perhaps, like me, you will begin to feel the world isn't as bad as it was half an hour ago. :-)

~Somewhere in the process of getting older, I forgot to grow up.~

I beta tested Vista from early on and have run the complete version for about 2 months now via TechNet and Microsoft Connect. I love how it works and runs. Only real argument I have is that I run it 64 bit with a dual core and some programs are not compatable (not Microsoft's fault.) They need to catch up! On another note, Microsoft released details of this OS a long time ago, yet kept dropping features (new file system...) to get to an earlier release date. Again, I love it, but after 5 years of the \\"best\\" programers, I expected more.

I've used this program (mainly for short story writing) for years. I love the latest version (4), particularly the storyboard feature, which makes it easy to visualize and reorganize scenes and chapters. The writing targets feature is great for keeping you motivated, and I also use the name generator a lot, to come up with authentic-sounding characters. These are just three of the many tools in WriteItNow, but it is the flexibility of the software that makes it a winner for me.

Before you buy this software read all of Amazon's reviews, and the user forums @ Roxio. This software is riddled with bugs, causes serious system crashes, and incredible frustration. Read Roxio's workaround for the problems before you install this, because if it crashes your computer, you're going to be spending a day or two manually cleaning your registry.

The problems mostly seem to happen when upgrading from previous versions. I have used, and loved, Roxio since version 5, and have upgraded to every version since then with little or no difficulty. But when I upgraded from 8 to 9 all hell broke loose. Major crashes, not just of the OS, but other software. Incredibly hard time uninstalling Roxio 9. Thought I would have to do a clean install of Windows to get my system back, but after several attempts at deleting all Roxio references in the registry, and then doing a \\"system restore,\\" I got the OS stabile again. But this took about twelve hours to accomplish, and because of the system restore rollback, I had to redo a lot of work.

Save yourself some some aggrevation: READ BEFOR YOU BUY! If one or two Amazon reviews were negative you could chalk it up to \\"user error.\\" But there is a pattern of serious crashes with this software. You have been warned!

Having purchased Vista, but wishing to keep Windows XP MCE, I purchased Acronis Disk Director Suite 10 in order to set up a dual boot system that would accommodate both operating systems. In addition to the Acronis product I also had a copy of Norton Partition Magic, and since I had two identical desktop PCs to configure in a dual-boot mode I intended to use Acronis on one and Norton on the other. After a few hours of Symantec software torture I abandoned the Norton product, and easily configured both PCs using the Acronis Disk Director. I have yet to figure out why Norton Partition Magic would not step through the dual boot configuration process, but Acronis Disk Director 10 sailed right through without a hitch. I have been using Norton products for years, and while Symantec makes quality software they also engineer their product line with a sufficient number of traps to drive even the most patient geek certifiably mad. You may ask why Disk Director did not get the 5-star rating; the answer is that Acronis has a few unnecessary traps of its own (but not quite enough to coax you into using the software as a frisbee) So, if I ever have the occasion to again set up a PC to accommodate two operating systems (dual-boot), and the software choices are between Acronis and Norton, I will not hesitate to purchase Disk Director; I highly recommend this software.

I was extremely pleased with this training video. The video player was very full featured; far better than any I have used in other video training I have used. Look over intro page ix of the accompanying book to get an over view if it's capabilities. Although it launches full screen, it can be reduced in size like any other on-screen window. Find the small handle at the lower right. You could of course shrink it down to the task bar, but it runs and looks great at both small and large sizes. What's more, you can pause the video at anytime, run you own copy of Lightroom and actually work through the same steps you are learning about. In fact, the image used on the DVD are also included on the DVD, so you could repeat the lessons with the identical images. (The video lessons are also on the DVD in .mp4 and .3gp format, so you may be able to work through some lessons on your iPhone/iPad or 3G cell phone while commuting.) It will pay to pause the first lesson and explore the user interface of the DVD playback software. It's not as complicated as LR itself, but quirky enough to make starting off somewhat confusing. You'll want to explore the LR interface at some point too. The Lightroom (LR) interface is designed around a good, flexible work flow, and the lessons generally follow that workflow. Of course, in actual use you can easily jump around the interface as you want, but seeing the software in an actual work flow is terrific. LR, like Photoshop, is a deep product, and watching it being used is actually far easier to do than trying to follow step-by-step instructions from a book. The DVD comes with a small book which you can remove from the packaging; it's got those small sticky pads holding the back of the book to the box. Just lift off carefully. The first half of the book is entitled \\"The Photograper's Eye\\" by Michael Jordan (but not that Michael Jordan.) This seems like basic filler, and is not related to Lightroom at all. The last half is pretty good,although a lot of those ridiculously small screen shots are included. The material covered is duplicated in Lesson 1.4 to 1.4.9 so you can at least see a much bigger image. There is also a handy keyboard shortcuts list. The book is also handy in case you want to change some of the settings without reloading the DVD. I have a few quibbles. In general, this DVD is aimed at Lightroom beginners. But much of Lesson 1 (1.1 to 1.3.7) deals with \\"What's New in LR3\\" which is almost useless, and frankly confusing, for someone using LR3 the first time. (If you just upgraded from an earlier version, this might be more interesting.) Start up your own LR and jump to 1.4 to begin the process of customizing your setup. At 1.4 you get a really useful, well explained review of the many LR settings. If you start with the 'Play All' option, as recommended, the interface takes you automatically from lesson to lesson, although there is no visual indication of which lesson and chapter number you are actually on. The titles are shown on the right hand sidebar (Chapter Videos) if you open it, but not the lesson numbers. You can use the dropdown at the top of the main dialog to see this, however. You can choose specific lessons from the opening main screen if desired. As you go, you can set bookmarks for sections you might like to revisit. All you bookmarks are available from one of the tabs at the top... a really nice feature! If you truly are a Lightroom beginner, this DVD will get you up-and-running quickly. If you have used Photoshop, and Camera Raw (CR) in particular, you will quickly see how adjustments in LR are so similar to CR, with LR adding so much more in terms of automation, asset management etc. Quirky start-up aside, this is an easy 5 star rating!

This library is a Vocaloid 2 collection of the Luka Megurine voice bank. It is packaged together with the Vocaloid 2 Editor and if that is OK then there is no need to buy the Vocaloid 3 Editor (you can make the editor use English text by installing it, find the file "VOCALOID2_Japanese.dll" and remove it or change it to another name).

Luka is able to sing in Japanese and in English, with a nice soft voice and a good note-span. She can be easily imported to the Vocaloid 3 Editor (provided that you activate the voice bank first). There is a comprehensive manual included with the library - but unfortunately it is only in Japanese. Installation is straightforward, but is is in Japanese so it is a good idea to find some instructive youtube-videos to guide you. Also remember that the voice-bank must be activated and de-activated if it has to be move to another computer.
