First of all, it is a tall flush valve: the overflow tube adjusts from 8.5\\" to 13\\" and is by .5 \\" taller than the OEM. I thought my Eljer Emblem toilet was standard height (it is 9.25\\" tall to the front rim or the flush lever hole), but the valve barely fit, given that the fill valve's critical level should be higher by 1 inch than the top edge of the overflow tube. All the parts seem larger now a days, which does not mean better. A Plumb Craft fill valve I got adjusts from 9\\" to 14\\" but even when critical level line is just 1/4\\" above the flush valve, the total height makes the lid not to fit. You may want to consider getting a pressure actuated fill valve (no float no rod) or measure your toilet carefully.

The main idea behind this patented performance enhancing valve is the funneling effect created by a wider mouth, where the flapper sits and a narrower opening at the bottom of the valve. The flapper is really wide, so make sure you insert the bolts prior to attaching the flush valve or you may have problems with getting them through the holes.

I could not position the flush valve perpendicularly to the tank walls, I rotated it a bit counterclockwise, because the flapper was brushing against the front wall. This would be OK, if it worked smoothly afterwards, but then the chain was catching the flapper, by hanging behind it and holding it up vertically in the air with water running forever, unless I wait and release the flush lever again. If I wanted to rotate the valve the other way, I'd have to disassemble everything and start over. So, I replaced the chain first, since it was really poor quality. This did not help, the smaller gauge chain still held the flapper up until I lowered the water fill level. If this water level proves sufficient, it will save us even more water, though the water saving claims are suspicious even after realizing that the valve leaves 1 inch of water at the bottom of the tank when drained (the seat disc is positioned higher than in the previous valve). So make sure to rotate the flapper clockwise towards the fill valve, not away from it. In my opinion instructions should include this advice.

The tank to bowl gasket is very thick and it did not work for my Eljer (I was warned about it) - the tank wiggled so much with the bolts fully tightened, I had to get a more stable one (designed specifically for Eljer toilets, with bolts' gaskets and 4 tank rubber \\"feet\\" incorporated), which included its own bolts. Also, there are just two tank to bowl bolts included even though the pictures on the package shows three. Not that I need them, but it is false advertizing. However, I liked the bolts from this kit better because they have larger heads and wing nuts rather than standard hexagonal nuts. Extra rubber washers proved helpful, too (why would I ever put metal washers or nuts directly against ceramics?).

It flushes just fine now, we will see how it holds up in time. I did not buy it for performance improvement - my tank leaked at a tank to bowl bolt.

The manufacturer's web site claims that this valve can improve performance OR reduce water usage. The flapper's cone has an internal rotating slot, which will reduce water usage the most when positioned in front and improve performance the most when turned all the way back.

By the way, it took me a while to learn that a standard 2 inch flush valve's diameter is not an exact measurement and may actually be as large as 2 1/4 inch (the gasket fills in the space) and all the toilets built prior to 1994 complied with this standard.ed higher than in the previous valve). So make sure to rotate the flapper clockwise towards the fill valve, not away from it. In my opinion instructions should include this advice.

There seems to be much confusion as to what this product is supposed to do. So I will start with what the manufacturer says it will not do and I did not expect it to.... It does not remove anything from your water. If you will have your water tested for hardness before and after, if there is any difference, it is not because of the Eddy Electronic Water Descaler. This product does not make your water feel any different or soap lather better.

What it does do is prevent the minerals in your water from adhering to the inside of your plumbing, things like shower heads, faucet aerators, clothes washer, dishwasher, inside of your water heater, etc. The minerals are supposed to simply pass through the system and down the drain.

SIX WEEKS ago I installed a new water heater to service my 5 bedroom, 2 1/2 bath home. At that time I also disassembled and cleaned the mineral crust from every shower head, faucet aerator, kitchen sink sprayer, etc. I installed the Eddy Electronic Water Descaler the same day the new water heater went in. The Eddy was installed in a location that protects everything in the house, hot and cold side. In the past, when I descaled all that I described above, within 4 weeks I was seeing evidence of scale build up again. (Note: I have city water that is reasonably good quality, but still some mineral content) After six weeks with the Eddy, I see nothing yet. I won't call this a definitive test until I get to 5 or 6 months out with the same result.... but so far so good. I'll update this review at six months.

SIX MONTHS out now... I am starting to see a need to clean shower heads and the kitchen sink sprayer. So, I have come to the conclusion that under my conditions of city water, with light mineralization, two people using water here, the Eddy reduces the need to clean scale from faucets and sprayers from every 30 days to about 6 months. An additional benefit is that cleaning is easier than it was before... the scale that is there now is not as firmly attached.

This is my last update on this product.is there now is not as firmly attached.

This is my last update on this product.

This is a unique product in the US market, but it has a fatal flaw in the many geographic locations where tap water is soft: the carbonation level is much lower than in bottled seltzer. That means, for example, the water out of this system is pretty flat in most of New England and in NYC due to the low carbonate hardness in public water supplies. Otherwise a very trick system and probably great where carbonate hardness levels are high. Contact your local water authority before ordering to obtain carbonate hardness levels. Also might not be a bad idea to discuss with Grohe tech support before ordering, they are very helpful.

I put three of these locks in thirty years ago and never had one problem, and they got used a great deal. I recently changed three entry doors and tried Schlage residential secure key and regular lever locks. I did not know this lock I installed 30 years ago was a light commercial lock, but I can sure tell now. These new Schlage lever locks are junk compared to my old A53PD TUL. The new lock when you open it with the key outside has to be relocked when you come in or with the key. The original lock had a button on the inside that stayed in even if you unlocked it on the outside, so you didn't have to lock it every time you came in. If you manually turned the button on the inside and let it pop out, then it would stay open one both sides but once you push it back, it stayed open on the inside but always locked on the outside. You can also tell the quality of both locks, and the residential feels like it could be ripped off with your hand but not the old lock.

Installation was easy and I tested that it works properly. The lock is on the cheap side. One tip: make absolutely certain that you install it such that the teeth of the keys face up when you insert the key into the lock. Otherwise, the key may not be able to turn in the lock because gravity is going against the springs inside. At least, that was my experience. Once I installed it with the correct side up, I tested it to work a bunch of times with no problems.

Edit: okay, now I realize the actual problem with the lock not turning. The instructions tell you to cut down the bolts that attach the lock to the door, but they don't tell you why. The reason is that when the cylinder on the lock turns, it also causes the steel cable to rotate. If the bolts are long enough, they block the cable from rotating, which blocks the cylinder from rotating. So it is important to cut them short or rig up some other solution to that problem. I used a Dremel cut off wheel.

Solidly built, heavy, and weather-resistant are apt descriptors for this Stanley padlock. It certainly gives the impression of being well-constructed and strong. I bought it for an outdoor hasp.

By the way, it's important to be sure the hasp is as strong as the lock. This should be pretty obvious, but I learned the lesson the hard way. I lost two inadequate hasps that a thief cut off around the lock shackles, thus defeating the locks without even touching them. The locks themselves were left on the ground undamaged.

A well built gadget ladder that works in a variety of situations like unlevel surfaces or stairwells. It is the best ladder I've ever owned. Here's a couple of bits of information that might be helpful: 1. When fully extended, the highest rung/step rated safe to stand on is 69 inches above the level ground surface. It is the second rung from the top. So, this 8-foot ladder offers a maximum safe standing height of 5 feet 9 inches. 2. The next step up - or the first rung from the top - is labled with \\"Danger\\" and \\"Warning\\" stickers. \\"This is not a step.\\" Well, it is built just like the other rungs and is solid. Therefore, it is a step, if you have uncanny balance and want it to be a step. It is 80 inches above level surface, but I wouldn't want to stand on it without something sturdy to hold on to. Another thing that makes life easier with this ladder is a good quality silicone spray like CRC Heavy Duty or NAPA. Don't use the foaming junk! Silicone does not collect dirt and dust like WD40. It is a clean lubricant. Spray the sliding boom, latches and hooks as well as the slide locks on top. After playing with the ladder right out of the box for a few minutes, I sprayed it with silicone. What a difference. It adjusts and glides into position smoothly. 34 pounds is not an issue. Move on up to the next level, which, for a change, is one you can actually see and touch.

After spending an inordinate amount of time howling at the moon, my wolfen brothers and I ran through the arctic forests of Johanngeorgenstadt, Germany hot on the trail of the No-armed man. I could still hear that tragic, heart-wrenching melody of Do The Limbo Dance from the [[ASIN:B0000070S1 Looking For-Best of David Hasselhoff]] concert where I had tracked the No-armed man and been ambushed by a lead pipe to the back of the head. Only now the shoe was on the other foot, and the three wolves and I chased after the No-armed man with the help of their keen sense of smell and the radioactive tin of [[ASIN:B000796XXM Uranium Ore]] I had been mashing against the side of my head for warmth.

Finally, after thirty years, I saw the image I had burned into my retinas, the No-armed man running ahead of me, almost within my grasp. My wolfen brothers stopped me, knowing I would catch the No-armed man now, and said their farewells. This was not their war, as much as they may have wanted it to be, and knew that I must go on alone now. We laughed, we cried, we remembered many stories that we had shared, and then we parted ways.

I ran after the No-armed man and quickly caught up to him at the edge of an enormous cliff. To one side of him flowed a massive river that dwarfed the Amazon, to the other side of him rose a sheer cliff, and behind him, a drop of nearly one mile to the placid surface of the lake below. And yet his deadliest choice was infront of him, me. It was then that I heard his voice for the first time and his words shocked me to my core.

\\"I didn't murder, John W. Trimmer, the author of [[ASIN:0870334336 How to Avoid Huge Ships]],\\" he said. \\"And he's alive with your ex-wife.\\"

Construction:
1. The fan shroud is flat with only one formed rib. This allows the shroud to contort once mounted causing the fan to hit the HEX head (should have been round-head) mounting bolts. Additionally, it is designed to be put into a PRE-CUT CIRCULAR HOLE of the exact size to give the shroud needed stability and prevent distortion to the shroud. *Plywood NOT INCLUDED.

2. The available mounting slots in the shroud are limited to two choices which, AGAIN, limit you to a PRE-CUT CIRCULAR HOLE in a sheet of plywood for mounting.

3. The electrical box is slightly undersized with no shielding for the 'hot' terminals going into the thermostat. An unshielded standard Romex ground can easily come into contact with either of the hot terminals if you're not EXTREMELY careful when putting the cover back on.

4. There is no vibration padding/dampening anywhere at any of the mechanical connections.

5. NOT BALANCED!!! The fan blade unit was either not balanced or the hub was not perfectly centered. It is vibrating and loud in the house.

Conclusion:

I WOULD NOT recommend this fan.

This was a replacement fan for me. Because it was so flimsy and would not fit a straight top and bottom frame support, I disassembled it from its shroud housing and put it into my old shroud. Once in the sturdy shroud from my old unit, the fan had the balance issues; balance has to do with blades and would not change in a different shroud. We'll see how long it lasts.

I had this model Rinnai installed in February 2013, so I've been using it for 5 months now.

Usage:
Usage is *almost* like when I had a tank water heater. There have been some minor annoyances. The biggest annoyance, and most reproducible, is when I shave. When I shave, I turn the hot water on, run the razor underneath, and turn it off again. Shave a section, water on, rinse razor, water off. Repeat. Eventually, the Rinnai decides that I'm not using any hot water and does not heat the water. Every single time I shave, I have to deal with eventually getting cold water from the tap when I ask for hot. I have called Rinnai tech support and they were unable to help with the issue. If not for this issue, I would give this model 5 stars.

I think the culprit is a problem with their flow rate algorithm - I am actually using enough gpm (gallons/minute) to keep the heater on, if you average out my usage while shaving over a whole minute. However, during smaller windows of that minute I use 0 gpm and so the Rinnai's computer shuts off the heater. Rinnai, please fix this and you'll be rockstars.

There is a smidgen of longer latency when you turn on the hot tap until when you get hot water, but it's hardly noticeable.

Energy Usage:
During these periods I lived in a 2 person household with 4 bedrooms, and I switched from a large tank heater to a large tankless heater (this one). My natural gas usage during spring and summer months (not using the air heater) has dropped, on average, in half - from 12 therms/mo to 6 therms/mo. This only saves me about $6/mo, but I'm happy to reduce my environmental impact. I also have a gas stovetop and dryer, so my gas usage isn't all for hot water.

I also measured the electricity used by this Rinnai - it uses about 0 watts when idle (as it should) and 30 watts when running. 30 watts is slightly more than I expected, but it at least does not run very often.

Installation:
You should know that this is not going to be a simple job to replace a traditional tank water heater due to these complications:

* The RU98IN uses a dual venting system which combines intake and outtake in a special pipe. IIRC, the exhaust pipe is inside of the intake pipe in concentric circles. It may be a pain or impossible to run an additional vent, e.g. to the roof. In my case, it is mounted on the external wall so it vents through the wall outside.

* The RU98 requires a 3/4\\" gas line, and your tank water heater may have used a smaller line.

* This RU98IN also has a condensate drain, and so you must locate the water heater near a drain. Warning: the condensate is somewhat acidic so if you have older iron drainpipes you may want to not install this system. On the plus side to the condensate drain, the condensate itself is a by-product of this unit efficiently burning natural gas - so there is a good reason for it.

* The RU98 also requires an electrical outlet to be nearby. If you don't have one there already, you'd need one installed.

Maintenance:
About once a year you should clean and flush the system to prevent scaling (flushing might only be in hard-water environments?).

Update: I completed a maintenance cycle a year after installation. It was fairly easy and I used these Amazon products:
[[ASIN:B002NJ99PS PETRA X1109-8FF-TP Black Rubber Washing Machine Hose, 8 Foot]]
[[ASIN:B000X05G1A Superior Pump 91250 1/4 HP Thermoplastic Submersible Utility Pump]] (The pump works great, though it is higher velocity than is required)

DO NOT BUY A BAGSTER!!!!! The product itself seems to be fine. The customer service is probably the worst that I have ever seen. The day of my bagster pickup I came home to find it sill sitting in my driveway with no note attached, no phone call, nothing. I called customer service to find out the problem, and they had no information to give me but assured me that they would call me back and get it resolved. Next day no phone call and no pickup. Called back and got yes sir we will get it rescheduled and picked up ASAP. Three days pass and no call, etc. I call them back after noticing a $50 fee on my credit card from them. After speaking to a rep I asked to be transfer to a manger but was transfer to scheduling. Finally she transfers me to a manager. Then she tells me all sorts of BS about not being able to access the bagster in my driveway (BTW - my drive is 35 feet long and 11 feet wide with plenty of space to get in and out. Then they said it was obstructed by a Ford Explorer (There was no car in my driveway at the time plus I don't own Explorer and live alone). My question was why didn't the driver a) call me b) leave a note. Of course these questions cannot be answered. After asking for a refund for my $50 I get answer that she will forward it to her Ops Manager who will then decide if I get my money back. Of course I will never see this money again.
DO YOURSELF A FAVOR - if you can, pile the debris somewhere on your property cover it with a tarp and call a LOCAL junk/debris removal company. You will save at least $70, a giant headache, and can sleep well knowing that you are supporting a local business instead wasting your money with Waste Management.

These Legend handles were a great buy! They are attractive, sturdy and inexpensive when compared to their competition from the home improvement stores. This variation is the one you would use for a door you wish to have the option to lock, like a bathroom or bedroom door. There is a turn knob on one side of the levers. Included with each box is a two sided lever, a striker and a tumbler mechanism along with the required screws. We replaced ALL (21) of the doors knobs in our house with these types, some locking, some key-locked and some standard levers; they all look, feel and operate great. Installation was simple, too. The price of these levers was about two thirds that (64% to be exact) of the home improvement store. I handled (pun intended) the brand at the home improvement store and it felt to be of similar quality to these Legend levers. Overall, these were a great buy and they add a subtle elegance to our home versus our old builder-installed brass knobs.

UPDATE 7/2017: These levers continue to look and function great! After almost three years installed, I have no real complaints. If I had to point to a few very minor nitpicks it would be that the outside levers (exposed to the elements) have had a bit of their finish wear off; I kind of give that a pass though. Also, some of the springs in the frequently used levers have weakened a bit and the lever hangs slightly below a perfect 90 degree angle...however for non OCDers that shouldn't be an issue. I still definitely recommend them.

If you are short on patience or arms, you might want to choose the paddle-blades instead of the tropical blades. It comes with both sets. The tropical blades make it difficult to wire up, because they are wide, and you have to reach around them and really extend yourself to get everything wired correctly. It can be done though - my husband ended up reaching around it with one of the blades mashed against his face to wire it. It wasn't very comfortable, but it can be done.

Installation at first went along amazingly simple, at the end of step 4 to step 5, I realized the directions in section 5 were for NO LIGHTS, and I needed lights, so make sure to pay attention there, as the book didn't seem all that clear to my husband, and he ended up having to redo the fan so we had a light.

On 6.3 in the directions, it shows 2 wires just exposed hanging, and it doesn't tell you what to do with them. We put caps on each one. It would be nice if the instructions were more clear there. In any event, that did the trick and it worked.

It came balanced and it is PERFECT. We didn't have to use a balancing kit at all. It works really well, it puts out a lot of wind - I could feel it across our kitchen/dining area, and our old fan could never be felt that far away.

The hanger bracket and the hanger ball make it really easy to put into place while you do the wiring. In the past, we had ceiling fans where it took 2 people, but with this, you put the bracket up, and set the fan in it, and it holds it fine until it is wired up. We had a bit of a business interruption, so work on the fan had to be stopped for a day, but it hung in place until the next day when we could finish it.

Don't be intimidated by the electronic receiver. My husband commented that it looked like an octopus with the wires coming out of it, but they are color coded and easy to match.

We only have 8' ceilings, so we didn't extend it down, but it's fine for clearance when mounted 'short' for us. For inside use, you don't have to stuff the wires in this little box- so there's a bit more care that needs to be taken with the wires for outdoor use.

For right now, I put it in my kitchen, and I love the color- it's a rich chestnut brown. I did have a white fan there, but the blades constantly showed any dirt, this one won't do that. Also it is a lot brighter than the one I had - the old one only had 2 lights, this one has 3. It comes with 3 compact florescent bulbs too, which was a nice bonus.

The remote works well - it runs on a 9 volt battery that is included. It comes with a holder that mounts to the wall. They included a bit of extra hardware in case anything got dropped.

It's a very solid attractive fan, and there's no wobbles at all, and it really moves the air. It's easy to see the quality of it by just looking at it. It's very well made.. The Nest Learning Thermostat is a great upgrade to a smart thermostat. The Nest was very easy to install and the included instructions were very easy to follow, making installation only about 20 minutes. I probably spent more time re-spackling and repainting the wall that our old thermostat covered after installing the Nest (The Nest has a very small profile and doesn't take up as much space on the wall as the old thermostat). Nest.com even has a video tutorial on their website to help you walkthrough the installation process if you need it. Everything you need to install the Nest is included in the box, so just use your existing wiring that came with your old thermostat.

The Nest is also simple to use and it makes saving energy fun (as well as addictive). :) We had this now for a little over a month, and we look forward to seeing how much we have saved with this neat little appliance.

The ViriBright Benchmark LED bulb is an excellent quality bulb. Matrix Lighting has done an amazing job at mimicking the color temperature of a burning tungsten filament that we are used to with traditional incandescent 60 watt bulbs.

Humans have evolved throughout the history of the world lighting their environments with fire. Campfires, candlelights, gas lantern, and incandescent bulbs. That is the core of the problem with CFL and LED bulbs to date... we want fire, we don't want the cold, pulsating, and frequency humming light generated by many of the CFL and LED bulbs sold today.

But this ViriBright bulb offers what we want. A true 2900 color correlated temperature. I've seen other bulbs claim these numbers and lower, 2700 in one case, but no LED light I've seen comes this close to looking like a incandescent.

This bulb is also running at 10 watts, which is a lot of bang for you wattage.

For reference, here's some of the bulbs I've tested and use:

[[ASIN:B00AYII2YE SWITCH - SWITCH75 - 18.5 Watt - 2700K Warm White - Clear LED Light Bulb - 1100 Lumen]] - This bulb is probably the reining all around champ. It's bright at 1100 Lumen, has a great color of 2700, solid build, and is liquid cooled so that you can put it in enclosed fixtures. But it runs at 18.5 watts and is expensive. It's also hot as hell after running for awhile. The light spreads evenly throughout the room.

[[ASIN:B006OTAE8Y Philips 418590 17-Watt A21 LED Household Light Bulb, Dimmable]] For the price, this is a great bulb. Perhaps the color looks a little too \\"orange\\" and not enough \\"fire\\". The light spreads well but is more directional than the Switch and the ViriBright. It's also bright at 1100 lumen. It runs at 17 watts. This is air-cooled, like the ViriBright, and cannot be placed in an enclosed fixture.

I've used and tested other older technologies but would not buy these new bulbs new today, so I'll leave them out for now. If I was to buy new bulbs today, the ViriBright, the Switch, and the Philips are what will be added to my cart.

An advantage of the ViriBright is that it is running at 10 watts, compared to the 18.5 and 17 in the above examples. The disadvantage is that it only outputs 800 lumens compared to the 1100 in the above examples. A disadvantage of the ViriBright and Philips bulb is that they cannot be placed in an enclosed fixture, the Switch can. The color of all three of the bulbs are good.

I'd recommend this ViriBright bulb in lamps or open-air fixture of a room where more than one will be used. I could see three of these lighting a room really well. Bravo, excellent product.e them out for now. If I was to buy new bulbs today, the ViriBright, the Switch, and the Philips are what will be added to my cart.

The disadvantage is that it only outputs 800 lumens compared to the 1100 in the above examples. I bought these to install in our bathrooms to provide a little ambient light so we wouldn't have to turn on the main lights at night. The sensor works well and the light is plenty bright (brighter than I prefer actually), but there are two things that really annoy me. First, the bracket requires that the light be installed as shown in the pictures - that is, the LED shines down. I wanted the opposite - I wanted to mount the lights near the ceiling, shining up, so that a soft reflected glow would light the room. The light is much more pleasing that way. The bracket doesn't allow this configuration (it falls off the wall if you try), so I ended up just using the double-side sticky tape to mount it the way I wanted. That's fine for now, but I worry I'm going to rip the paint off the wall when it's time to replace the batteries, not to mention the tape may not re-stick.

The second problem is the short duration of the light. It only stays on for about 30 seconds, which is not enough time for me to finish my...umm...business in the middle of the night, leaving me standing at the toilet in total darkness. It doesn't work to wave my arm to re-activate it as the sensor is not sensitive enough for that. You have to move your whole body several inches, which is not a smart thing to do when you're peeing in total darkness. Worse, it does reactivate as I walk away, unnecessarily lighting an empty room for another 30 seconds.

I don't know if another night light would have been a better choice, but knowing what I know now I wish I had done more research.

Since I am reviewing four products today I will copy and paste this review into all four for easy cross reference for anyone else who goes through what I did. All four products came from Sanford and Son? Overhead Doors and fulfilled by Amazon. All four shipped quickly and arrived very fast. The three Genie parts were the same as the originals. I was replacing the Genie 34107R.S Screw Drive Carriage which had stripped and was no longer opening the door (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000CST1L4/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_14). I believe this stripped because the Limit Switches were installed in a shabby fashion on my garage door opener, the Genie Excelerator screw drive system, and the open limit switch (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00286CVAQ/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_3 ) stopped working (both switches, for some reason, the wires were run under the switch itself and srewed onto the rail, which caused them to strip over time because the wires were not tied down properly using the clips; versus just using the clips and tying the excess wire in a loop with a twist tie at the end closest the power head assembly) . The Excelerator will shut off when enough force is exerted on the bumper mechanism, so even though the open limit switch stopped working the door would stop once it pushed hard enough against the bumper. However, this use of force to shut down the system over time wore down the screw drive carriage (took a little over a month for me). Since the close door limit switch (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00283OBXY/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_8) had also been installed improperly and also seemed like it was having problems (sometimes it seemed to work, sometimes it seemed force was taking over) I decided to replace the whole setup. So, two new limit switches, a new screw drive carriage, and a tube of the grease folks seemed to recommend over the higher priced Genie brand 3 pack (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FJ07W2/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_7) and I'm back in business. I am no expert, believe me, but the install of all three was a very easy one person job. Simply release the carriage from the Curved Door Arm, unscrew the one screw from the Head Bracket, and lift the rail high enough to slip off the old drive carriage. Have the new carriage ready to go and slip that right on. Lower the rail back on the head bracket and screw it back in place. Reconnect to the Curved Door Arm. The limit switches unscrew and screw easily back on. The wire clips just pop off very easily and are easy to reuse. The new limit switches do not come with the screws that hold them in place, so make sure to keep your existing screws because you will need to reuse them. I used the clips to hold down excess limit switch wire until I reached the Power Head Assembly, and then I just rolled up the rest of the excess, tied it up with a twist tie, and laid that on top of the Power Head Assembly. The greasing directions that Genie provides with their grease (available here from the Homedepot site ([...]) has you wipe down the rail before you put the new grease, and then wiping off excess once you grease the screw drive shaft. Not sure how necessary that is, but I did it, and then found I needed to do a few runs of grease along the rail to lube it up right. Maybe they meant wipe off mess that does not go on the drive shaft or rail...because you need the grease on those. One final note, once I reassembled eveything I realized the rail was not straight because the carriage was moving on an angle. It turns out that the Rail Strap had bent (this thing is heavy metal) presumably because of force causing the door to stop closing instead of the close limit switch. I had to go back and take that off and bend it by hand to straighten it out. Two months later and all is working...although I need to hire somebody to come out and balance my door because I realized when I took everything apart that the door came down very hard when not connected to the system and it should almost be balanced and not go down at all. Since balancing a door could be a bit dangerous I am choosing not to try that.

My home's nineteen-year-old LP Gas water heater was starting to show its age: brown rusty water, high gas bills, and a gas smell every time we went into the garage. While the old gas water heater still worked, we didnt want to wait and be stuck with no hot water and a 2 year old needing her bath time. It was time to begin looking for a new water heater.
My wife and I had noticed many commercials advertising the efficiency of instant gas water heaters. Even our gas company had a deal with financing. After asking a professional on Green Home Guide we focused our search on finding a heater that has a high Energy Factor (EF).
We researched the following water heating technologies:
1. Solar thermal: The best on energy factor however didnt meet our budget and had to be installed on the south side of our roof which was the front of the house. My wife didnt like that.
2. LP Gas tankless: The energy factor is around .94 and is consider by most to be morek water heater we currently had at .63 efficiency. Honestly this was the one we thought we would go with from the start. However, I would advise you to weigh the pros and cons before purchase. We found out we would need a water softener to prolong the heat exchanger, warranty coverage, and a larger duct vent through the roof than the one we currently had. A three to four inch duct vent is required. This added 40% to the original price quote. We also noticed a lot of false promises on true savings.
3. Electric tankless: The energy factor was comparable to the gas instant/tankless. However we needed to upgrade our electrical panel for the install because the electric instant water heater pulls more amps than the standard tank water heater. Plus they advised us a water-softener or pre-filter would be a good idea too.
4. Hybrid water heater: This product appealed to us because it was the most innovative and had the highest efficiency -- EF 2.35. Plus it was a lot cheaper than going thermal solar water heating. It also still qualified for the Energy Star tax credit, and was more efficient than gas instant or electric instant water heating.
We decided to buy the hybrid, a GeoSpring Hybrid-Electric Heat-Pump Hot Water Heater.
What ultimately made me buy a Geo Spring water heater?
There are several factors I considered.
The product and the GE website information were great.
High efficiency over conventional models without having to go thermal solar. I understand thermal solar watering heating is the best. However so is the hybrid water heater in my opinion and the return on investment is shorter.
Price was less than going thermal solar with having to install panels on my roof.
No commission to a sales person.
Warranty.
Tax write off! Use IRS tax form 5695.
Easy to install. I didnt have to install a gas tank, or cut holes in my roof to go thermal solar. I could put it in myself! This oight and other ways to learn about appliances or ways to save energy and protect the environment at the same time.
From $1,038 per year to $250.56 per year
Based on DOE test procedure, my projected energy costs for water heating with the GeoSpring will go from $1,038/year to $250.56, a reduction of 76%. That means I'll recoup a return on investment (ROI) in less than two years, not counting the $300 Energy Star tax deduction or the 27% reduction in kWh rate I'll get from my utility by moving into a lower usage tier. My cost for the GeoSpring water heater was $1,356 and I installed it myself. I estimate it would cost $300 to have a licensed plumber install it.
I should mention Im a Florida State electrical contractor, active RESNET Class 1 HERS Rater, and I installed this unit myself. However, that didnt mean I knew how to install one of these or knew all the answers on efficiency. I found several YouTube videos on how to install one of these and read the installation instructi back, picked up the material I would need to do the job and installed it without any problems. I think it took me longer to take that old LP Gas water heater out and clean and paint the area prior to installing the new heater.
I should also mention it works great. My wife is happy with plenty of hot water, no complaints, plus we have a garden Jacuzzi tub and it filled it up with plenty of hot water. I keep the setting in the eHeat (most efficient EF 2.55) mode most of the year and in the Hybrid (EF 2.35) mode in the winter months in Florida.

Your mileage may vary
Please do your own research. I live in Florida where the Geo Spring Hybrid will work great because its warm most of the year and the incoming ground water temperature is around 75 degrees.
However, if I lived in Ohio I would never install one of these because the temperature split is too high. The incoming ground water temperature there would be around 55 degrees. Most people would require LP Gas or Natural Gas fueeat more efficiently in that climate.
What should you check prior to installing a Geo-Spring water heater?
Location: The GeoSpring gives off 56-db of noise which is less than a box type fan running. If installing indoors fan noise, space required, and condensation drain will have to be considered. If installing in a closet the door will have to be vented to allow air to circulate around Heat-Pump. This unit works best with 700 cubic feet of air around unit for proper air circulation. I installed mine in the garage where its warmer and has space around it to evaporate the warm air to heat the water more efficiently.

Climate: Southern states in my opinion would be the best option on increased energy savings.

Cost: Check around, I purchased mine at Lowe's and extended the warranty up to 10 years for $80 dollars after the one year warranty runs out.

Contractor: Are they licensed? Did they pull a permit?

Needs: Do I need a 40 gallon, 50 or an 80? Geo-Sonly comes in a 50 gallon at this time. However we have a garden Jacuzzi tub and it fills it up just fine with plenty of hot water.

Full article: http://greenhomeguide.com/how-i-cut-my-energy-bill-for-water-heating-by-76

This simple little inexpensive and uncomplicated invention makes a big difference in one of those little ways that matter.

How many times and ways do we experience \\"little\\" annoyances that happen all too often. Nothing major but a source of irritation. Like, for instance, taking a nice shower after working outside getting ready to relax and chill but its always annoying hitting that little bump in the middle of the shower rod that sometimes leaves the curtain coming off one or two of the hooks which have to be put back eventually before the hooks fall off. Or the fact that it just looks messy. But mostly for me its that \\"struggle\\" every time I shower.

This hasn't revolutionized my world, I haven't experienced any huge financial changes one way or the other on account of it. It just makes my life a little smoother and that's nice.

Everytime I get out of the shower now I am reminded of what's missing, that annoying tug. And I admit I feel a little smug because I found an answer to something that's no big deal. It is, however, something I think a lot of people have just learned to live with. How can something so small be so nice and make me so glad I found, for this one \\"issue\\" in my life - an answer.

The only thing I would say as advice as to \\"how to\\" install it is that you will probably have to cut off a few inches from one end or the other. That's what I did which was no big deal. Thing is, though, there is a sticker on one end (manufacturers seem to LOVE STICKERS that you can't UN-STICK to save yourself) that is aesthetically a small blemish detracting from the \\"tidiness\\" I like. If I had noticed ahead of time there was this sticker which is about an inch and a half long that is the end I would have cut off but as luck happens so often, if there is a 50-50 chance of getting it \\"right\\" I got it wrong. So I had to try to scratch off this sticker thing which I wasn't totally successful at but \\"enough\\" to get by. It's not a huge thing but nice if you get it right and cut off the sticker end instead of the unblemished part. That's the only thing that could have made this nicer. I HATE STICKERS. What is the love affair anyway with stickers that defy removing? I don't notice it much or at all, I just know its there and it would have been better without it.

Anyway, with or without the sticker this has made my life more pleasant in one of those little simple ways that makes me a happier person. Who knew happiness comes in such small ways? A NICE, SMOOTH addition to an otherwise \\"rough\\" world - and it doesn't cost a fortune, the shipping was SUPER FAST, actually delivered by a carrier service within a couple of days which was a nice surprise too. I highly recommend it so you too, can be among the smugly self-satisfied who don't have to tug at the shower curtain AGAIN, a solution easy, fast and cheap. What could be better?

I'm glad they had an option here on Amazon to buy JUST ONE because I don't need a box of 20. The option I found for one combined with the shipping fee was still probably cheaper than if I had found one locally. This review is being written 6/9/2013 for the Zoeller 30-0181 Check Valve, 1-1/2 Inch, sold and shipped by third party vendors who advertise on the Amazon website.

The precursor to this model had a slightly different design where the valve came apart in the middle with four bolts, and the flapper was a replaceable item. This model is sealed and the flapper is not replaceable. This valve has the same rugged flapper design (reinforced with a metal disk) as the previous design. The flapper opens completely, unlike many cheaper valves, hence the \\"full-flow\\" claim. However, do note that this check valve is a 1 1/4\\" design with universal rubber couplings that connect it to either 1 1/4\\" or 1 1/2\\" PVC pipe. Therefore, if you use 1 1/2\\" PVC piping, you will not get the same amount of flow through this valve as you would with a model that has a 1 1/2\\" minimum diameter. This design allows Zoeller to sell one product with a single set of rubber couplers for both applications. Turn the rubber couplings one way or the other to accommodate the correct PVC pipe diameter for your application. Also note that this check valve does \\"klunk\\" with a loud snap. If you are concerned about the noise, you may want to consider another model with a different design. Otherwise, if you want a reliable, high quality check valve, this is a good choice.

I've uploaded some pictures to show the full flow design and the orientation of the rubber couplers.

I attached it to a Craftmade Model P152 fan. It fit perfectly. Should work on any fan that accommodates a universal light fixture with threaded nipple. The picture does not show it, but there is a threaded nipple protruding from the top of the fixture for installation to the fan. For the Craftmade, I had to remove the plastic button in the bottom center of the fan control housing (where the fan switches are). This light fixture then threads right in. My fan already had wires in the housing for a light fixture, so I just had to attach the two wires from this fixture to those wires. The brass on the fixture is bright brass, but it does have a more buffed look than the mirror-like finish of the fan I attached it to. I can't imagine anyone noticing the difference unless it is pointed out to them. Note that this fixture does not come with shades for the light bulbs. This is a review of my experience in using Restore. I am still in the process of finishing the deck so obviously I do not have any long term results. What I can offer is how easy/difficult it was to apply, texture, coverage, too hot? etc.

Coverage: Their website states that 1-4 gallon container will cover a 100 sq-ft area with 2 coats. I used just over 2-4 gallon containers to cover a 14x15 area (or 210 sq-ft) with 2 coats. I also did all the top rails and a few stairs with 2 coats. So, the coverage was spot on (if not better). Why was it spot on for me but poor for others? One possible explanation is that the weather has been relatively cool for this time of the year.

Texture: I am specifically looking for the textured feel as we have kids and have friends and family over often for the pool. The texture turned out exactly how I was hoping and am extremely happy. We are not having any issues with it being way too rough to walk on or as others have described, \\"like walking on rocks\\". Why did the texture turn out ok for us? Possible explanations can be read below...

How easy/difficult to apply (and prep): Use their rollers. Do all the necessary prep work - power wash (sand if necessary), mask off any areas (like you house). Their website talks about applying extra material to nail holes and larger cracks before you do the 2nd coat. I took the extra step to fill in any larger cracks and deep nail holes with caulk before I did the first coat (their website also talks about using caulk if necessary). I did this before the first coat because I wanted to eliminate filling in b/t the 1st and 2nd coat. It worked. Filling in the larger nail holes and cracks took some time but not as long as you think - quick bead then swipe with putty knife. I think it saved me time in the long run - plus you don't have to constantly stop and fill stuff in while you're just trying to focus on using the roller. Its just roll and go (in onedirection). I also brushed a light coat of the Restore solid stain in between the deck boards before I applied the thick stuff. This will greatly improve the visual appearance once the thick stuff is applied. I suggest using both the smaller and larger rollers - the smaller works great in the tighter areas. It will be somewhat weird when first applying but just like with anything new you'll find your rhythm. The first coat will be blotchy but the 2nd coat will fill it in nicely. First coat dry time was quick - 3 or 4 hours but I waited til the next day to put the 2nd coat on. I learned that the thicker you put the 2nd coat on AND the less you roll and re-roll over it the better the texture will turn out (less \\"rocky\\"). The material will start to lay down as it dries - rolling over it too much causes it to lay less and get \\"rocky\\", IMO. About it being too hot to walk on - I can't really say much on that yet b/c it has been relatively cool in our area for this time of the year. What I can say is this - we have 2 decks - the pool deck is composite and the larger deck is PT. Before Restore both decking materials got extremely hot in the direct sun (with the composite being the worst). We put a few outdoor rugs down and problem solved. So, will the Restore get hot? I would imagine.

TIPS: I used a roller grid that went right in the bucket vs a pan. Much easier IMO. I bought a $6 mixer and just left it in the bucket behind the roller grid - this allowed me to quickly attach the drill and mix if necessary (I did not have to mix that much - maybe twice per coat). I used a putty knife to scrape out the excess product that oozed in b/t the boards and scraped this on the next board I was going to do - no need to waste the product. Lightly re-roll to knock down where you scraped in b/t the boards - done.

I've finished @ 1/3 of my deck (@200 sq-ft) with 2 coats - took me 6 hours to apply the thick stuff. So, I'm looking at another 12 tofinish the deck - but won't be surprised if it takes less time. The majority of my time invested in this project has been the prep work. Sure, putting the thick stuff down takes a little extra time but, if I'm being honest, once you find your rhythm it's easy to put down. So, if you're considering doing the Restore - don't let the negative reviews steer you away - just make sure you prep, follow the instructions and take your time. After all, if you're supposed to get 8-10 yrs out of it (gimme 5 years and I'll take it) - don't you think it might take a little longer to put down? Oh, and I never added any water. Good luck Restoring...

Like others have stated, it may or may not turn on or off at the time selected. I set it to turn on and turn off three hours later. The "off" pin did move the switch about 3/4 of the way to the "off" position, but not far enough to turn the connected device off. Unfortunately I waited too long to return the item. It seemed to work the first time I used it, but failed the next usage after the return period.

The only glitch with this item is the tendency to enter test mode occasionally when you turn on a compact fluorescent light bulb near it. Apparently, the bulb triggers the TV Remote based testing function. A quick call to their support line later and they gave me the instructions to turn off that functionality. No more problems. Didn't get full stars ONLY because of the stress it caused before we figured out WHY it was going off. Other than that small issue, it seems to do it's job extremely well.

I have a number of Sentry Safes, they are fireproof for a length of time and this is the first one I've bought that is also waterproof, another nice feature. Their locks are make for locking, they're not real tamperproof, as I found when I lost the keys for my 1170 model and we were able to pick the lock within several minutes. In case you happen to have an 1170, this one opens a bit differently. With the 1170, you put the key in, turn it and can pick up the lid. With the H4300SG, after you unlock it, you have to press down on the lid while gripping and pulling up the lid at the same time. This probably serves the purpose whereas if the safe is unlocked and knocked over, the lid won't flop pen and possibly let items fall out. If you deal with something like bad arthritis in your hands, you might find opening the H4300SG a bit difficult. The Sentry safes do serve their purpose at a reasonable price; they don't take the place of a safe deposit box. The one I bought from Amazon was in \\"used - like new\\" condition, I saved money on it going this route. The condition was as advertised and I'm happy with the purchase.

The power goes off in the middle of the night and you are left to fumble for a flashlight in a drawer - if you have one. Or, you need to get up and walk to the bathroom or anywhere and need a readily available flashlight. This is HIPE's newest multi-function light and it's so easy to use.

The unit is a tray that plugs into the wall socket and the flashlight sits in the well - charging (simple induction). It has a three-prong plug, but this can be rotated at 90-degrees to fit the situation. The tray has a " thick LED blue light that stays on for a permanent nightlight. You can set the unit to ON, OFF or AUTO. The bottom switch is not labeled well, so you need to experiment a bit.

In the middle of the night, if the power goes off, the Light automatically lights up. The six (6) bluish LED lights are very bright and will illuminate the room easily. The button on the side will light the flashlight with one press. A second press will put it into strobe mode. A third press turns it off. I would suggest placing this near your bed for convenience.

When there is a black-out, the HIPE light will stay on until power is restored. I have not experienced this yet with my unit, but the idea of it not turning off means it will drain down. When you are done, simply switch the button to OFF. This will start to recharge when power goes back on. Because it is powered by an internal Lithium Ion battery, you never need replacement batteries. Remember those heavy flashlights with the Size 'D' batteries? Those are history and when you compare the price of this light to any ordinary flashlight, you'll wonder what took this invention so long to arrive.

Like all of HIPE products, they are environmentally friendly. This unit was generously supplied to me for an honest review.

I had a basic-model Speakman in the 1990s. It was all brass, solid as a rock, simple in design and function, and probably cost about $30 at the time I purchased it. The thing would probably be still working for me, but I tossed it into garage storage when I remodeled the bathroom, and opted for a high-priced, oh-so-fancy, multi-jet shower head from a company I won't mention. When that supposedly indestructible shower head needed to be replaced due to water streaming out the side seam (!), I looked around for my old Speakman. Gone. Probably donated to Goodwill by accident. So I went online and looked for a basic Speakman. Plastic! They are all plastic now. Then I saw this baby, and I was smitten. Old-school quality, even if it does come at a new-age price. I am pleased as can be after installing and using it. The overall design could not be cleaner, the chrome plating is thick and has a gorgeous gloss, the handle moves smoothly and evenly to move through the range of flow. I love the fine spray for most washing, while the "pour" setting is great for rinsing hair. No snazzy bells and whistles here, just a good, solid shower head that should last many years.

I think the reviewers complaining of inadequate water pressure may be talking about low water volume, which is a different issue. The strength of the spray this provides is quite good for a low-flow unit. I live in California, where every drop counts.

(One nice little detail is that Speakman provides the pipe tape necessary for installation, so don't buy any here, as I did.)

I love this lighting system. It makes me giggle because I had two men (an electrician and my husband) tell me that I couldn't have what I wanted for under cabinet lighting and this system gave it to me with the least amount of work and destruction. I wanted a regular light switch to turn them on (one on each side of the room was acceptable), and despite one side of cabinets being broken up by a window, I wanted those to come on with one switch too. The problem is that I have a two story house. They said that holes would need to be punched through the ceiling and the electrician said that we'd need to be concerned about the total load. Fortunately we were making this decision before tiling the back splash so we were able to run the connection, under the window and behind the wall, without any major destruction.

One piece of advice I'd offer is to be certain you know whether you want the cool bright light system or the warm lights. Newer appliances, like my exhaust hood, use the brighter blue light leds and the lights we've all been using in our homes are more like the \\"warm\\" lights. If you mix lights, chances are that the difference will scream out at you, and/or the \\"bright\\" lights will feel too harsh.

I should probably tell you that I purchased this same system through their online store. We needed additional pieces that this kit doesn't include and so it made more sense to buy it direct. We had to run one wire behind the wall for the cabinets separate by a window and the company offers that wire on their site. However, I did buy additional connectors through Amazon. It might be helpful to know that the website has videos that were very helpful in aiding us with our decisions, as well as helping us know what to expect. IMO, this company is tops for those looking to update lighting with ease, at a reasonable price that is actually relatively inexpensive when compared to others.

I ordered this radio from the World Net Daily Web-store. I had recently signed up to receive their email updates and as a thank-you bonus I was awarded a 50% off discount code.  I decided to purchase this Kaito 500 radio.  The price I paid was $30.35 and that included shipping.  I ordered it on Saturday evening and received it the following Friday morning.  The radio was packaged well and when I opened the box I was happy to realize it had been delivered in excellent condition.  After plugging the rechargeable battery in per instructions, and cranking the dymo for 1 minute, it powered right up and I was able to tune to my favorite AM station.  Although the speaker is small the sound was excellent at a fairly low volume.  I flipped to the FM band and that all sounded good too.  I haven't tried either SW bands yet but will test those at night.  I tested the flashlight and reading light function. Both worked without flaw. I was able to pick up the weather band on channel 1 but it did not pull that broadcast in nearly as good as a smaller weather radio that I have so the weather radio of the Kaito 500 could be much better.  The radio comes with various charging cables for cell phones etc.  I have not tested this function yet.  So far I rate this radio a 4 out of 5 stars due to the weather radio reception issue.  I have no serious complaints especially for the price I paid.

I purchased this mount because I wanted to mount my Samsung 63\\" [[ASIN:B003A7X5HU Samsung PN63C8000 63-Inch 1080p 3D Plasma HDTV, Black]] as close to the wall as possible, and this seemed to be the lowest mount available with the exception of the Samsung picture frame style mount, but that mount was over $200 and I had qualms about the stability of that mount (just mounts into the drywall - no thanks).

I had read some of the negative reviews about this ultra low profile mount where users had a problem with having room for wires. On my Samsung, the inputs are oriented towards the side of the TV, so I figured I'd have plenty of room for wires.

Installation wasn't too difficult, but the included instructions were pretty bad. I didn't find out until after installing that they have a video instruction on the Sanus website - I highly recommend viewing before installation. One thing to make sure you do before mounting the TV, is make sure you adjust the strings behind the TV so they hang down low enough (almost as low as the bottom of the TV) that you can reach them. You will need to pull these strings to make adjustments, plug in your inputs, or remove the mount later - so neglecting to adjust the strings prior to mounting, as I did on my first pass, can leave a major headache (I was able to fish them from behind the TV, and I removed the TV from the mount and adjusted the wires correctly and remounted ... again, had I watched the video I wouldn't have made this mistake in the first place).

So why 3 stars? Well I have a couple of problems with this mount. The bracket that attaches to the TV grips the top of the wall mount, then is supposed to \\"click\\" into place at the bottom in order to form a secure mount. Problem is, if there is anything back there at all blocking the TV, it won't click into place. This is the problem some of the negative reviewers who have TVs with inputs facing backwards have - it didn't leave any room for the HDMI or other input cables. In my case, my cables are perpendicular to the TV and don't seem to be the problem. What's even worse than the lack of clicking, is my TV isn't quite flat against the wall - the front of the TV is a little under 2\\" from the wall on the left side, and a little over 2\\" from the wall on the right side, for a difference of over half an inch. I think my culprit might be, the wall I have it mounted on is in a spot where an exterior concrete block wall meets an interior wall, with a sheet of drywall over the interior and the drywall has a very very slight (barely noticeable, and in fact not noticeable at all had I never tried to mount this to it) bulge to it. I think that very slight roundness is what is causing my problems with this mount. Yes, I realize this is mostly my own problem as I don't have a perfectly smooth mounting surface - but my point is, this \\"ultra slim\\" mount by leaving only .55\\" inches behind the TV leaves you almost no room for error. If there is any obstruction, including wires or anything else, you could have problems.

Other than that, the quality of this product is pretty good. The one week spot I would point out, and I haven't tested it for failure, but the mechanism where you pull the strings to release the lock seems pretty flimsy. If this mechanism were to fail, you would potentially find it extremely difficult to remove the TV from the wall. And again, with the extremely low profile of the mount at only .55\\", you'd have very few options to get back there and try to get the thing loose.

Overall, this isn't a terrible product, but I have to recommend it with reservations. If, like most TVs, the inputs on your TV face backwards requiring some room for wires, I would look for a mount that isn't quite so close to the wall. Similarly, if your wall is anything but perfectly flat and smooth (get up with your eye next to your wall and look, the imperfection I'm talking about is not noticeableotherwise), this mount could give you problems. On top of that, the flimsy string mechanism would worry me a little bit as well. Finally, if your setup can accommodate an ultra low profile mount and you do decide to buy this product, make sure to watch the installation video on the Sanus website, and if installing into concrete, I'd go out and buy better anchors than what comes with this mount.

3 Stars. Under perfect conditions it probably works fine and it does get the TV nice and close to the wall, but frankly I wish I'd just bought a less low profile mount to start with - it would end up looking just as good with much less hassle. I will probably replace this mount with one that has a little more forgiveness, likely one of the cheaper Amazon Basics models that get good reviews.oblems. On top of that, the flimsy string mechanism would worry me a little bit as well. I received these headphone straight from Flips audio themselves, I took there try before you buy challenge. I used them over a couple of weeks to them an honest try. I used them as headphones and also used the unique feature and as the name suggests the ear cups flip out 180 degrees to act as powered amplified portable speakers.

Here is the break down of the head phones.

Presentation.
The overall presentation of the headphones are very nice from the sleek packaging stating all the aspects of the headphones to the ample amounts of padding used to secure the headphones themselves. The headphones themselves are stored inside a semi hard shell. The. Hard shell itself Is more of an egg shape to accommodate the headphones in their folded positions. Inside the case comes the headphones in their folded position and a USB charging cable to charge the battery that is used when the headphones are used in the flipped out speaker position.

Build quality
The overall build quality of the headphones are a mixed bag. Some parts are built for use and abuse, like the sturdy metal hinges that are used when folding the phones to store them. While other parts seem just a little too weak for the job at hand. Ie. the pivot points of the actual ear cups have a very slight wobble when you flip out the ear cups to use as head phones. I do not know if they are designed that way or not. Also the headphones are a tight fit, after using them for an extended time the pressure of the head phone can be felt on the temples, even more so if you use glasses.

Sound quality

The sound of the headphones are good but not great. The sound range of the headphones seem to be somewhat limited are a bit flat. Mind you all of the sounds are their and can be heard. But the overall mix of the speakers seems to limit what these speakers are actually capable of doing.On the up side they do sound much better when they are flipped out and usedas powered speakers.

Overall

These headphones are descent headphones. But there are a few nuances That seems to keep these headphones from being great. I.e. the tight fit and the limited soundscape of the earphones keep these head phones from being a great pair.

I hope this honest review of these head phones help the maker consider some minor changes to these to make these head phones a great pair.

But as with all reviews it is up to you to come up with your own conclusion.

I bought the cable and for starters they sent the wrong length. Upon finally receiving the correct length, I found it to be a shoddy cable that would have channels cut in and out despite all of my efforts of twisting, bending, etc., when inserting into my laptop.

Yes, typical headphones work fine in my laptop. The cable was entirely at fault, and is now in the dumpster.
It sounds good, for the price, but it was a bit tight on my head.  I have used the mic feature and it also works well.
Third time is the charm.  This is the third pair of this type that I purchased for my wife and she loves these and finds them easy to wear.

We had used a Sound and Lights monitor for our first child, but when the baby came along and we needed a second monitor, I chose this one because of the many channels.  I wanted to make sure that there wouldn't be interference with our first monitor.  The difference between the two monitors is overwhelming!  This monitor does not make popping/crackling noises, or that odd bounding noise that my sounds and lights monitor does.  In addition, the monitor really picks up the baby sounds well and makes them stand out over the background noise.  We play a white noise machine (washing machine noise) and the noise cancelling feature does not eliminate this as background noise- however, it does minimize the sound in comparison to the babies noise in both modes.  I cannot begin to say how wonderful the lack of static etc is, not to mention the choice of 27 channels! My only complaint is that using this monitor has made me supremely dissatisfied with my older monitor- so I may have to buy a second Sony!

I just purchased these to replace my HD555s at work. Aaaand - I just printed the return label.

I love my 555s, but the open design is not ideal for a shared workspace. There's substantial two-way leakage, meaning that, in order to block out my more obnoxious cube mates, I must jack up the volume... in turn contributing to the general obnoxiousness!

On the other hand, the 555s are the most comfortable pair of cans I've ever put on, and I can wear them for an entire day with minimal fatigue. I've got some seriously sensitive ears, and even a bit of pressure or displacement becomes very uncomfortable quite quickly.

Upon opening, I was immediately concerned with the slightly less space in the cups, and the leather-like padding material (in contrast to the 555's velour-y padding). FWIW, I was aware of the leatherette cups at purchase, and thought I could probably live with it, (hoping they'd not be too sweat-inducing). I had, however, purchased the 448s hoping that sticking with the brand would mean the same voluminous cups. Alas, it proved not to be so.

Along with the above concerns, I wasn't impressed with the build quality by comparison. The whole kit was very plastic seeming and the cord was noticeably more flimsy than my triple-5 friends.

I gave the 448s an hour. I immediately noticed the outside attenuation, which was a good start, but also noticed a bit more pressure and less room in the cans. Sound was good through the laptop -> E5. Maybe a bit less transparent, but that was expected, and asked for. I didn't experience major discomfort, but I was *aware* of them the entire time, and thinking about how long it would be until I was going to experience cumulative discomfort.

Then the decisive moment - I put the 555s on to compare. Ahhhhhh. Little fluffy clouds.

Take note, Herr/Fraulein Sennheiser - closed version of the 555/558/595 design will be in my shopping cart the moment I am aware of such a product.

So, back go the 448s, sadly, and obnoxious co-workers will continue to be battled with reciprocal obnoxious volume-raising. Extremely *comfortable* obnoxious reciprocity...

[[ASIN:B0001FTVDQ Sennheiser HD555 Professional Headphones with Sound Channeling]]sadly, and obnoxious co-workers will continue to be battled with reciprocal obnoxious volume-raising. Extremely *comfortable* obnoxious reciprocity... [[ASIN:B0001FTVDQ Sennheiser HD555 Professional Headphones with Sound Channeling]]

Worked great! I needed this Active Adapter in order to be able to use three monitors at work with my Dell Precision M4700. I did not have monitors with display port so this fixed my problem. This adapter actually converts the DVI signal to Display Port signal. Something that normal adapters can't do. Best of all, I did not have to buy a new monitor :)

Setup, input, and connection are as everyone has posted - Amazingly Easy. But the design of the remote buttons is terrible. Logitech needs to have one of their designers actually use the remote and then send everyone the newly designed remote with an apology for letting this one out the box. It's long design screams keeping the most used buttons together - which didn't happen. You can actually stretch a thumb ligament finding the info button. DVR-GUIDE-INFO need to be moved up to where the EXIT MENU buttons are. An analog PAGE UP PAGE DOWN rather than 'sketchy" TOUCH SCREEN BUTTONS would add a flowing experience to the remote. I've owned Logitech mice, keyboards, and now this remote. And as the opening sentence shows, they're on the right track, just missed the bus with the layout.

I had been looking for a good sounding "portable" speaker. I must have seen about 20 different options. I started looking in the $200 USD range, obviously not the Marshall, but the reviews (i.e CNET) of such portable speakers would always make comparison to other better sounding speakers, including the Hanwell.
I am quite picky about sound.( I currently have a KEF home theater with a Velodyne subwoofer. I have my own dj sound system with Gemini amplifiers, JBL standing speakers and Mackie sub, AT 50 MX headphones. You get the picture. I am a sound freak.) I am always trying to get a good sounding system for different purposes.
So what about my verdict? I used to play the Bose Sound Dock 10 and it sounded so good. Now we own the Bose Soundtouch 30. Bose is really capable of delivering good music devices. The Hanwell is something else.
I just got mine. It is not produced by the same Marshall guitar amplifier/speaker company in England but by Zound Industries in Stockholm for Marshall. This company also produces their Marshall headphones which have great reviews too. I am not sure what components they are using but they could be from SEAS, a Danish company nearby with excellent components. I will have to write Zound to confirm this.
The Marshall sound is really outstanding as a "portable" speaker, considering you can carry a 23 lb speaker. It is not a speaker you will take with you around town, but is "portable" around the house. I wanted it for an outside dinning terrace, and it's just perfect.
As it is a single enclosure it will not give you any type of sounstage, but the mids and highs are good. Nice voice and guitars, and the lows are terrific for the size. It carries 2 6"; woofers, but it sounds like 10 inches subs.
I couldn't be happier with my selection.
I got myself a Logitech Bluetooth device and it works perfectly with my ipad and iphone.
This thing Rocks. It will be good for a small party(dancing included), if it's not set in an open area. I suggest to place it next to the wall and floor, tilted at 45. This way you get a better bass response and still direct the highs toward the ear level.
I used an SPL (sound meter) and at 1 meter it was pushing a very decent 97 dB. That's party level and not good for continuous listening, but it's nice to have it handy for that song that you really love.
So, if you want to have the best available sound from a "portable" 100 watt speaker, look no further. The looks are great too. Need Bluetooth? 30 USD and you are set.
I loved it so much I have ordered another one to play it in stereo. Now I will have a "portable" party system. Who could ask for more?
This speakers are a commemorative item, so they will become collectibles. The original price was 1000 USD. Under $600 they are a steal. They sure sound like a thousand dollars. Thanks Marshall. Thanks Zound Industries. From a grateful sound frea

I'm giving this five stars purely on function,  it is not the best tactile experience and lacts some programming features but fills a nitch that i could not find anywhere else.  If you are no longer using a cable STB and watch a majority of video content on the web (I'm using it with a Mac mini htpc) and don't want a 40 button monster remote then this is a perfect fit,  Of the three functions, one is your tv which becomes the standard channel up/down volume up/down input select and mute.  The next two become your audio receiver or a/v receiver and the last becomes your media device (apple tv or htpc for example).     Programming is pretty standard but I could not reprogram the menu button since it is used to exit the programming mode.  Other than that the only other problem I have with it is the small throw of the buttons.    I could not find the programming code map on the web so if you are wondering  it includes a very large tv,  av receiver and audio receiver list along with a list of media devices like apple.  That is it - no DVD/blue ray for example.    This product is all about simplification - it's very small (half the size of a standard universal remote), goes completely black (other than the ar label) when it's not moving (it has a tilt sensor to activate the button LEDs) and limits the buttons to an absolute minimum.
Works Great, easy to install, arrived on time and great price. Great picture conversion from HD to analog screen at home.

I have actually owned (and built) uhf antennas that were shaped like this, but that performed far better.  What irks me most is this came up highly rated in an amazon search for an outdoor antenna that could pick up uhf AND vhf signals.  It is not good for vhf signals, because it has no wide-armed element (I should have known better from my own experience).  It only picks up ONE hd uhf station and that is from the public television tower that is a mere five miles away.  It is advertised as having a range of 55 miles, but that is nonsense!  I am forty miles only from Franklin mountain (el paso) which has several uhf hd channels; there is nothing between me and them, it is a straight, line-of-sight projection; and yet I pick up none of these signals!  I actually did better with an old indoor antenna that I rigged up to sit on the roof!!  I will go back to that one and sell this on amazon.com I guess.    (Oh, I also assembled it correctly, mounted it correctly and followed all other instructions).  Very disappointed!

I replaced the bulb in my Hitachi 50VG825 LCD rear projection TV. The bulb was the original and I was surprised how long it lasted. When the bulb finally gave out, I didn't want to invest a lot in this older TV even though it is just like new. I saw bulbs from 29.00 shipped all the way up to the original Philips unit as high as 150.00. Since there are options with the case and without the case, I read the reviews and decided to forgo the case as most people ended up taking the bulb out of the case and putting it in their original case to get it to fit back in the tv properly. There are two wires that are attached with nuts to the bulb, on on the rear of the bulb and one on the side. Be careful with the one on the side. It is not as secure as the original bulb. Hold it firmly so it can't move and tighten securely. The new bulb was noticibly brighter, possibly because mine was so old. It is like having a new tv, even the colors are brighter. I am happy for now. I am interested to see how long this bulb continues to work, but for the price and improved quality, I can't complain. I will follow up when my new bulb quits!

If you like me enjoy the \\"bottom end\\" sound of music, perhaps are or were in to dance music in it's many forms, enjoy the sound of the base, perhaps spent a lot of time in dance-clubs as a youth listening to anything from deep house music through to reggae, jungle, drum and bass,  etc then these are not for you in my humble opinion. For classical music, guitar, vocal, folk, rock these are wonderful and have great high end clarity. If you want to hear the warmth of the bottom end save a few dollars or pounds or euros and go for the 485.

I am not an expert by any means. I just listen and see if I like what I hear. I found the RS170 to be very comfortable and easy to wear. It took just a little time to get use to where the headphone buttons were but no real problem. Even though the surround sound is digital simulation it is sure good enough for a non expert like me. It also surprised me how quickly the headphones recharged. I have some hearing loss and found that these headphones actually help with clarity of high frequency sounds.  All in all I was very pleased with my RS170 and would highly advise giving them a try. The quality is every bit of what I had expected and more.
