I do not recommend buying Able Planet products. I bought a brand new, retail packaged pair of $350 Clear Harmony NC1050 that failed within two weeks.  Under warranty, I requested a repair or replacement, per their written terms on the warranty card.  What they sent back were a pair of USED Sound Clarity NC510B ($149 - they called them "open box" but the padding clearly was worn down). When I complained they said they don't have anything else that is an equal replacement.  After multiple emails, including to their VP of Sales and Marketing, I was promised a new $199 pair. This was still not a fair replacement but they never even sent those! So, buy at your own risk because if your headphones fail, you can't count on this company to honor their warranty or to act in an ethical way.

This wall mount is a very good product. I have my 46 Inch Samsung smart TV conveniently mounted on the wall using the wall mount. Its been couple months now and its holding on great. The installation was also very easy. All you need to ensure is that you locate the stud properly. Beyond that, it was very easy.

Pros  Great sound quality  Perfect size - smaller than I expected  Easy installation and file/playlist transfer  A lot of space for the price    Cons  Battery life shorter than expected.  Menu a bit clunky  I've had it for three weeks and am still not used to the touch pad.  I always end up selecting things I don't mean to.  Who needs photos on an MP3 player?  I think they just add that to raise the price. I wish there was an 8GB without photo capability that was less expensive.    Overall  To me the most important thing in an mp3 player is sound quality. That combined with the amount of space and the easy transfer of playlists makes this a good deal.  I would buy it again if I had to do it over.

I have done a lot of research on screens after purchasing an Epson 5010 projector.  That particular projector was a bit past my budget, so I had to cut corners on the screen.  I was looking for the best bang for the buck while trying to achieve the best picture possible.  I found that in the Elite 100" electric screen.  I have owned the screen for about 3 months, but it was only installed 2 months ago.  I wanted to wait a bit before reviewing as I was concerned about a few things I had read in other reviews.  First, I bought this screen at about half the price that it is now.  Amazon had a great deal going right about the time I bought it.  I was worried that a "budget" screen wouldn't do my Epson justice but that is not the case.  The picture is fantastic.  I had read about problems people were having with curling.  The sides of the screen do curl a bit, but it does not affect the picture at all.  The motor is SUPER quiet, and rolls up and down with an elegance that belies the price.  I popped the batteries in, pushed the remote button, and my screen was rolling.  I had called Elite for some suggestions on placement, and they were excellent in responding, and even though they do not install screens they offered advice on how to install my screen in a drop ceiling.  I leave the screen down to avoid wear and tear on the motor, but it works just like it did from day one.  The picture on this screen is better than I could have ever expected, and for a "budget" screen this is just an excellent way to save some money while enjoying your movies in a larger-than-life adventure.  At the price I paid for this, this is just an excellent screen.  Highly recommended.

Pros  - Only 2 pieces as opposed to 7 with a traditional 5.1 setup, which also means...  - Only 2 wires! A power cord and a wire to connect the sub/receiver to the soundbar.   - Decent sound. This is NOT going to sound better or even as-good-as a standard 5.1 system, don't fool yourself.   - Price. My wife found these for $250, and that's a pretty darn good price.  - Connections. The thing has a LOT of them.    Cons  - The remote. Seriously, the thing has about 40 buttons and I only use 5, volume up/down, mute, power and input. And crazy enough, even those aren't laid out very well.  - Setup. People complain that there is no mid-range or that voice is hard to hear. These are people who obviously have either never set up a 5.1 sound system before or didn't read the manual. By default, the center channel is very quiet and the subwoofer is very loud. It took me about 15 minutes of going through the manual before I finally figured out how to alter those two settings, and now there's no issue with quiet speech or the lows drowning out the highs.  - As I mentioned, this does not sound as good as a 5.1 system.        Soundbars are for people who want decent sound at a reasonable price and don't want to monkey with receivers or wires snaking through their walls or under their carpet. In that regard, this product is a resounding success. I lament the fact that I don't get a true surround sound experience anymore, but I'm happy that my children no longer pull my speaker stands down on top of them, or futz with my receiver's buttons and throw everything off. It's easy (once you set it up) and it sounds great. You can't ask for much more than that.

Well folks, 2012 is finally here and some people tell us it's the end of the world again. Are you prepared if something natural or manmade knocks out the power system for an extended period of time?

A solar eruption like the Carrington Event of 1859 would fry the planet's electrical grids. Try manufacturing millions of replacement transformers when the world has gone dark; it could literally take years to restore power. Then there's foreign enemies setting off EMP weaponry high in the atmosphere with the same devastating result. Of course, more mundane weather disasters could also knock out power.

The K-TOR Pocket Socket along with a battery recharger and rechargeable batteries will give you some solace and keep your battery powered lanterns, CD player-radios, fans, and other devices working. I tested my K-Tor on recharging the batteries in my portable 9 inch DVD player. The good news is that I can relax in my bunker and keep watching my favorite programs on DVD after civilization has collapsed. The bad news is that it takes over 3 minutes of \\"light, easy cranking\\" for every 1 minute of viewing. Or you can attach your K-TOR to the Lenmar DVDU923 battery pack; recharging it offers a lot more resistance and requires some muscle power, but delivers about 16 minutes of viewing for 5 minutes of cranking. [[ASIN:B0011MZORU Lenmar DVDU923 Universal Li-Ion Battery for Select Portable DVD Players]] A competitor, the ERDVDMAX battery pack provides 17 viewing minutes for 5 cranking minutes. [[ASIN:B00076QBHS Technuity ERDVDMAX Battery, Universal Nimh for Portable]]

My initial effort at battery recharging suggests it could take an hour or more of cranking to recharge four AA battteries. Obviously, only an exercise freak would use this device so long as electricity is flowing out of wall sockets. But if/when there's no other source of electrical power, the K-TOR could be worth its weight in gold.

There are many things to like about this radio. It appears to be of high quality construction, the tuning knobs have a good feel to them and operate smoothly, and it has a sound bigger than the relatively small size of the speaker would suggest. There are some problems with it, however, mainly related to SSB and weak signal reception. I would urge prospective buyers to research the radio in the Yahoo Groups for the PL-880. It was brought out in the group that there appear to be multiple firmware revisions available, and that batch 8820 is the most recent. Earlier versions had even more problems than the 8820, so do yourself a favor and check.

The radio does have sync detection available by pressing and holding either one of the SSB keys. However, sync does not hold well at all, and it also adds considerable distortion. There are multiple filter options available, but SSB is limited to 4 KHz, even when sync detection is activated, which limits the fidelity of the radio. There are also other problems with the current firmware which cause the bandwidth to change when you try to tune a SSB signal, and also cause the audio to jump around when trying to listen to a weak signal. The front end overloads easily with an outdoor antenna, even when the signal is attenuated by using the 3 position switch to cut down the antenna gain.

If all you are looking for is a good looking radio with a great sound for AM and FM only, I would recommend it. If you will be listening to more Shortwave, Longwave, or SSB, and want a functional sync detector with a reasonable bandwidth for good fidelity, then I would hold off until the design matures more. Also beware firmware revisions 8819 and below at this time. These should be "B" stock and not sold as new.

Having purchased a smaller unit Eaton several years ago, I was prepared to be unimpressed. But this slightly larger unit has far superior tuning, reception and sound quality. I was disappointed to see that it doesn't come with a wall adapter, but later realized that it's not necessary because the crank is so incredibly effective. A brisk two-minute crank literally powered the radio for over five hours! It's so easy there really seems to me to be little reason to install batteries in storage and watch them slowly die.

It should be noted that the manual indicates a limit on the total number of manual charges the internal battery can sustain, which means cranking may not be a suitable technique for routine operation! But as a standby communication device it seems just about perfect.

Lo unico que hace falta para hacerlo perfecto es talves un contrapeso para evitar los saltos (skips) en los discos que no estn en ptimas condiciones. Location can allow these antennas to work well or worse than a short antenna because near by objects can greatly effect the signal.  In the open with an antenna which is not broken I have seen noticeable improvement.  However indoors I have had to move the location so that the longer antenna would work properly, like it would in an open field.  If you can not get away from metal objects within a foot or two at the same level as your wifi devices then yes this could likely give worse results than a short antenna, but the fault is how radio waves travel not the design of the antenna itself.

Battery 1 = 875 mAh
Battery 1 = 892 mAh
Battery 1 = 878 mAh

Consistent with its rating of 850 mAh.

Recyko is the low self discharge nickel metal hydride battery manufactured by GP (Gold Peak - a Hong Kong based company). I find them comparable to other low-discharge batteries from Sanyo, Rayovac, Duracell, Yuasa, etc. Package says 850 mAh, 1.2V. Printed on the battery itself says 820mAh. Needed a new alarm clock, nothing fancy, but had to be dependable with easy to read numbers, yet soft on the eyes. The Sony display numbers are 0.9 tall in a light green LED, which are very good. This Sony device fits the bill with a fairly small footprint (approx 6 wide, 6 deep and 3.25 high). In fact, for the money paid, it comes with a couple of features that, for me, are a bonus.  First, it has Automatic Time Set, which is adjusted by your time zone, and should never have to be reset with the built-in lithium battery.  With that is a daylight savings time adjustment feature that works automatically with the built-in calendar. This is not a huge deal, but a very nice convenience.  But I did get this primarily for its alarm feature and it does not disappoint. There are two alarm settings (A and B) and I use A for weekdays and B for weekends.  Nice and convenient.  While it does have a snooze control that works, I do not particularly use that feature, but it is there if and when needed. The tunerty good and will, more than likely, be affected by how well AM and FM signals are in your specific area. For me, I am able to capture my favorite few stations.  Overall, this Sony AM/FM Clock Radio is a very good purchase.

I must admit, I was a little worried by the reviews I read; seems a lot of people had trouble with these headphones.  Thankfully, my experience has been compltely positive.    I bought these because I have a new baby, and in the rare instance that I have free time to play a game, I didn't want it to wake her up.  These are fantastic for gaming.  The sound comes through clearly and- once you find the right channel & frequency- static-free.  I will go so far as to say it even enhanced my gaming experience because I don't have surround sound, and with these stereo headphones I can now tell which direction a sound in the game is coming from.    The range is fairly short, but if you're using it to watch TV or play video games that isn't a problem.    One point of consideration if you're buying this for the same reason as I did: one of the channels (there are 3 total) is the same as our baby monitor (Graco), so it couldn't be used.  Also, even on the channel that doesn't interfere, if I wear them into the room with the baby monitor microphone, there is substantial feedback.  So there's probably no way to use them too close to the nursery.    Overall, this is a fantastic product for the price; this headset is about half of what the other highly reviewed sets were ranging.  I absolutley recommend them.

I recieved the Zen Micro as a present and although I had never heard of it, I was excited to get a new MP player, and even more excited to get one that played 2,500 songs.
After recieving it, it took about an hour to download the software onto my computer and then 7 hours to fill my player with songs and create albulm for them. With the Creative media player that installs on your computer and takes over as the primary media player wether you want it to or not, the process of uploading music involves moving track by track and about a minute per song.

After getting about 800 songs on the player it was full, what Zen only writes in very fine print is that the player holds 2,500 WMPAs, which I had none of. Still excited to have a small player to put in my pocket on the treadmill, I headed out to the gym. After less than two minutes the player was broken. I tried rebooting it acording to the intructions, this involved awkwardly pulling out the battery and hitting some buttons, nothing happened. Also some of the aptions in the rebooting menu that pops up an not only wipe out your music, but wipe out all the firmware on the player, and because of the desighn of the virticle touch pad, accidently hitting on of these options is all too easy.

On the phone with Creative, they said they would replace it. Since my player was bought off of Amazon during the holiday season and I did not get it until two months later it was too late to return it to Amazon.

A month later I recieved my replacement. Again after spending the good part of the morning and early afternoon uploading my music, I headed off to work with my new player in hand. Then it happened again, this time I was running to catch the city bus when the player froze. Again nothing happened when I tried to reboot it.

Creative replaced it again becuase that was all they could do, they refuse to give me any type of refund.
I just recieved my third Zenmicro yesterday, oddly enough it arrived on the same day as my new IPod mini. The ipod took less than an hour to download the software (itunes)which had a much better interface even on my PC. Another hour later, itunes had uploaded 1,000 songs as promised to my IPod, which has proven to work wonderfully walking around, riding the subway, catching the bus, and yes working out at the gym. Also the circular pad is much easier to use tha the vertical pad of the Zen. The rebooting process also only involves hitting one button as opposed to opening up the player and giving yourself the oppertunity to wreck the whole thing.

Six months after first using the Zen Micro I am now happily part of the MP player carrying community with my new IPod mini. All I can say is that it's on top for a reason.

I bought this internet security suite because of the attractive price, features, and reviews, but when I installed it on my new Dell Inspiron 531, it slowed everything on my machine to an unbearable crawl. After many hours of frustration, I finally managed to contact tech support online, and someone in India took control of my computer and finally was able to get the software totally off my machine. Right after that, my speed was back to normal. Given the frustration and time wasted on this software, I would never recommend it to anyone.

This product is fantastic. I tried one of those flat, window mount devices but the reception was spotty. I live in a major metro area and I knew I should be able to get better reception. It took me about 15 minutes to assemble and about 30 minutes to mount to my old Dish network mount on the roof of my home. The reception is awesome. I now get 55 channels, all clearer than my cable or dish service ever got them. I know some people said the antenna is "flimsy" but all outside antennas are light weight. I guess a lot of folks have forgotten the old outside antennas from the 50s, 60s and 70s before cable, but they were all light weight aluminium.
Just be sure to ground them and clamp them tightly to your mounting pole. It is a real joy to watch these channels now at no monthy expense. (P S) I have tried the motor driven part and found four more channels so I am up to nearly 60 channels.

I was dealing with bad insomnia for the past few months, and my efforts to wake earlier (so I'd be tired enough to sleep earlier) were not helped by me constantly sleeping through my alarm. I was looking for a clock with a few specific functions: 1. It had to have a gradual wake feature, as the shock from normal alarm clocks always left me groggy in the morning, 2. It had to be able to use some kind of nature sound as the alarm, simply because it's more pleasant to wake up to those than it is to a beep, and 3. It had to be lit with cool blue LED lights, because this is less jarring to look at at night, and the blue is more soothing to look at than the normal red LEDs, which just look ugly to me.

It was really impressed with how many sounds there were on the clock (20), I didn't expect it to have that many. I've never heard the earlier model so I can't comment if the clarity was better with those, but the sounds are fine to use as an alarm. They are definitely not clear enough to use as a sound machine or sound soother; there is a lot of noise, like the sounds were recorded through a cheap microphone, or possibly the speakers are cheap. But since I did not buy the alarm clock to listen to, and just use it as an alarm, it personally did not matter to me.

Some of the sounds are also pretty clear. I like to use the wind chimes sound as my alarm, since it's a gentle way to wake up, and the sound clarity is better than some of the other sounds like the ocean or the brook.

It's very easy and straightforward to navigate the clock menus and set up the alarm. You can also program 2 alarms, which is a nice bonus! And you can set each alarm to go off everyday, every weekday, or every weekend day. I was impressed with how many features the clock was programmed with.

My insomnia is also a lot better now, and this clock looks great on my blue desk! It had an unobtrusive yet slick and modern design, and the numbers have 3 levels of brightness that are all aesthetically pleasing. There is also a daylight savings time button on the back of the clock, so you can adjust that with the flick of a finger instead of programming it through the clock buttons manually.

I am happy with my purchase and glad I bought it despite the negative reviews. :) There really wasn't any other alarm clock on Amazon that fit my criteria, and if they did they cost over $100 and there was no way I was paying that much for an alarm clock, so I'm relieved that the one clock that is reasonably priced turned out to be better than what I had been expecting.

I read almost all the reviews and agree with most of what's said. But I have a warning. First, my story. I bought this gadget to listen to and record the old albums I last heard back in the 80's. So I dug out my old Sony PS-X600 turntable (high end in its day), made all the connections to my home theater system, cued up \\"Innervision\\" (by Stevie Wonder), and let rip. AWFUL! Sound quality was terrible!

I started going through everything trying to find the problem. After all, I was an audiophile back in the day and I should have the know-how to troubleshoot this mess. Well, I found it. The moving magnet style M97 Shure cartridge, which was high end in its day, was shot. I replaced it with a new one (got a great deal here on Amazon), and then WOW I got blown away by Stevie singing \\"Superstition.\\" Then I cranked up Pat Benatar, then Spyro Gyra then Chicago Transit Authority. All sounded fantabulous!

For all you baby boomers out there, the warning is this -- just because your turntable spins the record it still might need a new cartridge or a new stylus. The sensitive internal stylus parts degrade and deteriorate over time even if you never use the turntable. So if you buy this Art Preamp and the sound quality sucks, check your cartridge, people!

I was provided this antenna free for an honest review. It just so happened I was in desperate need.

I have not had cable for about 5 years now. It was just getting ridiculous. So, like many others, I bought an antenna to get local channels. I tried three or four antennas of various cost, and it was always chopping and crappy. I could never get a solid digital signal. I gave up on ever seeing my local channels again.

This antenna, on the other hand, is totally different. It has a pretty good range on its own (despite being paper thin), but it also has a signal booster. It is powered by USB if you have a USB port on your TV (most TVs have this, and it says "for service only," but it works great); if not, there is a little power adapter you can also attach. The cords are all nice and long.

With this antenna, I am getting channels I didn't even know existed in the area. My local channels are clear as can be, no choppiness at all, and I get the public channels as well. I'm thrilled! I had given up on ever seeing them again, but now I have them, for free, with this antenna, which works where other antennas totally failed me.

These discs are great, but for the Mavica recomended cameras that use them, I continue to get disc errors with the Sony brand. Though I do have to say, they are much cheaper than the Mavica's. easy to put together and the level is actually accurate.  I have it holding up my 40" Samsung TV. it's not a heavy TV, but I like the quality of it.

Works very well in czech republic, hungary and austria.  When we got to Switzerland the hotels we stayed at had only one plug that it would work in(the plug where the TV was plugged in).  All the rest of the plugs were either recessed diamond shaped and too small for the adapter or the prong holes were too small for the adapter.  We unplugged the TV for one and utilized our power convert with small prongs for other chargers.  Two in one function was excellent as we had 3 cameras, one video camera,a tablet and an I-touch that needed charging(electronics you get when you take kids with you). They had to stay in touch with their friends via facebook every night.

I just received my Grace Tuner the other day, and I must say, this is an AWESOME product. I have been looking into various internet radios, namely the Squeezebox, and did not see anything that looked like it met my needs. When I saw the Grace Tuner and found out I could get internet radio stations, Pandora, and stream my MP3's from my NAS drive, with audio coming through my stereo, I had to try it out. I have the product installed using ethernet because I keep my router with my home theatre equipment (for PS3, XBOX 360, and Kaleidescape) so I cannot speak to the Wifi but every review I have read says the Wifi works great. From the moment I powered it up, it has worked flawlessly. I have located several local radio stations, setup my Pandora account to stream to the Tuner, and connected my Cisco NAS 200 box to stream my MP3 collection. I am using my iPhone as a remote, which is a great FREE feature for this device. The LCD screen, as many have said, is not that detailed, but it is clear and bright. My only gripe would be that when scanning through my 50GB of MP3's, I have to scroll through all the artists or albums to get to the one I want, so if I want to listen to Warren Zevon I have to scroll from the A's to the W's. Would be awesome if the iPhone APP had a search by letter feature for your files. Other than that, this is a great product and probably one of the best purchases I have made in the past few years.
Perfect - works as advertised and is much less expensive than similar name-brand wire.  Would definitely buy again.

I've been an audiophile for over 40 years and these headphones deliver as much value as one can expect for the price.  Very nice sound reproduction over the listed frequency range and for all kinds of different music/instruments.  The headphone design turns the earpices direcly in toward the ear canal in order to deliver more sound to the inner ear instead of around the outer ear.  Very comfortable foam earpads that don't cause ear fatigue over several hours of listening.  The only downside is the length of the cable.  I use my phones for my computer at work and a 6' or longer cable would be nice.  The 4.5' cable length should be fine for iPods or other portable devices, though.  Buy 'em, you won't be disappointed.

Just bought a brand new panasonic passive 3d tv to replace an old sony in which we were still using a converter box. Don't have cable, never have, never will. Anyhow, decided to buy a new antenna. My husband picked up this model @ Home Depot and its junk.
When we first installed it, couldn't even pick up channel 49(ION) Had to rescan at least 6 times. Every time you change channels, you have to get up and fiddle with the antenna, I mean everytime! If you're on 26(FOX), flip to 49(ION), antenna won't even pick it up, screen goes black and tells me channel is unavilable. If you're on 49 and flip to a major channel like CBS/NBC/ABC, picture continuously pixilates, sound goes in and out, so jump up and fiddle with the antenna. What's the point of remote control if you have to keep jumping up to move the antenna? Sometimes I just give up and turn it off. I've tried putting it in the window, turning it upside down, horizontal,vertical, antenna all the way up,half way down, all the way down and I only live about 12.7 miles from most of the major towers with no tall obstacles in the way! A couple of them are around 17 miles away, but those aren't the stations I have trouble with.
We have a 4 yo HD Magnavox in the bedroom, using a 4 yo,$5 Dollar store loop antenna that gets better reception than this amplified, optimized HDTV GE antenna does. I'd give it a minus 0, if I could. Guess we'll put our old 6 yo antenna back on tomorrow. Good thing we kept it.
Didn't read there was no inline volume control. Sound quality just ok but what do you expect for a mere $25?

Some batteries sold as 18650 LiIon batteries don't have a large enough button at the top to make contact on many devices. These batteries don't have that problem and they work in everything I have tried them on. I use them mainly for flashlights but work in laser pointer as well. Works great for me. Saw my signal strengths boosted by an average of 20 to 30 points on the 0 to 100 scale. I am using an attic fractal antenna and am 27 to 46 miles from transmitters. However, I also receive signals from two transmitters 103 miles away - one station all the time and the other about 75% of the time. That's 18 transmitters providing 50 digital channels. Hook up was very easy. I plan on adding a distribution amplifier to my other sets and then cutting the cord with cable. I should add that my TV shows max signal on several channels, but they never seem to be overloaded as the picture and voice are perfect.

Right now, we use only 2 Splitters - ViewHD 2 Port 1x2 Powered HDMI Mini Splitter & OREI HD-102 1x2 1 Port HDMI Powered Splitter. They work! And appear to be the same Device, different paint job. We're always looking for HDMI Splitters. As long as these work, no need to get firmware hacked HDFury HDMI Splitters from China. BTW: All of this gear is made in China. Anyway...  This ViewHD 2 Port 1x2 Powered HDMI Mini Splitter can also be Rack Mounted. We've found 2 ways - Compression Shelf or DIN Rail Mounts. The Rack Mount Compression Shelf is less expensive. We currently use Middle Atlantic OCAP-2 2U Vented Clamping Rack Shelf.  We have 4 HDMI Splitters Rack Mounted and wired into an HDMI Patch Panel. We can reconfigure, on the fly, for whatever a Presentation requires. Getting Power to 4 HDMI Splitters was more difficult. Solution: USB Power! Using Cargis 6 Port USB Charger & StarTech 3 foot USB to Type M Barrel 5V DC Power Cables. Works! Hope this helps!

like most 20something year olds... i'm obsessed with taking photos. especially straight-on self portraits or ones of myself and friends all trying to desperately squeeze our faces close enough together that we'll all be in the picture.
thank goodness for being able to digitally delete and redo!
i really can't count how many photos i've taken that aren't capturing anything more than less than flattering angles of only parts of people's faces.
we're all familiar with extending our arms as far out as we can and snapping the pic, then quickly clicking to view what ends up being only everyone's forehead.
how i didn't think of this invention first.. pains me, financially. but, i am happy to give my 30 bucks to the real mastermind.
it's awesome, truly.
you can extend it out far enough to completely capture everyone's entire face.
and once you REALLY get the hang of it... you can include some background in there. great for scenic vacations! or slyly getting that hot guy behind you in the picture, too.
it also seems totally plausible that you could just extend it straight up and over everyone's head in crowds to get decent pics at concerts and such!
everyone that's seen me use it comments on how ingenious it is, and i couldn't agree more!

I have four of these speakers. Of those four, one is defective. The volume isn't as loud as the other three speakers, but if you tinker with the volume wheel you can eventually get it to sound as loud as the others, considering you don't touch the volume wheel or move the speaker too much. From this, just know that there's a small chance you'll get a defective speaker. I cannot comment on return policy since the defective one was a gift.    Of the ones that do work, expect surprisingly loud sound. Turn your MP3 player, iPhone, etc. to max volume and turn the speaker to max volume and, trust me on this, you will be surprised by how loud this little speaker is. Plus, it has its own headphone jack to plug into your music player, phone, etc. so you don't need a separate one. All you need to do to charge is to plug it into your computer's USB with the included cable and the battery lasts a long time. I also like how if you buy two or more you can connect them to each other to play music through all connected speakers. I really recommend this speaker for gifts. I take it everywhere I go.

This is great for me.  I have a regular Sony Dream Machine and I wanted one that would work with my Ipod so that I could fall asleep to my relaxation apps and audio books.  It works great.  I thought it was very easy to set up and it took less than 5 minutes out of the box!  The directions were clear and it was pretty intuitive.  I love that you can dim or turn off the LED completely.  The sound is just as good as my other Dream Machine and I would explain it as "personal use" speaker.  I wouldn't use it any louder than 16... it's not a boom box it's an alarm clock radio and as such it's great!  It met all my criteria: Ipod compatible, back-up battery, LED dimmer, Sleep timer, FM radio to wake-up to my favorite station, Antenna to ensure my favorite station comes in, and it is just the right size.  For an Ipod it doesn't come with the seat part so you do need to have that piece that comes with your Ipod to fit in the clock and hold the Ipod in place.  Mine was white and I think it looks cool to have the white piece on the black clock.  It does come with three various seats for different versions of the IPhone. Overall I am very pleased.

Received the power filter before requested promise date and I used the free shipping option. :) The unit is very well built with a heavy duty power cord and plug - nice that the plug is a right-angle plug so it fits snuggly against the wall outlet. The unit came with its own mounting bracket - though I did not use the hardware included - wanted to be sure it never came loose from the wall so used screws that were a little more substantial. The mount bracket slots are spaced nicely and accepted the heavier screw, (my choice) also included is a template to mark the location of the screw holes and a sketch of the unit to show the dimensions of the filter prior to mounting as to not contact the TV mount. Having the LED lights on the end plate of the filter is a great location making them easy to read with a glace behind the TV. All in all - very satisfied with the packaging, construction and ease of mounting and would definitely purchase another one of these for a second/third TV an or home theater device in another room.

The cord itself is well built and delivers as a legit monster product. However...unless you have an old TV with one HDMi slot, this cord will block your other ports and forget about using it on the side HDMI, the angle of it makes it useless. You can put the right angle in the output of the digital device but you will then have to place your device on a book or something to lift it off the table to account for the length of the angle. This is with a 55 inch Vizio. On my 42 inch Sylvania LED, the HDMI ports are on the bottom of the TV so the right angle bumps into the front face plate and cannot be plugged in.

It's a good idea to make sure the HDMI ports on the back of your TV are flush and not close together otherwise it will block the other ones. Also, the side HDMI is a no go as newer TV's are thinner than the inch and half angle length making it so you can't even plug it in. This will only work with a flush HDMI slot on the back of your TV. It was created to eliminate the wasted space from your cables jutting out like zombie arms. Good idea, but to be used for ideal situations as listed above.

Purchased this remote after reading the reviews. Was a bit worried with some of the negative ones, but since it was compatible with the the dish network figured I would give it a try. When it got here looked for the code for the dish and  followed the directions which were easily understood. First code I entered was a hit and I could again changes the channels on the dish.   Then tried to look up the code for my TV. Not so lucky there, they did not have it. Tried using the 0 code that was suppose to work if your TV was not listed, but that did not work. So then tried the learning command. Again no luck, tried a few times, but could not get it to work. Figured since I really had only gotten it to replace my dish remote was not a big deal. Even though it would have been nice to only have to use one remote.  After reading the learn directions again realized I might have been doing it wrong. So today tried again to learn some of the TV remote commands. This time it was successful with one minor glitch. When I use the volume control it works backwards. When you turn it up it goes down and when you turn it down it goes up. Not a big deal since I can now control the dish and TV from the same remote. The off and on for the tv works fine. I did not program anything else yet because for now that is all I need, but it is nice to know that if I want to put more things on the new remote I can.

I bought this because I was having a problem with the HD signal on some existing wiring. The coax was fairly old. The signal was boosted fine and the problem with the HD signal went away. However, another problem came up. I use Verizon FiOS and the Version DVRs send signals back to the Verizon servers using the high end frequency ranges. All of my DVRs had the similar problems - they were either "unable to connect to the server" or they were unable to see the content on the other boxes After spending time on the phone with tech support - the result was "check your wiring".. I replaced the static, unpowered, splitters with one that were designed for HD signals and reran a new RG6 cable to the box that the other boxes could not see. The "can't connect to server" error went away, but all of the boxes were not able to see everyone else. I then removed the 8-port device and rebooted every server and every box could see all of the others.

I did return the box and received a refund.

So, even though it did not work completly in my case, it is still a good product.

I'm really surprised. I wanted to like this but Apple was asleep at the wheel. Never thought I'd say that about them. I just started using it, so there are things I haven't experienced yet. I used to own a 5Gen iPod, 80 GB, which I loved. But it got stolen and this was a replacement. I'd now sacrifice the added capacity to get my old model back. FTR, I also own an iPad 2, another great Apple product. I have been considering buying a Macbook Pro and leaving the Windows universe. This product is so flawed I'm reconsidering...seriously.   Here are my first impressions...I'll start with the positives.   PROS  1. The face looks more elegant than my previous iPod and the unit is thinner (a constant aspiration of iterative Apple design).   2. Double the memory of my 5Gen, 80GB (though I still had room to spare on the 5Gen).   That's it for the PROS.   CONS  1. The HD makes noise when you use it. Other people comment on this, and it's true. My older iPod was silent. This one chirps/whirs every time I click the controls. It's not loud, but it gets really annoying.   2. MY BIGGEST GRIPE: The edges are SHARP! It's an Apple iPod for crying out loud. Apple is known for its elegant design and feel. What were they thinking? The seam between the metallic back and face is a sharp edge that goes all the way around the unit. And I've got big, tough man hands...Used tools all my life. This thing feels like a cheaply manufactured piece of Asian garbage. When I rub my fingernail against the edge, it planes off shavings...seriously! It really is sharp. If I don't return the unit I will run a file around it to soften the edges. Shouldn't have to.   3. The split screen may have seemed to a young, inexperienced designer like a cool idea to pack more info, but the truth is (as others have said here) it just mucks up what used to be a clean, usable interface. It is useful for things like Settings, where it give more detailed info, but for most of the use it just shows pieces of album covers -style over substance. The user should be able to modify its function in Settings. There has been a trend to add thumbnail pics to everything, including smartphone apps. Often, though this adds tiny visuals that add nothing but get in the way of great clean interfaces. There is a reason Craigslist still rocks with its seemingly stone age interface. IT WORKS! You get exactly what you need without superfluous visual muck that competes for your attention. I consider it a step backwards.    I have not yet tested it thoroughly to hear if, as other have mentioned, the sound quality has been degraded over previous models.   For me the CONS are significant. The Classic has been out for years now. Every change should be an improvement. I really wonder if they WANT people to run away from non-iPod \\"Touch\\" models. If so, making people waste money on unpleasant designs like this is a pretty annoying way to do it. Good money for a device that feels like handling a steak knife by the blade.   Recommend evaluating a unit physically before buying online to see if you like it.

I have been buying these tapes for years because of their higher reliability compared to cheaper mini DV cassettes, such as some JVCs that I tried before. I do a lot of HDV recording, but the price of Sony \\"HDV cassettes\\" is way too high to be efficient. My archive library consists of over 300 mini DV tapes because they hold so little footage, and I trust these Maxells to store my HD footage. They record for about 01:02:30, that being about 2.5 extra minutes you get out of them which I have used on occasion! They work well with my Sony HVR-M15AU mini DV/HDV deck and dropout rate is very low. I used these as a backup for a critical show production requiring pristine quality video where computers would otherwise fail. Because HDV is a digital format, the tape quality does NOT affect picture quality, but it DOES affect reliability (i.e dropouts and errors). If you need cheaper tape stock for HDV recording and playback, I highly recommend these as a cheaper alternative to the \\"HDV\\" labeled cassettes.

I bought this unit for my Family Room because I wanted to have the following there: 1) Better sound from the front speakers, 2) Bluray player, 3) Working surround sound (had problems with some FOX programs), 4) Netflix streaming. 5) Ability to use HDMI to connect everything

I had an older THX certified Onkyo receiver and a Panasonic DVD player connected before - neither of them had HDMI support. I had surround sound, but it was using the small cube speakers from Cambridge.

I am very happy with this unit. The front speakers have three drivers each and the sound is a lot fuller than my previous setup. The stands are kind of big, so you need to allocate floor space for them. I don't see any way to use the front speakers without the stands. You can use your own speaker wire for all speakers - something that is very important for me and not seen in some of the cheaper units. Since the subwoofer amplifier is in the main unit, you can move the subwoofer to anywhere you can get the speaker wire. My previous subwoofer had a built-in amplifier and I had to keep it behind the TV and use shorter line level cables to the receiver. This new subwoofer was actually vibrating the surroundings back there so I had to move it to another corner of the room with more open space. Was pretty easy since I had a large spool of speaker wire. I did not use any of the wire that was included with the system. I used a much heavier gauge with no problem.

You should buy an analog sound meter to calibrate the speakers. There is a setup menu on the GUI that lets you send white noise to all the speakers. I had to knock down the center speaker a bit and crank up the two surrounds to get everything equalized. You can find a few on Amazon, like this one: [[ASIN:B0000YHNKG Extech 407706 Analog Sound Level Meter]] - but they are also available at RadioShack. Set it at 70db, C weighting, slow response. Send the test signal out the left front speaker. Adjust the volume until the meter reads 0dB. Then you just cycle through all the other speakers and adjust them so that the meter also reads 0dB. It's pretty simple and the meter is worth the money. You cannot do this with your ear. I have had my meter for years.

The Bluray performance is great. The movies look sharp and crisp on my Sony SXRD projection TV in 1080p/60Hz. The Netflix streaming was also flawless. I didn't order anything from CinemaNow, but the interface seemed to work quickly - just like the entire GUI. Before this unit, I had never heard of Pandora Radio. It's very cool and super easy to use with this system. The unit must enable some Dolby matrix setting because Pandora radio comes out from the surrounds too. YouTube was also easy to use, but I think that prefer the Apple TV interface for this. I did not try Audio CDs or the USB port yet. Don't really need those with the Apple TV pulling all those stuff from my iMac automatically. The iPod dock seems pretty convenient, but again I don't need that since I have an Apple TV. I did try plugging in my iPod touch (first generation) into the dock and it couldn't seem to access it. I have some newer iPods that I can try - the manual shows a very complete GUI interface for the iPod integration so it should be a nice feature for those without an Apple TV. Now that I think about it- if I had bought this device first, I may have never purchased an Apple TV.

The only thing that I am having trouble with is the integration with my Harmony One remote. It seems that LG does not supply discrete remote codes for source inputs. The 'InputNext' button downloaded to the Harmony was also not working. I had to re-learn that function and program it to the 'Enter' key for each Activity. The Harmony could not seem to switch between activities using this button, so I will just do it manually. I couldn't seem to find a way to have the LG skip over my unused inputs - like FM, AM, Coaxial, Optical. I am hoping for a firmware updatethat would do this because it would speed up the input switching task. I suppose they could also add these discrete codes using a firmware update. That would be great, but I'm not sure how long it would take Logitech to get the codes into their database.

This system really is a great buy. I have not found another device close to this price that included HDMI inputs and full range front speakers. My room is about 15 x 20 and the sound levels are fine. I can recommend this device for small to large rooms without hesitation. I have a front projector in my basement paired with much larger in wall and a full 7.1 speaker system setup. This LG is a much easier setup that has great performance. Unless you are willing to buy and build a real home theater setup, you should be very happy with this unit.

UPDATE 12-31-09: The iPod dock does work. Finally realized that I needed to use the iPod button on the original remote to access it. The InputNext button on my Harmony One would not cycle to the iPod. Also, the USB interface did play music and photos from a USB drive fine, but as was mentioned by others will not play videos.ed up the input switching task. I suppose they could also add these discrete codes using a firmware update. That would be great, but I'm not sure how long it would take Logitech to get the codes into their database. This system really is a great buy. I have not found another device close to this price that included HDMI inputs and full range front speakers. My room is about 15 x 20 and the sound levels are fine. I can recommend this device for small to large rooms without hesitation. I have a front projector in my basement paired with much larger in wall and a full 7.1 speaker system setup. This LG is a much easier setup that has great performance. Unless you are willing to buy and build a real home theater setup, you should be very happy with this unit. UPDATE 12-31-09: The iPod dock does work. Finally realized that I needed to use the iPod button on the original remote to access it. The InputNext button on my Harmony One would not cycle to the iPod. Also, the USB interface did play music and photos from a USB drive fine, but as was mentioned by others will not play videos.

I really rely on user reviews when buying unfamiliar technology, so when I was tempted to by a cheap IR wireless headset, I started reading reviews. I quickly decided to go with RF instead of IR because I wanted to walk all over the house, outside, etc.

But there were tons of choices. The reviews kept taking me back to the Sennheiser RS-120, so I bought one. They are great!

They are comfortable to wear, and the sound quality is great. I can walk anywhere in the house or in my backyard or front yard, and there's no problem with reception.

What I really love is the way they stay charged. The headphones are equiped with rechargeable batteries, and when you drop the headset back in it's cradle, it charges automatically. Two hidden metal contact points in the headband automatically make contact with the metal points on the charger, so you don't have to plug them in. They are always ready.

Now my wife wants her own set.

We recently converted from a rear projection TV to a wall mount plasma and we bought these speakers to replace our floor standing units.  While I did not expect these speakers to do as well as my high end towers, I was pleasantly surprised by the sound quality.  While they don't sound as good as my old Image speakers, they are a close second and are a fraction of the cost.  The sound quality is improved by adding fiberglass insulation behind the speaker, but you may have to drive them a bit harder to get the same volume.  I also had some issues with the clips not spinning out, but realized this was because I test fit the speakers a couple of times (first to test the fit, secondly to add insulation).  I found that the problem is that the plastic clips get lose when you run the screw through them a couple of times.  A bit of Locktite (nail polish would also work) will hold the clip to the screw allowing it to spin into position.

But this Logitch mm22 is perfect for me. I was actually impressed by the sound. Like I said it is for the beach and sits on the blanket with us. Someone wrote that the cradle kept falling. Well don't use it! Just lay the Ipod next to it. You don't even have to fold the speakers up. Just leave them down. If you buy ipod speakers for looks or major entertaining, you're a fool. Buy some rechargable batteries and you are good to go. Enjoy
Just would like to say I am very impressed with the fast delivery and more impressed with the quility of the cable even though it's made in China. Whats not these day's!

I do a lot of instrumental music recording and performing, and I use these Sony rechargeables EXCLUSIVELY in my gear, the most power-hungry of which are my [[ASIN:B000VBH2IG Zoom H2 Handy Portable Stereo Recorder]] and my [[ASIN:B0015YG34M GigLight Compact LED Music Stand Light]]. I also use them in my [[ASIN:B000V1VG2E Canon PowerShot A720IS 8MP Digital Camera with 6x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom]] when going \\"optical\\" rather than \\"audible.\\"

I can EASILY record two hours of music on my H2 with two of these batteries at 44.1kHz, 16-bit. I have never even come close to their running out early, and I've never had the device quit because of a lack of power. And I have recharged these MANY times for MANY gigs.

Loading my GigLight with these, I have found I can run it OVERNIGHT -- even 24 hours! -- and not drain them completely.

Plus, the batteries last between 200-400 pictures in my Canon, depending on whether I'm using a lot of flash and whether or not I leave the AF on \\"continuous.\\" I'm never short of power. It's amazing.

Charge time is very reasonable, and when I use the H2, which uses only 2 batteries, I have a spare pair at the ready if I need them.

These leave Alkis in the dust! HIGHLY recommended -- and that's high praise because I'm generally NOT a Sony fan. But I am a fan of these!

I have tried many in ear headphones over the years, with varying success. Most of them have ended up breaking within a few months. Not these. Aside from being durable, they sound fantastic.  The bass response is very good, better than any other in ear headphones I have used. Excellent clear treble as well, I have never heard any distortion out of these headphones, and they can get surprisingly loud. Forget the pricier in ear phones, and buy these!

The sound is clear and reacted as expected to changes to the equalizer setting on the iPhone 6, which it is linked.  It is also linked to an iTouch, 3rd generation.  No issues at all.  The first full charge lasted about 9 hours of play time.  Great value!

I bought two pair for both my son's because we travel a lot and they can use them on there DS and also the screens that are in the car. Amazing quality. They are super clear and they adjust to both there heads perfectly. Would def recommend!
Awful sound quality, strange static and ringing noises regardless of what I plugged into it. Purchased two and both were malfunctioning. Didn't feel like it was worth the time to get my money back.
it worked like a charm on my Surface Pro Tablet. I have no complaints this is great for on the go plugging into a projector or into a nice big monitor at the office so I can have two screens!

I'm happy with the performance and it has already protected my Apple Mac Mini and LCD TV set up during a storm and during power outages.  My only beef is the display, which shows interesting information is impossible to read, except from directly in front of it.  Mine is on the shelf in the cabinet below the TV, flat on its back.  The only way to view the display is to pull it out with all the cords attached.    Other than that, it works great.
These sound like toy headphones, the cord is cheap, they are not particularly comfortable... no reason to buy these

Very compact design and you will need to read the instructions carefully to save stations because its not all that intuitive. Having said that, the radio delivers what it promises. HD FM radio.  HD radio is similar to HD TV- the signal is very strong or gone and if you scan stations in one location, they may not be available in another.    I rode the train with this radio and found it satisfactory in holding stations (with occasional loss of signal for a moment or two)and clear sound delivered through small earbuds.    There is no AM frequency, and the only way to charge the battery is by connecting to a PC unless you buy additional  accessories.
Product is too heavy to place on shirt, Magnet is hard to remove and the sound quality is really bad!
This didn't work to make my video camera start working again but I think there is something more seriously wrong with it and I need to take it in for repair.

My mother-in-law bought this for my 5-year-old son for Christmas.  It's a nice looking clock and sounds decent.  However, it is virtually unusable.  It has, I think, 7 cones on it for control buttons.  However, you have to use exactly two of them to set the time, the alarm time, the alarm on/off and the date.  I'm an engineer and it takes me time to figure out how to do it.  There's no way my 5-year-old can.  And for him, he'll just hit the cones and change something and then you have to reset everything.    Also, with the radio, it's not AM, only FM, despite the description.  And there are no presets or even an indicator of what channel you're on.  All you have is a Scan button.  Hope you don't miss the channel you were looking for.    This is just a very poorly designed clock.  It looks nice, but I can't imagine they let anyone try to use it before they put it in mass production.
i had a sony before this it worked great. i had to upgrade though when we bought a 3d tv. i was disapointed the remote would not work with other products that were not sony.
It works with no problems.
This product arrived quickly to my residence. It was not the correct piece of equipment. It matched the specs for my unit but did not have the corect end piece.  I had to order another product.

The audio quality of the Phiaton PS 20 NC is above average: full bass, clear midrange and slightly rolled-off treble. The overall sound is \\"warm\\". Using an equalizer to boost treble can restore some of the high frequencies. The large audio drivers may be uncomfortable for people with smaller ears.

I used a set of Comply foam tips to improve ear comfort for longer listening sessions. The Phiaton's active noise reduction does not function effectively. Jet and wind noise are very audible with or without the noise reduction engaged. Compared to the Audio Technica ATH-ANC23 earphones I had previously, the Phiaton PS 20 NC provide negligible ambient noise reduction on a jet airliner (McDonnell-Douglas DC9-50). I tried back-to-back comparisons in-flight with a set of Ultimate Ears UE700 passive earphones with Comply foam tips, and the UE700 earphones allowed significantly less noise leakage than the Phiatons. In a relatively quiet office environment, the Phiaton's provide a subtle reduction in background noise, but it is not worth paying a premium for this minor improvement.

These headphones are such a good price.  They are not the highest quality but for the price they are more than worth it.  If you like to have audio at a certain level (whether lower or higher than the other person you are watching tv with) then this product is worth your investment.

This new line of flash-based, coin-like (but they are thick coins, esp. in the waist!) MP3/ATRACT players from Sony are the latest models of their Psyc line of digital music players. The new-age styling of these MP3 players does psyc you out. Which is not a bad thing, as they are more euro-cool than the rather bland and boring iPod and the downright butt-ugly iRiver. The more I look at the Psyc, the more I like its looks.

The new silver Psyc MP3 player features 1GB of flash memory, which is great for those of you jogger jocks out there. You can shake this thing violently and it won't skip a beat, unlike those hard drive-based players. Before you insert an AAA battery, the Psyc weighs in at an amazingly light 0.9 oz. -- that's right, folks, it's less than an ounce! With the AAA battery, my guess is it's about 2 oz. It's very small although, relatively speaking, it looks a little thick -- esp. in the middle area where the single AAA battery resides. (About 0.75 in. at its thickest part.)

What, you ask, it uses an AAA battery? Yes my friend, and this one AAA alkaline battery can power the player up to 70 hours! That's almost three full days of continuous playing. The phrase \\"up to\\" here means that in order to get all 70 hours of playing, you must 1) play ATRAC3Plus songs encoded at 48kbps and 2) do not press buttons or do random play (i.e., just leave the player playing sequentially). In the real life we like to skip a song, fast forward, random play (a.k.a. shuffle play), turn it on and off and on and off, and most importantly, we play MP3 songs. All these operations reduce the battery life. Given my experience with previous Sony MP3 players, my estimate is one good AAA battery should last you 40 hours or more. (With my beloved Sony NW-HD3, I routinely get the advertised battery life of 30 hours even when playing MP3 files.)

Of course, the use of AAA means you get an abundant and ready supply of cheap power source, and you can trek in the Amazon for weeks on end without having to worry about finding an AC outlet.

The Psyc also comes in three other colors (green and blue for the 512MB version, and orange for the 256MB version). It has a nice, sharp backlit LCD screen, so you always know what you are playing as opposed to having to guess as on some other certain MP3 player. It plays MP3 as well as Sony's ATRAC songs. If you are an ATRAC fan you'll like the sound quality of this little player; it's at least as good as Sony's MD players. For MP3's, the sound quality is a bit \\"muffled\\" compared to my NW-HD3 20GB player, but still quite good if you pair it with a good pair of headphones (i.e., ditch the stock earphones).

Sony still has a long, long way to go in the user interface department, as this has always been its weakness, whether it's digital music or digital video or anything else. The Psyc is not hard to use; its basic functions are no-brainers. But, for anything beyond play/pause/skip, its interface, whether on the unit itself or on the PC transfer side, is still not polished and was clearly designed for a Japanese audience -- Japanese consumers reportedly love to play with complicated gadgets; no surprise given how elaborate sushi-making and origami are. We American consumers like things that are elegant and simple, and Sony has a lot of room for improvement in this regard.

In short, I don't think you'll be disappointed in the new Psyc flash-based MP3 players. They are stylish and lightweight and lasts forever on cheap AAA batteries. They have good sound quality and are priced right. Just be prepared to spend some time with the manual and experimenting a little with transfering music. If you are stuck, you are welcome to e-mail me at gadgester @t hotmail with your questions.

Purchased this cable to connect my PS3 to my receiver. Build quality is excellent. No problems at all. I would recommend this product to anybody needing a quality HDMI cable at a reasonable price. I would not hesitate to purchase other AmazonBasics products in the future.

The wife bought one of these over a year ago and absolutely loves it!  She also has the mouse pad.  Yes, they do stain after awhile, but, they sure help her when using the computer all day.  I give this five stars!!

I purchased these for my husband who wanted some high end head phones.  He tried to like them but they just did not work.  I used them to see what was wrong and thought they were more complicated than necessary.  For one they had to be charged prior to use.  I am not sure why as they could be used without charging but reportedly you get a better sound with charging, I could not tell the difference.  The control box attached is big and bulky and awkward if you are trying to listen to something on go you need to have a pocket to put this in and lastly the earpieces just did not fit snugly or stay in my ears despite changing the size of the tips.  I was very disappointed especially at this price point.

This is the most simple and most handy little do-dad i have ever seen! I love it! It makes is very easy to carry your headphones with you any where you go without having to untangle them when you get there. I highly recommend this little gem!

....& need to fix: Video quality. It's poor, static-prone & easily bumped by external factors such as mobile phones, computers etc.

The biggest problem i had with it tho' is the internal battery. Although rechargable, the charge lasts for less than two hours (not 2.2 as mentioned)---far shorter than most of the activities it's being used for.

Worse yet, the receiver only has a composite video output with stereo RCA audio jacks. Most TV's & especially monitors these days have HDMI as the standard. And as there are no adapters, you're going to have to hunt for an old fashioned TV to make this product work....

Purchased this to expand the number of optical inputs for a new sound bar and it works perfectly. Quick switching, low profile and makes my soundbar purchase that much sweeter. I didn't even know this type of product existed until I found it on Amazon. Been using it for 2 weeks and no problems

Easy to install. Strong connection. Small profile minimizes cable clutter behind an amp.

One word, awesome. If it was not for a small scuff, I would have thought it was new! The interior was very clean, no dust whatsoever. The tape head, capstan, pinch rollers all did not require any cleaning from me. All I did was insert a cassette, plug it to my speakers and listen to music so clear I almost cried. Just kidding. I bought these headphones to sacrifice their drivers for a sound isolating headphone mod, and thought that I'd give these a try.
At $14, these are ridiculously good for the money. They aren't Audio Technica M50s. However at 10% of the price, they don't have to be.

First, the weaknesses:
1. Look and feel cheap (they are cheap!)
2. No isolation (they're open headphones, duh!)
3. Not the richest, most airy, most resolving, or warmest headphones.
4. Cheap headband. Pinches the ears after 10 minutes of wear.

Strengths:
1. Very coherent. While the highs aren't the highest and the bass isn't the strongest, overall the package works very well. There's no overemphasis on any particular spectrum. (Eg. Grado trebles, Beats bass).
2. Nicely textured. Voices are nice and lively, textured.
3. Really cheap! Most headphones in this class are around 4x-7x more (Sennheiser PX100, Grado 60i).
4. Includes a gold plated 1/4 jack converter.
5. Cables are not microphonic.
It's 14 Ga wire, not much to say except it conducts electricity as expected.  And that's why I bought it.

USB ports failed upon receipt, not sure if I should give it a second try.
If you are lucky to get a good one, it should be an ideal solution for someone like me who owns iPad and another Samsung tablet.

What can you say about an HDMI cable? It carries signal from one point to another, but this cable made me say "wow" to myself when I took it out of the box. I was expecting a normal plastic-coated cable, but instead received a very nice flexible braided cable. It has a very nice tactile feel to it as a result, and looks great.

I bought this cable mainly because of price, but got a cable far better than expected. Very happy with BlueRigger, and I will definitely look for this brand again. The seller also had very fast shipping.

I originally purchased this item about 2 years ago and it has worked great for me since. I recently purchased a second one for a backup. I use it when sleeping at night to mask unwanted noises. The speakers are not too large for my ears - they fit fine as long as I use a soft pillow. I can imagine that using a harder pillow might be troublesome. The quality of the speakers are as I would expect and are very acceptable. The cord provided is not quite long enough for me to place my smart phone (which I use as the noise source) on my nightstand so I am using an extension cord. The only problem with the second purchase is that the headband seems smaller than the original and is very tight on my head.  It seems that the product is now being promoted as a sports headband and not for use while sleeping so maybe a tighter fitting headband is more appropriate?  Maybe it will stretch after some use, but it's definitely smaller than the original band I purchased.  If it weren not for the smaller headband I would have given the product 5 stars.

1- Pig tail antenna wire is 30\\" long and has to be plugged into headphone jack to have FM or TV reception though speaker. No reception except AM without wire. How would like a 30\\" wire sticking out of your cell phone or PDA wifi? Looks bad.

4- If Amazon allows me to return it I will.

Honest Review: This product is not perfect, but I couldn't swim without it. I was on swim team all throughout middle school and high school but stopped after graduation. I loved swimming but the process of getting in and out of the pool was a pain and you can't even listen to music. I recently started lap swimming again as my primary exercise. I heard about these waterproof headphones from a friend and I was pumped to try them. I read the reviews, I knew what I was getting into with all the complaints. My main issue is that water still gets in through the sealed ear buds even though I sized them correctly. I usually lose sound in one ear after 15 minutes of swimming. When they dry the sound does goes back to normal in both ear buds. I cannot do flip turns or backstroke without them falling out. I use them for my warm up, cool down and light-moderate freestyle. They do have a more cons than pros but I am so happy that I can listen to music while swimming that I will take it.

This is a sleek-looking, overpriced and poorly engineered MP3 player. I bought it because I really liked my Sansa e200, but wanted more than the 4G of storage I had (2G of built-in memory, plus a 2G micro SD expansion card). I should have gotten an 8G e200 instead of the \\"View 16\\".    The worst disappointment about this device is the short battery life. The manufacturer's claim of 32 hours of continuous music play time is sheer fantasy. I have never been able to get it to play more than 5-6 hours of MP3 without needing a charge. Moreover, charging is very slow. I had it plugged into the USB port of my PC at work for about 4 hours this morning (it had been nearly dead at the end of the day yesterday). I got maybe 2-3 hours of play, then it shut down and gave me a red battery icon when I tried to start it.     The controls are also considerably inferior to the Sansa e200. The e200 has buttons around the blue volume dial that do what you would expect them to do--like traverse a menu vertically or horizontally. The View has a weird rubber-like washer that you're supposed to turn in order to navigate the menu or change the volume. It gives no tactile feedback whatever. I had to draw a mark on the rubber \\"washer\\" to determine whether it was actually turning or not (yes, it does turn, but the effects appear to be completely random).     There are other bugs as well. For example, the display will often lag behind considerably; it will indicate that it is playing a song other than the one it is really playing...then suddenly it will update.     I'm giving it two stars because it DOES play MP3s. For a short time.   ------------------------  Update, 4 Sept 08    I still have this player, and am using it regularly at work to drown out the noise. (Yeah, and the voices...) Obviously, I'm not so dissatisfied that I returned this player. However, I still wish I'd bought the tried and true Sansa e-series instead.     The mechanical design of the View is actually pretty good--thoughI still hate the rubber washer that you're supposed to turn to choose menu options. The problem was and remains the firmware. I've updated to the latest version (the one released in June 08), and I think play time has improved by about 25%. It's still far short of the promised 35 hours, but it will do for my purposes.     However, the player continues to emit novel mutant behaviors. For example, the songs seem to multiply like bunnies. I'll select an artist or an album, and there will be about 8 to 10 entries for each of the songs that should be in the list. I'm sure the content hasn't actually been duplicated--I had about 20G of MP3s on there to begin with (have the 16G model with an 8G Micro SD card)--I think it's a database corruption issue. There's just numerous pointers to the same song. I have no idea how this happened--I've just been playing the music, and haven't downloaded new content via my PC. This is a major hassle, as I have to manually fast forward to the next song by skipping over the spurious entries. Putting the Sansa on random play means hearing the same songs over and over again, as it keeps finding the duplicate entries. Bah.
What can you say? It's cheap, 10 feet long, and it works well. It's well made, and doesn't feel like the cheapest HDMI cable on Amazon.
did the job
They work great! Held firm even through the rain!

Loud, sounds nice and was easy to connect to my wireless network. For the price it can't be beat. Glad I bought it The people dissing this speaker must be incompetent or clueless. It works great. Connection is easy, reconnection to a different wifi network is easy. Don't be fooled. It looks great, sounds great and is great. I love mine
These are great! Just like the reviews said they would be! Even my 13 year old daughter noticed the great sound quality as quickly as the first day she used them! :)
This item I purchased did not work, I had to buy another one from Frys much higher price but it worked.

I've been paying over $20 a month for basic cable and, by basic, I mean about 10 broadcast channels. I finally bought my first digital TV (great deal on the LG 32LK330 here at Amazon) and wanted to change that. I didn't have high hopes -- the skyscrapers in Manhattan are notorious for making reception akin to living at the bottom of a canyon and, while I live fairly near the Empire State Building, my apartment faces away from it.

My TV is on the wall furthest from the windows but I didn't want to invest in an extension cable until I knew if this antenna would work at all. I screwed it in, ran a scan and had 52 channels with PERFECT reception. (TVGuide says there are 56 digital channels in my area but I don't think I'm going to bother with an extension to try to get the other 4.)

The Mohu Leaf is giving me 5 times as many channels and will pay for itself it 6 weeks. I'm only sorry I can't give it more than 5 stars.
I ordered replacement pads from Bose and returned them because they wouldn't snap into place. They aren't as soft as the originals but I like them.

I suspect the manufacturer knows he is making a piece of junk but the very low price will entice buyers. I have many MP3 CDs, mostly books but also music. You can get 10 hours on one CD. But that system is dying and the good manufacturers have stopped producing MP3 CD players. My Supersonic never worked with an a/c adapter, and you had to bang it and repeatedly press the buttons to get it working. After I played a few disks it just died and nothing could get it to work. Luckily more good old MP# CD players have recently appeared on the market and I ordered a Panasonic. If you need one stick to Sony or Panasonic. Also, can anyone explain to me why a seller is selling a new  12-year-old Panasonic at an insane price? I mean who is dumb enough to buy it when good used ones are selling 10 times cheaper.

I don't really know what else to write here. If I just write that it is an excellent product, then readers will probably vote my review as unhelpful, as they would expect me to describe the reasons why I rate this product so. Well, for that they should just read the description given here on the product's Amazon.com web page; it is accurate. The iSkin I bought for my 80 GB iPod is of excellent quality and finish, and serves its purpose just as is claimed for it. In addition, I would also commend the company covercase.com which supplied it to me at Amazon's behest. The service was quick and packing good. These headphones provide great sound for the price, plus they're foldable, light, and pretty comfy. But the real reason the PortaPros get five stars is this: Koss stands behind their products. When a piece of plastic broke off my headphones (my own fault, really) I looked up my warranty and realized that I could get my headphones fixed for free. I was going to just buy the plastic piece and replace it myself, but Koss decided to send me a brand new pair in exchange for my old paid, plus pay for my return shipping. On top of that, Koss sent me the new version of the PortaPros.

Whenever anyone asks me what type of headphones to get, I always recommend Koss. Whether you want a cheap good pair, like these PortaPros, or a studio set, you can't beat Koss's customer service.

Now we have found this mini-alternative to work very well for a large patio, a section of the yard.  The battery life is as it says, about 3 hours. Instead, set them up as the main speakers in a 2-channel stereo setup. They rock! Simple as that. Yeah, \\"only\\" 60 Hz., but damned if it ain't an honest 60 Hz.!

These speakers are really excellent for their size. They will almost take pretty much all you can throw at them (their impedance is 8 ohms, and they'll handle up to 125W peak), and at slightly saner listening levels, they are sweet, solid, punchy, balanced, articulate, clear, and just plain fun to listen to!

Get a pair, and try them for yourself. Jazz, Rock, Classical, these really deliver. Dub? Hip-Hop? They only go down to 60 Hz.! Toss in a sub, and you'll be doing pretty good! Otherwise, turn up the bass a little bit (they're only 5\\" drivers), and let them take you away!

Solid build, and solid sound. In my opinion, you really can't go wrong with these speakers. They are that good!

Update:
As I've been listening to these speakers, I am realizing that I really don't need to turn up the bass in order to get a solid sound! Even at lower volume levels, levels where you might consider switching in the Loudness button, I find that when leaving the Loudness off, and leaving the tone controls set flat, the sound is still very full and balanced, and the bass is solid without being boomy or otherwise smearing the rest of the sound! And when turned up with the tone controls flat, the sound is balanced, solid, and punchy; the percussive nature of the music comes through naturally.

Listening to Beethoven's 5th Symphony, the second movement, the quiet Double Bass notes are deep, rich, detailed, and solid. Listening to Steely Dan's song, \\"Babylon Sisters,\\" the sound is percussive, deep, sparkly, and clean! Dave Brubeck's \\"Take 5\\" is detailed, and natural. The bass sounds woody, deep, and very clean, and the drums are sharp and solid, with clean, and detailed cymbal sounds!

I keep focusing on the bass, and the percussive nature of the sound because that's what usually gets compromised in a small speaker system. In my opinion these speakers are well designed, and well executed. They continue to amaze me!

I really have no way of testing the quality of this voltage regulator. All I know is that it's much bigger and heavier than I was expecting. I guess I didn't look at the specs closely enough.

For years I had an APC UPS. The only annoyance was the battery doesn't last more than a year or two, and it was expensive to replace (the shipping on it was expensive, too). However, it was a very smooth sailing for my computer, over those years. I think the most important thing you can do is buy a quality motherboard and then protect it with a good voltage regulator such as this one. My feeling is that if you don't, you might get that one power surge when you weren't paying attention and it will weaken the board to where you'll have periodic blue-screen problems from then on out for years to come. I certainly don't trust the standard surge protectors which can be bought at the department store.

I just did $600 worth of upgrades to my computer and I needed to protect my investment.
