Let me preface this review by saying I have just started using this new remote (RC71) after years of using the \\"regular\\" DirecTV remote (RC65 universal IR remote).

First off, the back of the remote is a hard plastic with no sort of grippy texture or rubber coating so it is quite slippery, especially when you're using the top portion of the remote, which includes all the buttons except the number pad. I don't watch much live TV these days. I record everything and watch it later which means I rarely use the number pad and my hand is almost always towards the top of the remote using the playback functions (guide,list, menu, play, pause, record, etc). Also, because of the design of this remote and the fact that I use the top half almost exclusively, I always feel like I'm about the drop the remote because of how small it is and how it balances in my hand.

Another thing that really irks me is there is no STOP button like the old remote had and like you'd expect to find on a remote control that is supposed to be used to play recorded shows and movies. I'll tell you how I used my old remote so you can see why this is a problem for me. lets say I'm watching a recorded show and I want to stop it because I want to finish it later or im in the mood to watch another recording. I should be able to press STOP but there isn't a STOP button. So now I have to either hit pause (so the show doesn't continue to advance) then either hit the EXIT button (which takes you out to live TV) or hit LIST button then find another show to watch and play it. I can just hit the EXIT button to take me out of the show but that brings me to live TV and not to the list with my recordings.

Yet another thing that ticks me off is I can't delete a recording that I'm currently watching without going into the list. With the Old remote and old DVR, I was able to just hit the delete button and the currently playing recording would delete. Now I have to go to my list, go downto the recording I want to delete and press the delete button to get rid of it. Why all the extra steps?

With all this said, I should mention that I just upgraded to the DirecTV Genie. Maybe some of these issues are related to how the Genie works and not the remote itself. Either way, this remote does not feel good in the hand.

E-ink displays do not require a back light in order to display an image, this results in a less stressful experience for your eyes. Also, e-ink displays are easier to view in sunlight, this device is perfect for anyone that wants to read outdoors and have a large volume of books at your finger tips. These displays only use power to update the image on the display. Once the image has been updated, the display no longer consumes precious battery life. Meaning this device can actually last weeks/months on a single charge. The draw back is due to the update once scheme, the device may feel a bit sluggish to people use to tablets. This device was only designed as a reading device, therefore a quick response time should not be an issue.

This device exceeded my expectations, easily copy and pasted my pdfs from my computer onto the device in a few mouse clicks. I would recommend this device to people who hate reading on LCD screens and prefer physical copies of books.

I bought this to replace an old iPod mini. The battery in this is incredible - I can go for weeks without charging it, and I use it at least five days a week.    You can definitely still use iTunes with this Walkman. It can play M4A files, which are what type of files are created by iTunes when you import a cd. If you buy music from the iTunes store, they will be M4P files (unless they are the new DRM-free format.) You can just burn your M4P files onto a cd and import the cd back into iTunes. You can open your iTunes music folder and drag and drop the songs onto your Walkman as though it were a memory stick. Very handy.

Bit short on battery life but that seems to be par for the course with mini amps in this class. Where the E6 still shines is in its low noise floor.  I generally use this class of amps with IEMs while on the road but o  I have compared this with the E3 and the newest Rocky and even with bass boosted I have a nearly silent background with the E6 and 16 Ohm IEMs.  The Rocky, in comparison, has quite a bit of noise that persists with 32ohm Grados with amplification and bass on. This may be a function of having bass boost, amplification, and a microphone circuit crammed in there. But, there you go.  If you don't need the mic and you don't have any particular preference for the controls (the E3 is significantly harder to manage in your pocket or such) the E3 seems to be the better package for pure listening. A solid worker at an acceptable price point, which seems to be the hallmark of Fiio.

This is one AWESOME MP3 player. It has so many features and the fact thats they are also easy to use makes it even better. I may have had it for a few hours, but that's all I (and most people) need to operate this player to it full extent. I have made a pros and cons list as well.

PROS:
MENU SYSTEM - This is GREAT! It's so easy to use because of the icons and the scoller button. One of those players that you could operate out of the box without the manual.

SIZE - It's VERY small for an MP3 player. I can't say it's an amazing size because I came from an Panason SV-SD80 (THAT player, by the way, is INCREDIBLY TINY! The size of a psotage stamp). But the size DEFINITELY pocketable.

SCREEN - It has a nice blue backlit screen. Some people says it's too small, but I don't think so. It displays the battery life, time elapsed, type of EQ (equalizer), and song name (NOT artist). The only showing the song name is a little bad, but it doesn't seem to bother me much. Technically, you DO get the see the artist's name because right before you select the song, it displays the file name. If you put the artist's name in the file name, you get the see it for a split second.

Accessories - It comes with Creative earbuds, a belt clip, and an armbamd. The earbuds are nice sounding, but they are so big and thick in my ears that it hurts them after 5 minutes. The belt clip is rubber, which does WONDERS to the plastic surface of the MuVo. It grips the player. Plus, the way the belt slip is designed, you must stick in the key ring side of the player, so the MuVo's keyring goes into the keyring hole. That way, the player cannot fall out. That was hard to explain; it's something that you must buy the player or see the belt clip in order to understand. The armbad is actually nice to use. Not hard to use and the player is VERY safe. To use the armband, you have to use it with the belt clip, even safer.

SOUND - The sound was GREAT when I first used it. Then it got even better when I setup my settings for the custom EQ. NOW it sounds AMAZING. Plus, now I can actually hear nice music coming from Sony Street style headphones (I couldn't before on my Panasonic)

TRANSFER - SOOOOOO FAST! The USB 2.0 is amanzing when it's on an MP3 player AND a thumb drive. I LOVE the drag and dropp ability of the Muvo. My panasonin had to use Realplayer to transfer the songs. ABSOLUTELY ANNOYING! Now I have no fustration. Drag and drop and I outta the house.

FM RADIO AND VOICE RECODER- GREAT I just autoscan for the radio station. I don't know how many presets it can save total, but when I autoscaned, I got 16. still impressive. I don't have picky ears, so the FM radio recorder was nice to have and listen to. Voice recoder is nice but not high quality. Can't expect much from an MP3 player.

PRICE - I think it is a plus because you get all these things all together in one packeage: MP3 player, Voice recoder, FM radio/recorder, and flash drive. Plus, the original 256 MB MuVo TX that had NO FM radio was more expensive than this one. Funny, huh?

CONS:
NOT RECHARGEABLE OUT OF THE BOX - It didn't come with rechargeble batteries. It was kind of sucky, but I cant juss buy either ALOT of AAA batties, or a rechargeble battery kit.

NO LANYARD - It didn't come with a neck strap. I kind of like those because if you don't want to use the belt clip or armband, but still hands free, a neck strap would be nice.

NO DISPLAY OF ARTIST'S NAME

SIZE - I had said that size was a PRO of the player, but it's also a CON. When you separate the player and the battery pack to plug in the player, you'll notice that the player will take up the space of 2 PORTS. Kind of annoying for some people since for me, I don't have that many USB peripherals. I'm just telling those people who DO have all USB ports filled and a USB HUB. Other than that,size is still a PRO

Memory - Although 256 MB is actually ALOT more than I expected, it would be nice to have a 512MB version or even a 1GB version of this AWESOME player. 256 MB is definitely plenty for the average user and even above the average user.

All and all, VERY nice player. When I rate this player, I have no doubt in my mind taht is deserves a 5.
good

If you're looking at these headphones, you must already know about head-fi. A good consumer would have read their reviews, and if you're like me, been terrified of the anemic low-end.

There is NO NEED TO FRET.

My primary pair of headphones before I picked these up were the Sony MDR-XB500 (XB for Xtra bass, bro). Transitioning between them does not make me feel a lack of bass. It is absolutely less dramatic bass response, but I don't feel like I'm missing anything. Bass tracks I fell in love with on my Sony's (Dead Man's Tetris by Flying Lotus is currently playing) sounds great and full, with clarity and articulation that doesn't need the "Xtra Bass" bloat.

AND THE SOUNDSTAGE! Good lord, these feel so enormous! The way things move feels effortless, and the sound envelops you like a blanket fresh from
The dryer.(that is NOT saying it's a warm can; imagery only)

These headphones are clear too! The texture of woodwinds comes across so exquisitely, i can feel the texture of the reed on my lips.

I had concerns about the treble reproduction on these headphones, and I will say the treble (the hanging ring of bells for example) can be a tad aggressive, but by no means a deal breaker. That agressiveness has been defining in certain tracks, showing me more of what I was there to see.

Lastly, I was concerned about the need of a headphone amp with these cans. While i'll still be buying an amp (little dot 1+) everything you've read has been experienced through my iPhone. I'm very excited to see how these will sound with an amp, but It's great knowing they're not lifeless without one!

As My first pair of audiophile quality headphones, I feel these are a great selection, but I was almost scared out of buying them after reading reviews on head-fi. I'm glad I went with my gut.

Too early to give a full review of the SR605, although I can say that set up has been very easy and so far DVD sound is quite good.  I like the automatic sound adjustment on first use.  My complaint, or question for anyone that might have ideas on how to resolve, is that it does not seem to work as passthrough for Xbox 360 using component output.  I hooked Xbox component output into SR605, HDMI output from SR605 to Aquos LCD TV.  No video image.  I wonder if this is due to XBOX outputting in 1080p, and SR605 converter having difficulty passing 1080p from component input to HDMI output.  Onkyo support site has no answer to this.  To resolve, I hooked Xbox component output directly to TV, but this means I have to switch TV input every time.  One of the big advantages of SR605 is that you use it as the input/output switch, theoretically not having to switch TV input to change sources.  Now for my, uh, kids (cough, cough) to play Xbox, we have to switch both SR605 and TV inputs.  Any solution to this, or is this just a SR605 flaw?

While I'm no big fan of typically over-priced and over-hyped Monster products, I'll readily concede that this beats any of the 9 or 10 other splitters I tried. I see comments here from users who say they can't see a difference with this product; my comment to them is that they need a better tv. I also noted one reviewer who somehow heard that this splitter can't be used with CATV (It can, and I've been using mine for over a year with my digital cable hookup). Advantages: less noise and grain than others I've used, and channels at the frequency band extremes look much better than my cable company's \\"free\\" piece of junk. Most notably, this splitter maintains excellent image contrast and has no visible chroma effects that I can see. Few splitters can manage all this. The only product I've tried that might beat this is a $[...] job whose brand I don't remember (probably because I ain't spending $[...] on a splitter, for any reason). Even if you're not crazy about Monster in general, you'll get your money's worth here. I'm using two in my setup with a CELabs booster amp.

This is an \\"old fashioned\\" dial and pointer radio, lacking all of the features of a modern digital set... no preset stations, poor indication of the actual frequency that is tuned, no clock, no alarm. Somehow, it is still great fun to use!

Band scanning has been a weak point of digital radios... the sound is usually muted while slewing through the frequency range, leaving just a tuning indicator light to show that a station has been found (most will not stop scanning on weak signals), or if not muted, a loud \\"chuffing\\" noise is produced as the frequencies are scanned. With this set you just turn the knob and listen for stations!

If you want to easily find, say the BBC on 5.975 Mhz a digital radio will get you there much faster, but for scanning the band to see what is on, the old dial and pointer still works quite well!

For a similar but smaller and slightly less expensive radio, see my review of the Kaito WRX911. For a more expensive radio with \\"Double Conversion\\", which eliminates \\"false signals\\" on shortwave, see my review of the Kaito KA1107.

Six years ago when I got my first iPod I discovered that the standard ear buds would not fit my ears.  It wasn't that they were uncomfortable; they would NOT physically even fit in my tiny ears.  If I tried to put them in they would actively \\"pop\\" (not just fall) out.  At the time I ordered a second set of ear buds from Apple -- these had three sets of padding in various sizes.  I thought surely the smallest size would work, but they did not.  I then searched for reviews of ear buds that would accommodate tiny ears, but to no avail.  I tried ordering a few other brands, but never had any luck.  I settled for some large, noise-cancelling headphones and just gave up my quest for a smaller solution.    I had concluded that my ears are just absurdly small and I was out of luck.  However, I recently renewed my search and found a couple of helpful lists of the \\"best\\" ear buds for small ears (notably an excellent one from CNET: [...]).  I ordered two pairs: this brand and a JVC Marshmallow set that were both reviewed in the CNET article.  While I was prepared to be happy with the cheaper JVC set, I was glad I ordered both sets as these Thinksound Rain headphones had a much wider range of small tip sizes.  The JVC set, which had several positive reviews about being suitable for small ears, were not nearly small enough for me.  However, I could actually use the second smallest Thinksound Rain earpiece set!  It's a miracle!  If you are looking for ear buds with a range of options for truly tiny ears, these are terrific.

This item costs way too much for its sound quality but as my description says does its job. I really recommend you try these for yourself before you buy as peoples ears for music vary wildly.   They are way smaller than pictured.  They realistically should be in the $99-125 range

I was very excited when I first heard of this product. However, it didn't really met my expectations. After a half year of usage it's now resting on the bottom of the closet. It's quite OK, although the setup is a bit complicated.

There are three reasons why I wouldn't recommend it:
1. It's just a device that wakes you up at the time you set. I can't even remember myself using some of the other features. Not to mention, it's a bit uncomfortable wearing such device on your hand when you go to sleep.
2. You can't really use it for polyphasic sleep. It will always tell you that you didn't sleep enough, because it doesn't accumulate the time you spend sleeping during the day.
3. Considering what I wrote above, it's a VERY expensive alarm clock.

Pros:
1. Good for long distance running as they sit in your ear and need adjustments only a few times during the run.
2. The memory wire is very helpful and holds the earpiece in place with minimal irritation or creating any pressure on your ears

Cons:
1. The \\"with Microphone/Remote\\" may lead customers o believe that it has remote volume control, which it does not. That is why I give it 3 stars. The seller should come clean and make it clear in the technical summary on the top that it does NOT have remote volume control.
2. The headset inserted for a good fit gives you good sound and bass but if you are running it also creates a thumping feeling with every step you take. That will negate the advantage of \\"quiet listening\\" and will make any runner to loosen the inserts a little bit. I do not have any other comparable in the ear headset that I can compare it to.

I love this little guy, I love this MP3 player so much I've replaced it three times. But after today I realized that I need to find a new brand or model. I have had similar issues with all three, but the first lasted much longer, and the one I have now is already crapping out on me after a few months. One consistent issue is the headphone jack somehow becomes damaged and will only play music on either just the left side or just the right side of the headphone. If I fiddle with it it will play in both ears for a few minutes, but the time and attention it takes to have the music play in both ears continuously is not worth it. The player also freezes and other times will not turn on unless you press down the On button for several seconds.

If you're looking for something that will last a couple of years, this MP3 player is not it.

I can see the point of a tool like this, and I suppose if I didn't have access to my [[ASIN:B003L1ZYYM AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable (6.5 Feet/2.0 Meters)]] and a couple of adapters for my various Apple devices, I'd have tried harder to make it work. But since I do, the problems and disappointing performance of this Media Fusion TV Dock means it went right back in the box.

I have an HD TV and, while not huge in relative terms, it was big enough to make the poor-quality graphics of the Nyrius display painful to look at. I would comment on the quality of the video reproduction, but none of the four video podcasts I tried to play showed up on screen -- audio yes, video no, and although I have 10 movies stored on my iPhone at the moment, this dock couldn't locate any of them (I question whether this dock is fully compatible with iOS 5). I could have tried showing photos on screen, but to get to the photo display, you have to manipulate the iPhone yourself via the touchscreen, which kind of defeats the purpose of having a remote.

Music playback was fine. It would have been nice if the Nyrius showed album art on screen, but it doesn't.

I know using a cable is still a step or two below wireless playback with AirPlay and/or an Apple TV. But until I get there, I will stick with my HDMI cable. It works a lot better for me than this product did.

Based on the number of positive reviews, my experience may be somewhat of an outlier. I purchased the BTS via the Kickstarter campaign and received the unit in July. The unit arrived undamaged and partially charged. After getting it paired with my iPhone, I played some music off Pandora and noticed that the sound was distorted. Additionally, when the battery went low the speaker's voice began giving me the "charge me" indication. I plugged the unit in and, after being plugged in for quite some time, the "charge me" indication continued. Eventually, the battery died, while plugged in. I contacted Outdoor Tech and they sent me another charging cable/transformer. The new cable cured the charging problem. However, the biggest problem was the issue of the terribly distorted audio quality. The distortion manifests itself in a high(er) frequency buzzing/rattling sound as music is being played. I'm assuming that the speaker driver is either loose or defective or there is an issue with the enclosure. I appreciate high quality sound and happen to notice poor audio quality quite easily, my wife does not and yet she commented on the poor audio quality. I contacted Outdoor Tech again and they sent me a return authorization form. Due to my frustration with the unit (and the serious let down after FINALLY receiving the unit) I put it in a drawer and never sent it back. I just sent an email to Outdoor Tech to see if they will still rectify the situation and will update this review once I see how they will handle it. It is somewhat frustrating when a mail/web order item is defective considering the pain and inconvenience it is to deal with the RMA system and then, again, WAIT for a unit that hopefully does what it is advertised to do.

The remote arrived without any instructions.  You need to press each button and figure out for yourself its fucntion, it's a PITA but the remote itself works great even from a distance of over 20 feet.  Installation was quick and easy, just plug into USB and it works.

Generally regarded as the best media available, it certainly has lived up to expectations..no coasters, smooth burns and looking forward to long life data and video integrity. Buy with confidence, this media is well worth the 20-30% premium over cheaper, lower quality media. The top side is printable (we use Memorex 300-pack labels instead) and the bottom side dye color is on the dark side, which is good (not as dark as BD-25 blanks, but that is to be expected). The clear, plastic center-portion is blank, which is awesome and classy..never did like seeing brand names or media type printed there.

We got this because our farm truck's (a ford f250hd) CD player went south. Since then, we've used it without fail. The Walkman has bounced off the front seat numerous times as the two of us are listening to e-Books, and never skipped a syllable! We're able to resume from where we left off by virtue of the fact we just don't remove the CD until we're ready to start listening again. I'm guessing there's a flash-mem which retains the current track position. Nonetheless, the Walkman is built sturdy and works well. And when we switch to the town car, we're still able to keep following the latest e-Book we have, right from where we let off. We love it!

I've always been a Sennheiser fan but I also own about 20 different earbuds/headsets across 10 different brands. The quest for the perfect earbuds for running has ended. At the same time, the quests for the perfect earbuds for the plane, at work, and just about anything else have also ended. These MEElectronics M6 earbuds are amazing! After listening to them, I would pay $100 if that was the going price.

PROS
- Fits perfectly out of the box (six pairs of ear pieces to ensure find one that you can get a tight seal with)
- Very good highs, mids, and lows -- if you can't hear/feel the bass, then try a different ear piece to get that seal
- Amazingly comfortable even though this is deep in my ear canal
- Does not move at all during running; I can turn my head, do jumping jacks, etc... they stay in place
- Isolates from other noises -- no active noise cancelling but it will block noise, including your own voice when you speak
- Cord management is well thought-out; not only does it have a clip but it also has tightener where the left/right wires come together

CONS
- Since a tight seal is necessary, I can hear the sound of the cords rubbing against my body when I'm running; in order to minimize that, I need to hang the cord in the front and not the back

OVERALL
I really wish I bought these sooner. I'm glad I found a set of earbuds that are no longer 'just good enough' but actually motivates me to put them on and go for a run! The best $20 I've ever spent.
I connected my pc to the TV with this and it works great.

I purchased this device to replace three remotes and most importantly the remote provided for the DVR by my cable provider.  The remote for the DVR also controls the TV and thus is the primary remote.  However, its keys are difficult to push and my thumb was starting to get sore with use.  I chose this remote because reviewers indicated it was reliable, sturdy and flexible.      I agree that this remote is sturdy.  You drop it and it keeps on working.  The keys are easy to push with my thumb or fingers and minimal resistance.  The side keys are a little small and not as convenient as the larger keys that control most of the functions.  The side keys control up/dn for volume and channels, and certain functions of playback.  They are OK once you adapt to the remote.    The instructions are minimal in the print form but they are provided as a type of help function when you program the remote. It took me about 30 minutes to read the instructions and learn the basic programming method.  My wife would never have figured it out.  You need some technological sense to program it.  Once you figure it out, then it becomes fairly easy to do.  I was able to program it easily for my DVR (cable) and TV. The DVR box was Magnavox and the TV Panasonic.  My DVD player is Panasonic would not accept a code number so I had to program it button by button.  That is not fun and it is not as flexible.  I programmed it to turn on the DVD but then I use the controls of the DVD to play, etc, as the button by button controls are not as flexible or intuitive.  If all the devices had been  programmed by using a code number I would have given it a 5 star. Even though I was not able to program the DVD I give it a 4 star because it is reliable and controls properly the DVR and TV, which I mostly used.  If someone is challenged by technology I would not recommend it unless you have someone in the house who could set it up for you or trouble shoot it.

I think the relatively high price for these requires the product be a premium product. Unfortunately it is not. Although the sound quality is great (really), and the tubes are the longest I've seen (best EMF exposure reduction from user), and the comfort is fantastic (triple-flanged rubber ear-inserts)...the sad part is that it malfunctioned only a few weeks after pruchase, and I hardly used it all (maybe 50 times). Currently I can hear the other person, but they can't hear me. Probably a break in one of the wires somewhere. Also: one of the triple-flanged ear inserts split and now doesn't attach anymore. I can't figure out how to contact the seller as Amazon says it's no longer eligible for a return.

P.S. I also bought the \\"Natural Health Alternatives Black Hollow Air Tube Anti-Radiation Headset Stereo Model Emf Protector\\" at the exact same time as a backup (thankfully) and it works well. It also has good sound-quality (almost as good as Smart&Safe), but is only half as comfortable, and the tubes aren't as long (less EMF reduction to user). Oddly, it's unfortunately REALLY loud, such that phone calls actually hurt my ears, even with the phone volume turned ALL the way down. I don't remember having this excessive volume problem with the Smart&Safe. I recall that the volume was just right.

If they can improve the quality on the Smart&Safe, it would be nearly perfect (needs its own volume control though). Unfortunately, it's way overpriced for something that only lasts a few weeks.

Like the title says, I'm concurrently on my third pair. The first pair (purchased in late 2009) had a design defect in the headphonejack that broke the wires on the inside after about a years worth of use. A short email later I got a RMA number, returned the old broken pair and within about 2 weeks was sent what I'm assuming were a refurbished pair that had a redesigned headphone jack. These in turn worked great for a few months until they too stopped working. These also had a problem with the headphone jack, this time a material defect. A bit of exposed wire in the jack caused the sound to cut in and out. A short email later I was given another RMA number and sent a pair of BRAND new buds. So with all of tht in mind, how can I give these buds a five star rating?...  Well tbw, they sound incredible! These are some seriously nice earbuds. The mids sound great, and unlike most contemporary buds the bass won't drown everything else out (not that there's anything wrong with the bass on these btw). These are some incredibly well balanced buds. They also drown out most ambient sound when in. I love the matte finish, and their inconspicuous design! They also come with a handy clip you can use to attach them to your shirt so they don't flap around when worn (that I broke after a while that they replaced for FREE!), have an inline mic, and Controls that work with almost any Android phone! As a Android user awash in a sea full of iOnly compatible accessories I can't tell you how refreshing it is to have accessory that's fully compatible with my phone of choice!  So, in addition to some awesome sounding and looking buds (as evidenced by the countless other reviews I'm sure), the real killer feature that sets these these buds apart from any other in the same price range is the company that stands behind them. What other company would go to the lengths they did to honor their product like they did almost two years after my initial purchase? Not many I'm guessing, and that's whywhenever I need a new pair sometime in the future they'll be Etymotics.

The sound on these doesn't blow me away but is fine for outdoor patio use.  They can get plenty loud and the price was definitely a good deal.  I only really have had two issues thus far.      First of all, if you plan on mounting these any way but straight off a wall, plan on purchasing additional mounting hardware.  The instructions mention some sort of 'mega' bracket, which is a joke.  I scoured the net and found others baffled by this phantom mounting device.  Yamaha is doing a disservice to it's customers by even printing this in the enclosed documentation.  I needed to mount these on the patio ceiling but did end up finding a great bracket that is sturdy and has quite a bit of flexibility.  The bracket is item number 10776 from a1components.com.  I'm sure you can find it elsewhere but it is very sturdy, made of metal and not plastic.  Best of all it was only $13 per bracket.  It did the trick for ceiling mounting.    The other issue is the grills just fall off.  After only about two weeks outside, the grills just dropped right off.  I live in Texas but the speakers are completely out of the sun.  I had to strap rubber bands around the speaker bodies to keep the grills on.  It's not attractive but seems to work.  It seems like a better design would include a simple clip in of the grills instead of using glue.  The Yamaha engineers must not have tested the glue above 80 degrees F.

Works great with the wall mount speakers I bought. This item came double boxed and was shipped out very quickly. Very happy with this one.

Overall Impression

I just picked one of these up based on the reviews on Amazon as well as a few reviews on here. And while I is a dual purpose integrated hybrid/tube amp and headphone amp, this amp really earns its money as the integrated amp. It does the headphone thing pretty good, but I have to be honest. I can not say that it is better than a properly configured Asus STX's headphone out, but its only marginally more expensive than the soundcard. But, I do not think I would be doing this thing justice without talking about its speaker driving abilities as an integrated amp. As an amplifier, most will rule it out due to its limited specs of 16.5 watts @ 8 ohms.Well, I have to say this things sounds better than two of my $800 Integrateds (NAD and Sony ES). If you have somewhat efficient speakers and not trying to fill a large room, this thing will drive speakers to loud but enjoyable volumes with ease. This is perfect for an office or bedroom. This thing has a tremendous soundstage and plenty of low end grunt, without sounding bloated for exaggerated, even through bookshelf speakers, Even with a flat eq setting on the STX, it sound full an balanced with the right amount of glassy sparkle with a touch of midrange complexity.

Tubes

These take 6N3 or equivalents. As for tube rolling, I feel a lot of people get caught up into it so much that they hear things based more on expectations than reality. Judging tubes is one thing that I feel I am more experienced in than a lot of people, as I've not only been using them for 30 years, I've also done a lot of tube amp repair work, as well as some building and modification for professional musicians. Although most of my experience is on the guitar amp side, I can assure you that guitarists are just as picky as audiophiles. I started out with the stock Chinese tubes, which appear to be Shuguang. I also bout about 4 sets of GE 5670W's. The thing people miss about tubes is that the tolerance for any manufacturer is all over the map. The output on one tube from the same maker can be up to 30% from the next tube of the line. If you have a tested or a reliable vendor that measures and tests tubes, I contend that a cheap tube that is strong and within spec with sound nearly as good as the expensive tube within the same specs. No guarantee just because its more expensive it will sound better. The other point I would like to make is that most designers design around evaluations done with a specific tube. So, they tweak according to what they are hearing with a specific tube. In my case I think the stock tube sounds better than the GE tubes. The GE tubes sound as if they have more gain, resulting in a little more boomy sound, but the stock tubes sound more natural to me. Both tubes have pretty small plates and seem quiet and free from microphonics.

Conclusion

I highly recommend this amp for a study or bedrooms. It's simple looks cool and sounds like an amp 3 times its price. I promise you that you will be surprised the sound that comes from this thing. As for the headphone amp, I think this may be overkill for just that. I rate is a very good, but not OMG good.

everything worked just fine and came on time. they are just what I needed to complete my setup. We use them to patch cell phones into a sound system or for attaching video equipment to portable video set ups.

I have had these headphones for over a year after I tried out about 2 other pairs from different brands, both of which either sounded muddy or tinny. These headphones have clear sound and satisfying bass, for the price you really cant complain. I paid almost $30 for these at Circuit City and I would do it again. I take them with me everywhere and use them with my laptop, DS and portable DVD player. I listen to all sorts of music, everything from metal to dubstep and I dont have any complaints with how these deliver the sound. For sure they are the best in this price range, period. My only complaint is they do get uncomfortable, I wear them for hours on end occasionally (gaming or listening to tons of music) and when I take them off my ears really ache and are kinda numb. They lack good cushioning. Also, as some of the other reviews have mentioned, they do tend to move around a bit on your ears and can affect the sound but just a quick reajustment and they are back in full. I would recommend these headphones to anyone that casually listenens to music or just wants to watch some Youtube vids. If your gonna be wearing them for more than an hour or so then you will need to give your ears a break for a few minutes every now and then. The bottom line: for the price you cant beat them, love the sound, they are tough, look good and as long as you give your ears a rest occasionally they will be fine.
Great little speaker. Its nice and loud and I gave it 4 only because it vibrates on louder settings making it kind of distorted. I still love it and use it all the time.

These are simple 2-way design with a 4" midrange and 1" soft some tweeter. These are a great example of what can happen when you take two modest components and execute the design with well chosen crossover points and enclosure design. You get a great sounding speaker with a surprising response in the low end, warm, detailed midrange and a clean upper register that after 4hrs did not produce a hint of fatigue that often plague the listener with lower end speakers. I was convinced that I would need to turn on the powered sub to round out the sound stage, but to my surprise this wasn't absolutely necessary with jazz, acoustic rock and blues. I'm not saying these speakers will produce tons of bass, but their well designed ported enclosure allows a much fuller low to midrange transition than a lot fo speakers I've demo'd that, despite significantly higher cost, are lost without the help of a subwoofer. So it's IMHO, that I would say these are the best bookshelf speakers I have heard in the sub $50 category. I've seen them at local big big stores with their "promo codes" in the sub $40 region and for that they are an absolute steal.

One of the selling features of the Audio-Technica (AT) headphone series is that the ear pads are replaceable.  I suspect there are many users that considered that a "nice-to-have" feature, but not something they would ever cash in on.  This particular set of headphones advertised flat response (fs).  Accordingly they replaced a more expensive set of DJ headphones I had been using for pleasure listening since DJ headphones usually emphasize the bass.  With the flat response of these ATH-M40fs, I have been able to use them for rough mixes.  So much so, that (even with an acoustically imperfect room), I have figured out how to mix with these--and then afterward have developed a consistent tweak of the EQ for the masters.  These headphones allow one to do rough to nearly final mixes (final mix with studio speakers, of course).  Consequently, after considerable studio hours, the material covering the earpads started to disintegrate.  How great not to have to replace the whole shootin' match when the headphones themselves are still kickin'!  This set of headphones (and the replaceable earpads) are definitely one of my best studio purchases!

I was provided with a free copy of this item for testing and my fair and honest evaluation.  Of course receiving something for free may impact any review, but I can honestly say this is a solid product and worth the cost listed here.  I have delayed my review a bit simply because I wanted to see if I would actually use and benefit from this Speaker.  It has served its purpose on several occasions.  I have used it in my office both as a charger and speaker.  Packaging -  shipped in solid packaging that was padded well, there is no way this should be damaged in shipping.  Comes with the charging cable and a cloth bag for carrying and keeping from dust.  Ease of setup - Charged it for the recommended time of two hours and easily got 8-10 hours of use before recharging.  Powered up and started the pairing process, which connected without a hitch on the first try.  Have not had any issues connecting via bluetooth at any point.  I have not figured out the NFC option, but I am confident that is user error, and not really necessary.  Buttons/Features - Has power, phone, play/pause, and volume or track buttons.  I will say that everything works as advertised, but remembering the button combination to make things work takes a little bit of a learning curve.  It is as simple as pressing or long pressing combinations, but if I had a complaint, I wish that I didnt have to think before pressing, but not a deal breaker.  I like the ability to answer my phone while listening to music.  This comes in handy when at the office and having hands free talking that seems to be clear enough.  The sound through the speaker for calls is plenty clear, and nobody has complained when I have used this method to talk with them.  Sound Quality - This is not a surround sound experience, and sound at maximum volumes isn't as rich as a high dollar audio system.  (I have edited this portion of the review)  The speaker is surprisingly loud, and I have yet to have a need to turn the sound all the way upother than for testing.  All of my testing has been done with an LG G3 phone connected to the speaker, and a Asus Chromebook.  I would rate the sound quality a 4 of 5 considering the size and a 3 - 5 if I was just rating pure sound quality regardless of price.  I think it is important to consider what you are using.  If I wanted a high dollar sound system, I would not be buying this device.  For the market of portable bluetooth speakers I would say the sound quality is very good.  Use as a Power Bank - I think this is probably the feature that has me most interested in buying a second unit.  When at my office, my desk is small and the compact speaker size is great, add the sound from that compact space and the device is solid.  Add to it that I can give my phone a fast charge when needed is a nice bonus.  The manual also claims that you can connect more than one speaker together.  I have a feeling I will be buying a second speaker to keep at home so this one can stay at my office.  I will test this out and edit the review if I do end up buying a second one.  I also will get a video review posted as time allows and after using it for a little longer.  Overall, this is a quality device.  I have bought a few other Sharkk products and so far I have not had any issues with their products.  If you are looking for a speaker that is compact, practical, and provides powerful sound this is a worthy option.  I use in a small office and a large living room and the sound fills the room well.

First I have to say that I am in Wow land. This Zune HD interface was designed to make discovering music fun. Swipe your finger tip up and down to scroll the text menu up and down. Select music, and tap into your favorite playlist. Tap play and start playing the playlist. Okay, easy enough but it gets very fun, read ahead see what I mean.

Swipe down to the Radio. Add stations. If you hear a song you like, on the radio, add it to your cart. That's right, add a song you head on the RADIO to your cart. Hit the home button on the bottom to quickly escape the radio. Swipe down to Marketplace, select Cart, and the song you heard on the radio is in the cart. Download it and add it to your permanent collection.

It get better. You can do this wirelessly because of the built in WiFi. Now, Sync your Zune HD wirelessly back to the PC to push the song you just downloaded to your PC. How awesome is that. Your Zune Pass Subscription means you can grab all the songs you want.

Now, it gets even better.

On your Zune HD, go to the Marketplace, and start to tap on songs. You can play them through your wireless WiFi. Okay? Songs you don't even have, you can play right off the market place via WiFi. Think about that for second. If you are home and on your WiFi network, you can listen to any of millions of songs, without downloading them!!

Okay, say you find one you really like. Download it. It's all part of your Zune Pass.

I have not even scratched the surface.

QuickPick

That text menu on the home screen? It's one of two menus on the home screen. Swipe to the left on that text. See how there is this small strip of icons on the left side. They become in focus and the large text shrinks off to the right. Now, this little list of icons is huge. Swipe up and down and cruise through the history of the songs you have been playing. Even the radio station you set is here in this history. This strip also contains a QuickPick. So what is a QuickPick?

Say you are listening to song and you love it. You just found it on Marketplace and you want to listen to it over and over again until you're tired of it. How to find it easily? Well, tap and hold the album icon while the song is playing. A prompt window will appear and offer to pin the song into QuickPicks.

As you explore for music on the radio or the Marketplace, completely wireless, you can easily find those songs again via the QuickPicks or History. That's what that little strip of icons are on the left side of the home screen. Fantastic huh?

More fun stuff

So I am listening to song and I see the album cover on the display. Tap that screen, and the album dims. A new dimension of menu overlays the album. It's a control surface. You see pause / play in the center. Up and Down are volume up and down. Left and Right are skip left or right. The upper top is to go back. Ignore it for second and it goes away returning the album art to view.

The album / song you're playing has a small list under it. That's the songs coming up next! Tap on that little list and your in the list that this song comes from. You can now easily switch to other songs in this list.

All of these menus and animated and fluid. It's actually fun to run around within this interface discovering music, adding it to quick picks and retrieving it. It's almost like a dance.

Subscription music with the Zune Pass is such a great idea. And it really works with a device like this. Imagine all the ways to discover music, but keep the cost of enjoying all that music to a minimum. That's what the Zune accomplishes.

There is so much more. Audible Books works with this. Though you do have to download Audible's Download Manager. I've listened to well over 200 books over the life of my Audible subscription.

The Zune Marketplace software for the PC almost mirrors the features ofthe phone in that you can see your quick picks. You have a dashboard that shows you what's going on in your music world. And it gets this information from the device as well. As you add music, the whole ego system gets smarter and exposes you to more music you'll probably like. Absolutely fantastic.

Think about it. You can add hundreds of songs a month if you like. Listen to them via radio, and download what you like. Listen live off the Marketplace from your PC or even your Zune portable. What ever you do with the Zune HD will sync back to the PC. In fact, there's more!! I know huh....

So you have Zune software on your office PC too, okay... Listen to this. Go to Settings, Account, Subscription History. Remember, do this on your office PC, not your home PC so you really understand what's about to happen. Those songs you found on the radio, added to cart, and downloaded from the Marketplace are here in this history list even though this office PC had nothing to do with that. It's connected to your account so it knows. And you can, from your work PC, now download those songs to your work PC collection. It's subscription! You can have multiple PCs all connected to your account and they each aware of a collective history of subscribed to music. You don't have to carry songs with you on a thumb drive from your home PC to your office PC. Just let the Zune software show you the history. It tells you what is in your collection on that machine and what is not so you can update your office PC with those great songs you found on the radio or in the marketplace.

Hey, do you like Tina Fey's 3rd rock? I sure do. You can download those TV shows as video and watch them on the Zune HD. They have movies too. For rent in SD and HD. I'm watching 21 grams.

I have all the free games microsoft added to the apps section. By the way, you can download these from WiFi direct to the device! I've been playing Texas Hold'em.

With WiFi, you can use the built in browser to browse web sites. I have The Wall Street Journal, Engadget, PCWorld and several other favorites sites programmed into mine.

So, absolutely the best music experience you're ever going to have, because you won't have to worry about money while you download your ears off. Get the Zune Pass and just go crazy. Play games if you like that. Watch TV shows, movies, and music videos. Add your own photos too! Listen to Audible Books. I'm listening to the new John Twelve Hawks 3rd in the-part series of the 4th realm trilogy called The Golden City. Book one is The Traveler. You're missing out if you've never heard of it. I am also listening to Dan Brown's sequel The Lost Symbol. And actually, a Gunslinger / Dark Tower Stephen King book as well. Too much good stuff all came at once and I had to.

On the radio station I added, I found Black Eyed Peas - I Gotta Feeling. Oh I love this song! Also just found Cassie - Let's Get Crazy. It's amazing all that you can explore and find when you pay a flat rate and can go nuts like this. I'm in music nirvana.

This is so much better than any iPod / pay as you go eco system I've had in the past. I'm giddy and had to share. I'm bobbing my head to the beat of I Gotta Feeling. The bass is great! Oh that reminds me. The music quality is absolutely here!! If you saw me listening to my Zune, you'd know I was having a good time.

Okay, so enough. I have music to dance around to now.

We've purchased many Zen products over the years and we like the small size and usebility of this model.  The battery life is ridiculously long, MUCH better than the larger Zen M's but that's good because the only way to charge this little one is thru the USB (unless you purchase the charger extra I think).    Zen's have been good products for us in general but they definitely have a shelf life.  We don't handle them rough but accidents do happen so maybe it's that they've been dropped a certain way but each one just suddenly has stopped working at one point and it's been futile to troubleshoot it or reinstall the firmware.  It's been frustrating and we are hopeful the Mosaics will last longer than the M's.    We are not big users of the firmware for creating playlists and we would probably have an easier time if we learned how to use the software more effectively.  But that's our own fault, not Creative's.    My recommendation is that if you can get away with the smaller GB model like this 4gb Mosaic, the price and all it's other positive features makes it the perfect little Mp3.  Would definitely buy another one if we were looking.

I was excited to get these speakers and planned to add them to my system as a pair of back speakers to complement to two studio monitors and mid-size two-way speakers from Acoustic Research. I planned to drive them through my vintage Pioneer integrated amp.

With all the power needed, I hooked up the speakers. They are very easy to connect - either with plain wire ends or connectors, simply thread the finger-nuts down tight and the speakers are connected with color-coded terminals.

The front grills remove easily and snap back on positively.

The black cabinets will go well with most systems.

In short a good looking speaker that's easy to connect, and small enough to place in a number of locations.

I turned on my amp and started playing a favorite CD. I'm sorry to say that the speakers were not pleasing to my ears. Keep in mind that speaker \\"sound\\" is subjective. I have Infinity Reference series speakers in my cars, Acoustic Research studio monitors in my house (the old \\"real\\" AR speakers), and Bose system for the \\"good\\" TV in the family room. The sound I like is no doubt tied to my habit of listening to these speakers.

I found the JBL Balboa to be hollow sounding. While crisp and clean, they are overly loud in the mid-range. The bass wasn't as solid as my other speakers.

These are good speakers for low volume-level listening and would probably work as an element in a low- or mid-level surround-sound system as speakers for secondary sound. But placed in the middle of a high-end stereo system they were out of place. They're a good value for the price but don't expect to \\"Wow\\" anyone with them.

I don't know if I am missing something and reading manual doesn't help. I am still happy with it on use with a smartphone but wish that connection to the pc still works.
This case was actually better than the one offer by Bose at a fraction of the cost.

It took some planning and measuring and the use of a stud finder was very helpful. Mine came with instructions only for concrete/brick walls. If you're application is into regular study/drywall rooms then here's your guide:

Step 1: use stud finder to find edges of studs and mark them.
Step 2: measure for desired height of tv/mount and mark holes for lag screws (6 inches apart (center to center) top to bottom)
Step 3: mark holes for third (and/or 4th) screws on each arm of mount. note these will not go into a stud...read on:
Step 4: use toggle anchors or I recommend using Cobra Driller Toggle drywall anchors for securing extra bolts in drywall applications
Step 5: drill pilot holes for lag screws and anchors
Step 6: screw in anchors
Step 7: have someone hold up the mount while you screw in two of the stud side lag screws on one of the mount arms (helper dismissed till step 12)
Step 8: screw in lag screws for other mount arm
Step 9: screw in bolts for anchors
Step 10: use built in level to adjust level-ness and then tighten the screws securing mount arms to mount surface
Step 11: bolt mounting brackets to tv - back out the screws that will secure the brackets to the mount from underneath.
Step 12: use helper to help hang tv/brackets onto mount (helper dismissed!)
Step 13: tighten underside screws to secure brackets to mount
Step 14: enjoy / sigh relief!

Install certainly takes some measuring and planning but it's worth it. My wife and I have our 55" tv hanging from the wall with this mount so that it is on there rock solid. There is NO CHANCE of the TV falling over if kids are running/jumping around in the living room. (Important especially if you have a wii!) I'm a worry wort and I feel much safer with the tv bolted to both walls of the corner with this rock solid mount. Love it.

(Although the product is not exactly the same as my purchase, they are very similar; so take this review at that) I purchased the STR-DE995 7.1 "Home theater" receiver. After less than one year, it deteriorated into an overpriced stereo receiver. For your amusement, I attached the letter I sent to SONY of America's CEO.

Mr. Howard Stringer,

I am writing to inform you that your company has just lost my business. Over the years I have purchased many products from Sony and its subsidiaries, including a SONY Walkman, a Car Discman, 3 stereo receivers, a CD/DVD 5 disc changer, a WEGA TV, a PlayStation and its software, and DVDs and CDs distributed by SONY and its subsidiaries Columbia and Epic.

With the recent purchase of the SONY STR-DE995 receiver, I experienced audio problems 9 months from the date of purchase. The chronology of action taken is outlined below.

In an email, I wrote:
"Audio problem - When Dolby/dts (or any surround format) is selected a rhythmic, chirping noise is sounded through the center and rear speakers (currently have 5.1 setup). The noise is amplified as the volume increases. There is no recognizable noise when the receiver is in stereo
mode (since the surround speakers are not enabled). I've tried the following connections: RCA analog, Digital Coaxial, and Digital optical. The receiver is stored in an entertainment center, and is connected to a SonicBlue ReplayTV DVR and Sony DVP-NC655P (both devices have the same sound output problem). The audio problem began about 2 weeks ago. No devices/cables/wires have been added or removed leading up to the problem. I've had no other problems with this device."

Follow-up email from customer service stated the problem would need to be serviced. My reply:
"The service offered is very unsatisfactory. I treat and have treated all my electronic devices in excellent condition, and this productwas purchased less than a year ago (09/26/2003). The recommendation was to have it serviced. Since the closest Sony Service Center is over 2 hours away and the closest authorized center is 45 min away, I'd have to mail it to one of
the centers. Figuring 2 business days to and from the center and about 3-5 days to be serviced (if it can be repaired at all); that would leave me without a receiver for at least 2 weeks. With the many years doing business with Sony, I expect its receiver to be fully operational for many years, not just 9 months. Also, the out of pocket expenses that would be charged at my expense to get the receiver to one of the service centers is not acceptable.

I take a great deal of time researching the best products for the resources I have available to me; when I decide to purchase that product I not only expect the product to be exceptional, but the service as well. Therefore, since the product is under warranty, I want the STR-DE995 replaced with a new one, and I will ship the "problem" receiver to Sony at its expense."


A 2nd follow-up email was sent stating customer service would need to be phoned. When I spoke with a rep this morning, he stated SONY's policy would not be able to honor my request as stated in the above email. When no progress had been made I requested to speak to the manager. He said he was the manager. I reiterated my request to speak to his supervisor. He then transferred me to a rep named Luke. He basically mimicked what the precious rep had told me; insisting policy must be adhered to. I continued the conversation stating, I expect perfection in the products I buy and the service that comes with that product. He replied that SONY equipment is constructed by humans and mistakes will be made. With that said, am I to believe that now and in the future I can expect less than perfect products from SONY? Even if my receiver is serviced, what's to guarantee there will beno other underlying problems? He didn't have the knowledge to answer my questions; instead he repeated the warranty policy. I went on to say, if SONY will not compensate me with a new receiver and pay for shipping costs, it will lose my business and will recommend to my friends and family to do the same. He told me I shouldn't base this decision on emotion, and tried to explain to me how businesses worked. I cut his rhetoric short by restating my position. He offered to fill out a service request. I said, you have lost my business and be sure to pass the message onto your supervisor.

With the end of the conversation, the SONY Car Discman that I've been using at my workplace for the past 6 years went right in the garbage. I will not advertise SONY or any of its subsidiaries. I will not purchase any SONY product and encourage my friends and family to do the same. I will not buy advertising that supports the Spider-Man franchise or Columbia/Tri-Star films, nor those products advertised on Wheel of Fortune and Jeopardy!. Finally, until I have the resources, I will be replacing all my SONY products with non-affiliated brands.

I've used serveral different brands for coconut oil and this brand is my favorite for several reasons. 1. Texture.....much creamier texture than most brands and melts smoother when warmed up. 3. Taste...I know a lot of cooks and chefs prefer a more neutral flavor but I personally love the more pronounced smell and hint of coconut. 4. Versatility...with the everyday user in mind I love to use this oil for popcorn, sauteing veggies or roasting as well as using as a scalp and hair treatment and makes for a wonderfully gentle makeup remover esp for the hard to budge waterproof mascara...be sure to rinse away from eyes very well tho...can block the delicate pores! I was very excited to purchase the Omron Full Body Comp Scale. It appeared to be state of the art and with its 4 point of contact I was hoping for extremely, or more accurate body fat numbers. In 24 hour spans there were BODY FAT swings of 4% or more. I know from being involved in fitness that these types of swings are highly improbable, some would say impossible.

The scale also has an \\"Age\\" feature, which uses an algorithm that produces your \\"Body Age\\". As someone who trains 5 days a week and engages in a very active lifestyle my \\"Age\\" was consistently 80 years old!

I am starting to believe that our technology just is not yet available to offer a cost effective methodology of accurately measuring body fat. I have used Omron before and they get high grades in construction and durability. My hope was for a device that if not record accurate BODY FAT measurements at least record consistent records so you could gauge if you were moving in the right direction. Unfortunately that does not seem to be the case.

So there is frustration in trying to gauge my actual fitness levels using this scale - though it does appear to run a true and accurate body weight. Additionally, while the body age feature was an attractive lure for motivating me to get back to High School fitness level it would appear to have the opposite effect and rather than getting fitted for my High School Letterman Jacket had me thinking of getting fitted for dentures and depends!

I am in search of the ideal elbow sleeve to relieve the pain of cubital tunnel syndrome. When the sleeves provided by my physical therapist came up short when it came to pain relief, I decided to try this sleeve. So, here goes with what I like about this sleeve: - It is sturdy. - Generous gel padding helps protect the ulnar nerve from being aggravated and causing the pain. - Sleeve fits snugly and doesn't move around on the elbow. - Sleeve fabric quickly adjusts its fit to your arm instead of forcing your arm to adjust to it. - Offered in a nice, blue color along with beige. Now for the nits to pick: - It is pricey (but what cost is too much if it does the job well?) - Make sure you select the right size! The way Bort Medical sleeves, braces, and other devices are listed in Amazon does not include a size selection from within one web page. You have sift through all of the Bort Medical items available on Amazon (17 pages of information according to my searches) to find the product you want with the size indicated in its Amazon listing title. - Develops a funky smell after one day of use. It can be hand washed, but washing it once a day and letting it air dry isn't convenient.

I purchased this product last spring to help de-tangle my toddler's hair. Back then, she was only 14 months old and still had short (but curly) hair. Even then, this didn't really help us comb out the tangles in her hair. It DID help define her curls once her hair was already combed, plus it did add shine - which was nice. I followed the directions on the bottle and used this when her hair was still wet. I also tried using a conditioner first and also tried using this when her hair was dry. It still didn't help de-tangle.

Now that she's 22 months old, she has hair that goes almost down to her shoulders when it's wet. Her hair is fine and she has lots of tight Little Orphan Annie curls. With her hair now being longer, this stuff no longer does anything for it at all. In fact, I'd say that it even dries her hair out. After using this, her hair turns into a frizzy mess in a matter of hours. Her hair seriously looks better WITHOUT this product in it.

I do love that the ingredients are safe and this stuff also smells fabulous. The bottle lasts a long time. I really do wish it would work. However, I've now switched over to using California Baby Calendula Conditioner in her hair to help tame it - and that does work wonderfully - but I'm still hoping to find a natural de-tangler that actually does what it's supposed to do.

* (I use Earth Mama Angel Baby or California Baby shampoos on my baby. I use either Healthy Times or California Baby conditioner. I have very soft water and only wash my baby's hair a couple times per week. The only reason I mention this is to point out that my baby's hair care routine isn't overly harsh, so it shouldn't be making this product ineffective.)

I can think of several better brands then the Body Fortress brand (EAS, BSN, MuscleTech etc...) but Body Fortress is probably the best bet if you're on a budget and can't afford the high price tags of the bigger brands that are out there. Cookies N Cream is easily the best flavor for this particular brand, which isn't saying much because the rest of the flavors a completely horrid. However, to this flavors credit, it does taste a little bit like the flavor that's labeled on the container.

Despite what many people might think because of its price tag, Body Fortress is a high quality protein source and the fact that its Whey products are 52-60 grams of protein every two scoops is really impressive. The only problem that has plagued this product, is once again, the taste. This is really the only flavor from their Whey Protein Powder line that is actually somewhat easy to chug down, because the regular Chocolate, Strawberry, Vanilla and the awful Chocolate and Peanut Butter are not.

So overall, this is the only flavor that gets a passing grade from me.

One user commented on the nuggets being hard. That is true for me as well. I put a nut cracker in the box of nuggets and just crunch up each nugget before I use it. It may not be a problem for machines where you add soap with the clothes. I use a front loader with a dispenser and we have had hardened chunks that did not completely dissolve. I'm able to crunch the nuggets with the nutcracker and it doesn't burst the outer pack. Just a few squeezes and the hardened nuggets are ready to use and dissolve easily with nothing leftover.

The Nature Made Fish Oil 1000mg Liquid Softgels, 250-count is a good value. It is 1000mg with 300mg of Omega 3. 2 soft gels taken with a meal provide the recommended daily amount of 600mg of Omega-3 - including 500mg of EPA and DHA. The recommended daily serving is the equivalent of 2 servings of fatty fish. There is no color added, no artificial flavors or preservatives and is gluten free. Ingredients included however are gelatin, glycerin, water and tocopherol (vitamin E). There is a note that it contains fish (anchovy and sardine) as well as soy. The fish country of origin is Peru but it claims to be manufactured and tested in the USA.The expiration date on the bottle I received is 3 years out and expires January 2018. They are easy to take and have no after taste. Too soon to know if it produces results or not, but I can update my review in 6 months when I know for sure whether or not they are effective.

PLEASE do not ingest this stuff! Go ahead and use it topically or in your laundry or whatever, but for the love of Pete, don't take it orally. If you think that this is a "natural" disinfectant or anti-fungal, you are wrong. Unfortunately grapefruit seeds do not have natural antimicrobial properties.

The FDA and DEA have issued MANY warnings to the manufacturers of "Citricidal" in the last few years because these products are heavily contaminated with benzalkonium chloride. What exactly is this chemical? Well you may already know it as HAND SANITIZER.

I can't speak for the purity of liquid extracts, but the powders are most heavily contaminated. Please read the industry trade article below:

http://www.nutraingredients-usa.com/Suppliers2/Expert-dismisses-grapefruit-seed-extract-false-positive-explanation

TL;DR - one of the manufacturers stated that Citricidal is the same molecular weight as BZK, giving a false positive test result. This is total BS, as explained by one of the nation's top chemists, director of Flora Labs, James Neal-Kababick. This guy is a consumer advocacy crusader who does this for a living:

http://www.nbcnews.com/id/19230748/ns/health-health_care/t/bogus-ingredients-put-consumers-health-risk/#.VWzlIM5vb0c

They've even found TRICLOSAN in these powders...that's the disinfectant in your anti-bacterial soaps. So PLEASE do not consume this, and understand the only reason it kills your athlete's foot or yeast infection is because it has artificial sanitizers illegally and unethically added to it.

I can't claim that taking the recommended 3 softgels daily (3.6g) was responsible for any measurable memory improvement, weight loss or lower cholesterol but I can say that doing so didn't hurt at all. While the benefits of Lecithin are being debated and research is ongoing, I am happy with NOW's product because it has no 'bad' ingredients such as sugar, corn starch, salt, yeast, wheat, gluten, corn, milk, egg, shellfish or preservatives. NOW also states that their product is GMO-free - a good thing.

Given the suggested serving size of 3 softgels, the 400 quantity should last for about 4 months if taken as suggested. The gels are easy to swallow and, since this Lecithin is extracted from soybeans, there is no aftertaste and I haven't experienced any digestive trouble.

I am unaware of any negatives other than the lack of consensus on Lecithin's actual effectiveness but for a 'food supplement', not a miracle cure, this is a good product.

three issues:

(1) your raw data is locked into the fitbit online service unless you pay $50/year for the premium service to unlock it. in terms of owning the data about yourself this is a really unfriendly policy.

(2) could just be my device, but i've found that after it has been in use for 5 days+ without a full reset it will start to claim that i've climbed a flight of stairs every ~100 steps even on level ground. this causes me to end up with 100+ flights in a day which is really annoying because you can't remove just the stairs from your activities.

after much searching i learned how to reset the device and now when i charge it i deliberately reset it (you plug it into the USB charger and hold the button for ~10s and it will power off, then you release and press the button again to power it on). when i reset it like this i also notice that it also seems to recalibrate its battery charge indication, and is frequently more empty than it was showing prior to the reset.

in case it helps fitbit folks mine claims to have FITBIT 6.60 when it powers up.

(3) (2014-07-12 edit) in the span of 3 days fitbit awarded me the 1000 floors badge and the 2000 floors badge, and the above bug (2) didn't even occur during this period: nothing on my tracker indicates i climbed 1000 floors.

A friend's company were offering it's use as a wellness program and it caught my interest. I researched and purchased from Amazon.com

Pro:
Small
Light
Tracks sleep pattern, stairs, distance walked, calories burned
Nice integration with web or android apps, sends encouraging emails when goals are met or close to be attained
syncs to my Galaxy SIII via Bluetooth and to my PC app via supplied Bluetooth micro dongle
Battery lasts 5 days
easy to plug in USB charger design

Cons:

Have to remove it from the silicone case and insert into a pouch on a Velcro attached wrist strap -- not hard to do but a bit of a pain to have to remember every night (not an issue if you don't care about tacking your sleep)

The Clip while seemingly well made and securely attached to articles of clothing, can eventually detach based on where it is attached: My story: Just a quick note to ensure you know where your fitbit is at any given time -- Mine was hooked to the inside of my left pants pocket facing in. It seemed like a secure fitting clip but somehow, (maybe the getting in and out of my car), it shimmied loose and went AWOL..

Luckily, based on the last time it synced and knowing where I generally was at that time, I was able to zero in on where it might have detached and amazingly lucky for me I called the Office Depot that I had been perusing around that time and they actually found it and put it aside for me!! VERY LUCKY!

I have since engaged my trusty Brother label maker and affixed my cell # to the back of the device and inside the clip to hopefully help it find it's way home should it ever happen again...

If it was lost, for me, I was not going to spend another $90 unless there is a better designed belt clip...

Over all a great tool to keep track of your fitness and to get an idea of your sleep pattern.

There are hundreds of reviews on Amazon about this scale, and they are overwhelmingly positive, which is why I chose this particular brand and model. After two weeks of use, here is my summary:

Design: Perfect! Sleek, modern, light weight, and super thin. Now I just need to by a modern loft downtown to put this thing in! Did Apple design this scale?

Weight Measurement: Perfectly accurate and delivers a very quick reading, less than three seconds. What more could I ask for?

Body Fat Measurement: Relatively accurate, but needed to be calibrated by adjusting the height of the individual. This was a bit of a disappointment. After programming the unit for myself and the wife, my body fat reading was at least 10% off, reading much less than my actual body fat. Unfortunately, I knew what my body fat % was, so I couldn't be blissfully ignorant and content with the 14% reading, which is optimal health. My wife, on the other hand, was off about 5% in the other direction. In the time it took for the scale to be delivered, she got 5% fatter!! WTF? I emailed EatSmart, and they replied within hours, giving me instructions to change our heights in user program. This will either slow down or speed up the electrical signal to align the measurement with what we knew our actual body fat percentages are. From here on out the scale will be calibrated correctly and the measurements accurate. So far so good, over the two week period or percentages have remained constant, as expected.

Other Measurements: Water, Bone, & Muscle. These are just bonus numbers to me, all I am really concerned with is weight and body fat. The numbers seem to fall in line with what I would expect from the charts listed in the user manual, but I really don't pay too much attention to them.

Overall: After the adjustment to the body fat settings, I am happy with the scale, and I love the step on technology; no buttons to push or taps needed. I deducted one star for the body fat issue, otherwise this would be a solid five star scale.

I was initially pleased by the quality and texture of the toy, not to mention the suction is an absolute plus compared to others. However, cleaning it proves to be difficult, as the only way it will dry is if you manually reverse it and hand-dry with a towel. It will not air-dry, which is important in maintaining longevity and preventing other things from accumulating (think of hair/fuzz from a towel, etc). I left it hanging upside down in an open, airy room for a full day and it was still damp. Not good.

That minor detail aside, however, the real dilemma is the way the inner lining is formed. The outside is a thick pink mold, whereas the inside is a very thin sleeve bound along the edge of the sleeve itself. Within a week of very minimal use, the inner sleeve started to detach from the wall of the outer mold. Now there is a gap between the two layers that lets water inside (when cleaning) and is impossible to dry or clean out. It also slides and detracts from the experience of using the sleeve. The more it is used, the more it detaches. If I really wanted to, I could just slide my finger to the bottom between the layers and detach it entirely and remove it. Unfortunately it is this inner sleeve that provides the texture so that is a major issue.

The fragile state is worrisome, as I cannot get much use out of the toy since purchasing it originally. It took little use to degrade to its current state, though I'm sure it is just a fluke in my particular unit's molding. Others seem to enjoy their sleeves, so I would be hopeful that anyone that purchases it has a better experience than me.

Says vegi caps but that is misleading. Only the capsule is vegan. This supplement contains intrinsic factor derived from pigs (porcine). Intrinsic factor is produced by the stomach and is essential to the assimilation of B12. Some people need intrinsic factor supplement because they no longer produce intrinsic factor in sufficient quantities to assimilate B12. Yet I fail to understand why a company would bother to create and advertize a vegi cap when contents are derived directly from animal. On the positive side, the B vitamins are phosphates or methyls -- no oxides. That is very good and, truthfully, very hard to find. Despite being a vegan, I'm going to finish these vitamins because I'm not a total fanatic. But they get one star for misleading description. How many people even know what porcine is? I knew but missed the fine print. So, I recommend these B vitamins if you really need intrinsic factor with your B12.

I spent 1 year thinking about this scale: "Is it acurate? Do I really need the wi-fi? Is it worth the money?"
And I came to the following conclusion:
- It's the most beautifull scale I've ever seen
- The weight it's super accurate - It measures till 0.01kg - not that I need it, but it's good to have that precision.
- It's the most simple thing to use in the whole world - You just step on it, and it reads your weight, body fat %, and BPM. And at the end it recognizes you and sends the data to your account. Currently 5 people use my scale and the scale works perfectly.
- The Wi-Fi, THE WIFI - This is the thing that makes it all worth it. The ease! The simplicity. This saves you so much work. At first it may seem useless, but when you use it... I fell so good seeing my progression from this last 3 months (when I bought the scale).
I can see my everyday weight from this last 3 months; and because I track my calories too, I can make a correlation and figure out what is working with me and what is not.
- I dont really need the BPM but it's nice too see mine slowing down as I keep doing cardio and geting used to it.
- The Health Mate Website is super clean, and shows you everything you need to see with precision and beauty.

I absolutely recommend it to EVERYBODY. It could be a bit cheaper, but the scale is great and a good investment. It improves your life quality easily.

Depend Guards for Men, Maximum Absorbency...

We bought these for my father, who is 83. He has been having a bit of trouble with incontinence at night while sleeping. These Depend Guards for Men are just what the doctor ordered. Literally, the doctor said he should get these. Because he's embarrassed about his problem, we had to get them for him and show him how to use them.

These are a thick, absorbent product that fits men well. The guards are shaped like underwear and have an adhesive strip that holds them in place in your underwear. They stay put well and are absorbent enough to capture and hold almost any accident, day or night. The package contains 52 guards for protection day and night. They are not noticeable when worn in the underwear. They work in boxer-briefs and briefs. They do not work well in standard boxer underwear.

This is a great product that just work right out of the package. They are absorbent and do not show when worn correctly.
