This is a decent value, however buyers should be aware that the product is only 20% by weight of phosphatidyl serine (PS). I believe that the seller should clearly state this. (This product is derived from soy beans, and the remaining 80% consists of other phospholipids such as phosphatidyl choline.) (NOTE: 20% strength is typical for PS powder; other commonly available strengths are 50%, and 99%; most PS supplements in capsule form use a 20% strength powder). What this means is that for each 500 mg of powder, you are getting 100 mg of PS. Thus 100 grams of this PS powder gives you 20 grams of actual PS, which is equivalent to a bottle of 200 capsules each containing 100 mg PS. With this powder, you are paying ($35.55/200) = $0.18 per 100 mg of PS. For comparison, the best value bottle of PS I could find on iherb (Doctor's Best, Best Phosphatidyl Serine, 100 mg, 120 Veggie Caps, $31.98) worked out at around $0.26 per 100 mg serving. So with this powder, you ARE saving money (18 cents versus 26 cents per 100 mg serve). There are other advantages to powder over capsules/ softgels. Powders can be sprinkled on foods or blended into smoothies. I like to blend my PS powder in my whey protein drink for example. Regarding storage, I tip the entire pack of powder into a plastic tub with an airtight lid, and store it in the fridge. If you keep it chilled, it's possible to take a spoon of the powder and sprinkle it into e.g., a smoothie without the powder sticking to the spoon.

When you purchase the Hitachi, you've got to know what you're getting. You're not getting one of those novelty vibrators that'll work for about 100 uses (six months at best) and then putter out or otherwise breakdown. You're also not getting a regular vibrator, with service vibrations simply do the trick. The Hitachi is incredibly powerful, packing up to 6000 rpm on the high setting, its reputation is very good and it will last in all likelihood a large portion of your sexual life. We're talking years, and decades if you care for it well. In addition, the vibrations that the Hitachi provides are not only powerful, but penetrating and deep. It woke up parts of me that I didn't know were there. It's funny because I thought that the sheer vibrating power of the Hitachi would make me less sensitive and stop me from enjoying my partner as much. Wrong. If anything, it was a sexual aid and made me more sensitive and responsive to my partner, and even other vibrators. I've had my Hitachi for 4 months, and at the beginning I didn't like it as well because it \\"worked\\" so quickly that there was no build up. But after spending a few months with it, it's hands down my favorite toy. Also, amazon's pricing is a steal for what you're getting; other websites or sex shops sell the Hitachi for as much as $50. The one thing to watch out for, and the one downside, is that although it is a machine with incredible, deep vibrations and last power, the material isn't really built for sensitive tissues, and it shows. It's made out of vinyl and with frequent use, even if that's just every couple days or so, it tends to irritate skin. Even so, it's worth the buy and putting a condom over the head or buying an inexpensive attachment (I just ordered the natural contours g-spot attachment) you can make an awesome toy damn near perfect.

I have been taking this product for 2 years now (off and on of course, can't over do it) and I managed to lose 30 lbs. in the first 1 1/2 - 2 mos.! Then I slacked off and took maybe 2 pills a day and gradually added back in a little more food. I did quit junk food altogerther. But later (and It took a while to even have craving again,surprisinly) I could add in a tiny snack and be fine. I even in the beginning cut down to 1-2 meals a day... I know that's bad, but honestly I'm so used to it anyway cause I have digestion issues. but later I did start adding in like 3-5 really small meals with no issues and no weight gain. This is THE ONLY PRODUCT of like the 20+ I've tried that actually works! And I also like, unlike most, it doesn't make you jittery or headachy or sick..however, on me I have found if I don't eat at least a couple bites when I take it, it tends to make me feel sick. but mostly, i'm fine. Also, after a couple weeks or so I will start feeling sick so it's my cue to hold off a while. I usually, just to maintain weight, take 2 a day for about a week then take a week off sometimes more. So yeah, definitely watch how much you take for sure...don't go overboard. If you stay in low doses and take breaks, it doesn't make me sick or jittery. In the beginning or every now n then when I need to lose a poumd or two I've gained, I take 4 per day. but go down after few days. I also used the Jillian cleanse first too. and every few months I'll take a few days of it just to get rid of some bloat.. It also works really well...not harsh like a laxative. It's a gentle, maybe frequent, normal like, over a couple days kind of thing. I RECOMMEND JILLIAN FAT BURNER. Oh, but stay away from the red bottle one. I've gotten it in by mistake(?) once and I tried it but it didn't do squat! Not even a mild energy., The white bottle like this one does give you a "just right" energy unless of course you take too much you'll notice your heart rate go up!

I came across more than one online person claiming that MSM in soap bars and creams helped their skin rebound after weight loss. As someone who is restarting a diet (after losing 32 pounds and maintaining for more than a year), I want to see if it helps with elasticity issues (anyone who has lost a lot of weight knows what I mean...that stretched out and unappealing look of skin that was expanded with fat and is deflated with fat loss). I'll update if I notice improvements by next year (by which time I hope to be down anothe 32 lbs).

I do find that it has a nice absorbent, creamy, moisturizing quality. I use it on upper arms, belly, bosom and thighs (I use fragrance free sensitive skin moisturizers elsewhere, except feet, where I like to use perfumed lotions). It absorbs fast and leaves skin nicely soft. Not greasy at all. If it gets in the bloodstream and helps joints, all the better. (I will be starting to take the MSM powder for my aging knees and ankle joints which often hurt after exercising).

The scent is light to medium-light (not heavy or annoying) and is herbally (probably from the chamomile extract and rosemary leaf oil.

So far, I'd say this is another quality product from Source Naturals. If it does half of what I hear about it, I'll be happy--but especially if it helps my skin's elasticity and health. The price here with S&S is very, very good and this two-pack is convenient.

I want to thank the other reviewer for posting about the eyebrow hair-regrow use. I'm going to start trying it for that (if my facial skin can tolerate it, as I do have a supersensitive face with dermatitis/eczema issues). I also have thinning eyebrows since perimenopause and then menopause hit. They've definitely gotten a bit \\"bald\\" with age. So, thanks for that tip.

Hope this review helps those considering this product...be well...

UPDATE: The advice for eyebrows is correct. Mine are filling out in the bald spots. :) Now, I also started taking Biotin with this cream, so it may be synergistic, but I had taken Biotin alone in the past and it alone didn't have the effect on eyebrows this combo does. So, whether it's the both combined or principally the MSM cream, dunno. I use a Q-tip to apply. I have had to pluck a bit more. :D

I can't tell yet if it is having any good effect on skin elasticity, but I'm continuing with it. I had to discontinue oral MSM due to an allergic rash reaction, but the cream isn't affecting my sensitive system/skin, so I hope it will have good long-term use effects. I did start using a sage and MSM powder mix on my scalp where my hair is thinning a bit post-menopausally, and I hope that since I can't take it internally, that application pre-shampooing will be efficacious.

I used to start my day with fruit juices like orange and pineapple. They would give me a quick energy burst (probably because of all the sugar), but would eventually wear off, making me feel tired and run-down by mid-morning. A long time ago, I switched to spirulina supplement drinks in the morning. mixed just with water. They do a better job of getting me started and keeping my energy and focus up all morning. Here's a good way to start your day: Mix this up with water and drink. (For a more creamy drink, you might try rice milk, almond milk, or coconut milk instead of water. But that does add a bit of sugar). Since you have to wait about 20 minutes after drinking and before eating, that's a good time for some exercise, like a brisk walk. After about 20 minutes of exercise, then have breakfast. I should add, if you don't like the normal \\"green\\" taste of most spirulina mixes, you might want to try this one. While each person's taste are a little different, you might find it tastes better than the others.

I have only used it one month, but already like it more than tampons. I was a little worried at first about getting it out based on some of the other reviews, but really had nothing to worry about. The instructions are very detailed, although the cup is easy to use. Really just place and forget for hours! My heavier days I empty it out about every 6 hours but lighter days I can go as long as needed. I try to think ahead to where I'll be in 12 hours and if it's be easy to empty then. If I know I'll be out and might be in a public restroom, I empty then and know I'll be home in at least 12 hours from that point. It does get a little tricky in public restrooms where you're not right next to a sink, but a cup of water works (although you look a little strange going into the stall with a cup of water). For me I try to empty it at home as much as possible because I still squat down for removal and insertion (maybe others have perfected it in more of a standing position). And squatting is also awkward in a public restroom. Also make sure you have a good grip on the cup when empting, it can get slick and you don't want it falling into dirty water....or maybe always flush before empting.
It can be messy when you're emptying it but you wash your hands anyways. I feel much better using this than tampons but I'm the type who has always hated having my period anyway.

Get another flavor if you can, but I doubt it'll help (considering their ingredients). I have just finished up my 2nd course of IGF-2 along with a few other Applied Neutricuticals products (HGH-Up, Neovar) and I've had serious strength gains in the last 3 months. I have also increased my caloric/protein intake though so it is definitely not a one-bottle solution. Take this review as much for an endorsement of the whole App Nut. stack rather than IGF-2 exclusively. As mentioned it's one of the more expensive supplements but I've had good experience with it. Numbers don't mean much because my regimen is going to be completely different from yours, however: Time Taken: 84 days (with app nut stack) Lifting: 4 days week x 90-120m BF Change: 1-3% drop Weight change: + 17 lbs I'm writing this review primarily to report an unexpected benefit. From the very first night I started taking IGF-2, my sleep cycle was better regulated than ever. I've suffered from an irregular sleep cycle all my life, but once I started dosing 3-4 capsules, say about twice a day, the 2nd being right before bed, I found that I wake up every morning at 6-8am regardless of how much sleep I got. If I'm exhausted I often consciously go back to sleep, but it has somehow given me some sort of internal alarm clock. It's quite noticeable because it will go away if I don't take it for a day, and come back immediately when I start again. It's a major game changer and I plan to consult my doctor to find out if it's safe to take this stuff indefinitely. Maybe it has something to do with insulin control? Who knows.

Zarbee's Naturals children's cough syrup + mucus relief - grape flavor does not have Cinnamon like some of the other brands of natural children's cough syrups, so this is a better option for any kids that are allergic to cinnamon (either face or diaper rash). The only ingredients are: blend of dark honeys, zinc, vitamin C, water, natural flavor, grapefruit seed extract (to preserve freshness), and citric acid. Ivy leaf extract is also added to the Cough Syrup + Mucus Relief version to help thin and loosen mucus. Our stubborn daughter does not resist taking it, so the taste must be pretty good. *Note, that it can NOT be used with children under one year old, since it does contain honey. Children one year to five years old are directed to take 1 teaspoon, and children six year old and older, 2 teaspoons per dose. One 4 fluid ounce bottle contains 22 teaspoons, or 22 doses for a child one to five years old. 11 doses for a child six years or older.

Having bought various types of vinegars hoping to find the right one but never did until now. Made a pot of my homemade(from scratch)pasta sauce, while it's also been really good 2 tsp of Alessi made it great. Can't believe the taste it gives to a tomatoe based sauce, was eating by the spoonfuls before adding to the pasta. Wanting to experiment some more, I have been wanting to make some roasted red pepper remoulade to jazz up a BLT or Roast Beef sandwhich. This was the key ingredient even more so than the roasted red peppers. The balsamic cut the fatty taste of the mayo(not a fan of may alone except potato/pasta salad)and added an interesting sweetness but not like sugar. Ate couple spoons of that as well. Not to worry I am not a double dipper even in my own house. I think this will wake up a roast beef gravy and who knows what else. Now I know what to buy and can also afford.

We've had this for almost 3 years now. It seems to do pretty well at filtering out chlorine, judging by smell and how my skin/hair feel. It does make a difference in how both feel. I'd love to see actual measurements of chlorine reduction over time. There's two of us, we take a shower each almost everyday (a bit overkill in my mind, sorry mom) and the filter seems to last 3 to 4 months. But remember there's no quantitative analysis going on here. The whole contraption, with the exception the connections, is plastic. Given the mechanical loads it undergoes it's not surprising that it breaks fairly easily. The housing has fractured on ours with no unusual force being encountered. ( Ahhh epoxy... Wasn't I trying to *reduce* my exposure to something or another? Oops. ) Taking apart a used filter reveals a simple case containing what I assume to be activated charcoal, exactly like you may buy for an aquarium filter with a little bit of paper or synthetic mesh I assume is for sediment. Only thing is that if you did buy this much charcoal from a pet store, it would cost about one tenth what a replacement filter cost. All filters must reduce water flow to some degree. This filter does pretty well here, the reduction is minimal. If you're looking to reduce the odor (at least) of chlorine and don't have kids, and don't mind the steep replacement filter costs, and promise not to ever overtighten anything, nor ever to drop, pull, or stare directly into its eyes then this is the filter for you!! Not awful but not recommended.

I ordered a package that was on sale here through Amazon Local. I ordered the protein package. I am sorely disappointed. I only am enjoying about one out of five of the meals. Many of the chicken cutlets are not cleaned properly of their tendons and grizzle. The spices and/or additives used might make one feel more full yet it often gives me a headache and when I can't eat it because of an odd taste I find that the family dog doesn't want it either. The package did come quickly, in cellophane packages still very frozen yet it is not an easy item to return. I learned that there is only a five day window in which to complain and for me I was still hopeful and sampling the foods during those first five days. I would not recommend this to anyone I cared about. I would only say that it might be better than starving if you are going through an extremely stressful patch in your life. Otherwise the least expensive frozen diet meal like Lean Cuisine in my opinion would be way better quality and when your supermarket has sales would be way cheaper than the Personal Trainer Food. I am writing this long review since this is one of the first Amazon purchases I ever made where I felt the reviews misled me. I really am more disappointed in this than any other item I ever purchased on Amazon or on line period. I also feel badly that there was little recourse for me-the PTF rep wrote to me basically saying I only had a five day window to voice my concerns and that was it. The only frozen food I ever purchased that was as sub par as this was some frozen prepared meals from Walmart--but Walmart backs up their products and PTF does not after five days.

Curved backdoor toys are supposed to add extra sensations on top of what they are otherwise designed for. These can be curved column dongs which provide a better fit for the naturally arched inner cavities. These can be prostate stimulators, most often in the shape of towers or permanent plugs. Finally, all sorts of curved fantasy shapes are possible too. The point in using them is to tickle a specific spot, hence choosing the right tool for personal anatomy is key.

Titanmen Big Stuff Large is a a very simple curved dong. The 62 mm bead at the top gives way to two rings followed by a curved column. The dong is quite heavy, and features a massive base with a sucker, allowing for safe riding once the column is all in. It is a superbly made toy, much easier to use than others of similar girth.

Build and Entry:
------------
Big Stuff Large is quite large, but I could easily imagine a 10 mm thicker dong that would be as easy to use. I wish they had made an XL version. The top bead is 62 mm in diameter, although since it's an ellipsoid, it will be as easy to insert as toys which are 3-4 mm smaller in diameter. The two rings that follow are 57 mm in diameter, followed by a shallow 51 mm gap. From that point on, there are no features on the smooth, curved column, that continues to slowly increase in girth, reaching 60 mm in diameter at the base, at 170 mm of insertable length.

Even though 62 mm might sound like much, this is by far the easiest toy to insert among my large collection of 60+ mm backdoor toys. Once the top bead is in, there are no difficulties to come -- it simply slides in all the way to the base. It is really quite surprising! If only some of my other toys were as easy on my bum.

Capture:
------------
Since it's pointless to stop at the gap which follows the rings, the sphincter will be always dilated, anywhere from 50 to 60 mm, depending on how deep the toy is in. The best use of Big Stuff is fastriding. It is not a probe, but since it's significantly curved, it will bang just above the prostate, repeatedly, if the insertor chose to sit on this thing all the way down. I have found that prostate stimulation is more effective if the curved dong is only 2/3 of the way in. As such, I prefer to use it standing up.

Exit:
------------
Now for the fun part. Although it is really easy to extract by hand, I now do it hands-free, standing up. Just letting go of the column will let gravity do its work. Since it's so heavy, it will begin sliding out on its own, accelerating in the process. There will be a slowdown when the bead hits the sphincter from within, and a gasp-inducing plonk will eject the bead also, and the heavy dong falling onto the floor. I can't imagine using this toy and not trying a gravity assisted exit ;)

I bought this stevia for the first time, a few months ago. I've been using stevia extract powder (1/32 tsp. = tsp. sugar) for almost 10 years and this brand is just as good as the other brands and the cheapest price I've seen around per serving. This is such a great deal compared to the other brands of stevia I've purchased in the past. A pound (16 ounces) of stevia extract powder for $40 is such a great deal. The Now brand sells for $55-60 a lb. and around 7-8 years ago I paid more than that for that size bottle at a local health food store and it lasted me more than a year (I was only able to buy it once from that store like that. They no longer sell the big bottle like that. They use the bottle to repackage in smaller zipper baggies and sell by the ounce. They were surprised I wanted to buy the big bottle which they did have a price on.) The last few years, I was purchasing a 3.5 ounce bottle of the Kal brand for $28-30 at another local health food store and that much wouldn't last me 2-3 months. I use a lot of stevia, mostly for my cold green tea with lemon, which I drink like water, from 1 to 1 1/2 liters of tea a day. Also, I refill an old small (1 oz.?) Now bottle of stevia, and carry it around in my purse for sweetening unsweet tea in restaurants, which I use about once or twice a week. I also use stevia to sweeten coffee, which I had only been drinking once or twice a week but lately I have been drinking coffee more often. As far as the taste and sweetness, it's just as good as the other brands like Now and Kal. It's just as good as the store brand that I bought for several years from Vitamin World, which they used to sell a few yrs ago (which they don't anymore, they use a more \\"watered down\\" stevia powder now). The Kal brand is slightly sweeter but a lot of times I was easily using too much of that brand anyway. If I was using 4-5 scoops of Kal brand to sweeten a large glass of tea in a restaurant, I may need to add an extra scoop or two of this brandto get it just as sweet but this brand is still such a great deal and I'm less likely to use too much. It's been awhile since I've used the Now brand but far as I can remember it's similiar to Kal brand but Kal may be slightly sweeter. Again, this is the best deal around on stevia. The best price and just as good as other brands. I still have a lot left and will definitely purchase this brand again. It may be a year before I need some more but this brand is dated 1 1/2 yrs from now (which I've already had half a year). I'm sure it would still be good long after the sell by date but I'll have it used up long before the date. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this stevia.

[[VIDEOID:mo2Z765I8AEXTOX]]I have the Reynolds vac sealer that I bought over a year ago as well. That works just as well, however they no longer sell it in my area, to my knowledge anyawy,so when I saw this pump I was curious. First of all, you can't beat the price. The refill bags are reasonably priced as well. I purchased them at a Walmart in my area. The pump and the battery powered Reynolds sealer are comparable to each other in function. I have used the pump many times and have had one instance where there seemed to be some air leakage; to remedy the problem, I re-pumped and placed 2 strips of tape over the pump entry point- so far so good. The way I see it, even if it doesn't work 100% all the time, it still gets more air out than using an ordinary zip seal bag alone, and at such a cheap price, I feel it more than pays for itself.

In the video, I demo both the Reynolds and the Ziploc so you can see how they match up to eachother. Also, you'll notice that the Ziploc bags can be used with the Reynolds sealer ,which is good to know if the Reynolds bags are no longer available in your area, and you own one too.

My toenails had gotten thick and slightly yellow, so I decided to try Kerasal Nail to see if it would help. After just a week or two, my toe nails were clear, the thickness had returned to normal, and they were no longer brittle. It's simple to use (just apply to clean, dry toenails by rubbing the applicator tip over the nail, around the cuticle, and along the open edge of the nail once a day, at bedtime), and there's no staining of socks, sheets, or other fabrics. No strange odors, no weird sensations, nothing. Just let it dry for a few minutes before putting socks on, if you're going to put them on after applying the treatment.

As someone who is normally hesitant to use sleep aids, I am glad that I have finally found one in Active Rest that I feel comfortable using. Now, after several weeks of using the product, I have seen first hand the benefits of taking Active Rest before going to sleep each night. This is a review and two questions. My review: The manual says to be careful when I cut the tube to fit around the ear. Well...I cut a little too much, and so the tube is too short now. I called the company and explained the situation. The tube kit, which also includes dome-shaped plug, is $25.90 for pair. plus $3.95 S&H. So, be careful when you cut the tube because they don't sell just the tube. The customer service also said that they sell a thin tube kit, which they say is more invisible, for $34.90. plus $3.95 S&H. I guess this is a must because, although I was impressed with how well it worked, I was a bit disappointed with the size, and how visible it was. My questions: How do I make sure that tubes don't fall off. When I pull out the plug, the tube often gets disconnected. Is it ok to glue it? That is, I carefully use crazy glue so i don't clog the tube. Another question is about the setting. H is for those who have sloping hearing loss. But what if I have a little bit of both? I set my volume to about 1 and 1/3 under N. it gets too loud if i set it to 2. So, i guess my hearing loss isn't that bad. but it gets worse when there are distractions like in outside. Are there many people who switch from N (low pitch) to H (High Pitch, distraction) when they go out in a crowd? And then, back to N when they come indoor?

ATG, WTG, XTG...is my method.
Prep is VERY important!!!
